story:
The Idea.

We want to create a colorful and artistic dance cover of the song Boy With Luv by BTS. Taking stylistic inspiration from the ARMY with Luv music video version, we will film in beautiful locations around the Seattle area. This Indiegogo campaign will help offset costs for equipment and permit fees for our crew, who are donating their time & expertise to the project to add to their film portfolios.

The Crew.

Our director and cinematographer for the video are Shelby Bowen and Preston Standiferd - two local filmmakers in the Seattle area. Each attended Seattle Film Institute and have experience working on several different types of projects - from short films to dance covers.
"Our ultimate goal with everything we create is to share human stories and connect the people around us. We'll be bringing on people we've both worked with in the past in order to make this project successful!"

The Dancers.

The dance project is led by Mitch LeSage, who has performed in many kpop dance covers and competitions and has led dance workshops and other events in the Seattle kpop community. Joining Mitch are Samantha and Vanessa, who have been a part of dance covers and workshops in the past, and have worked long and hard to bring Boy With Luv to life.

What We Need.

Now it's time for the nitty gritty. The budget. We sat down and planned out three different tiers, depending on how much funding we're able to work with -- a base, a median and the ideal. We're obviously hoping to be fully funded so that we can make this project everything we want it to be, but we're prepared with back-ups in the event that doesn't happen. Your donations will be going toward the following categories:

  • Equipment rentals

  • Location permits/fees

  • Insurance

  • On-set food & water for dancers and crew

  • In the (miraculous) event that we are over-funded, all residual funds will be donated to UNICEF in BTS' name.

What You Get.

Every single person that makes a donation toward this project will be listed in the credits of our project, as well as a video message from the crew to say thank you. We'll also be looking for extras, so if you're in the Seattle area, keep your ear out for our casting call!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't able to donate, you can help by simply spreading the word about our campaign!

story:
Short Summary

This play is something one could call a culmination of our friendship so far: we've always been united by our common philosophical and artistic interests, especially where really weird abstract stuff is concerned, and we've worked on many theatrical projects together, but this is the first one that's totally us. 

"Cataclysms" is a play about two friends trying to connect to each other while a seemingly insurmountable gap, filled to the brim with surrealistic horrors, spreads out between them. With it, we are marking what our friendship has achieved, and imagining what human connection, in general, can achieve.

What We Need

Obviously art is expensive: theatre especially so because it so often has a menagerie of moving parts attached to it. We have over twenty props and costume pieces to use throughout this show, and the purchase of all those props is right now coming out of our own pockets. Our hope with this campaign is to defray the cost of these props and also to save money for future artistic projects like this one.

The Impact

Both of us have put out weird works that have to do with people on the margins of society, and we feel like people suffering from Mental Health definitely count in that category. Our hopeful impact with this is to chip away at the stigma surrounding mental health conversations and encourage the people who see it to reach out to others, regardless of what side of this issue they stand on.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're broke like us, no biggie! You can help us in these ways:

1. If you live in ABQ: Help us out with props or costumes! Hit us up by email and we'll let you know what small items we are currently lacking and you let us know where we can find 'em.

2. If you don't live in ABQ: Share this with your friends! HELP US DROWN IN FAME or whatever.

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Greetings! We are Coffee & Whiskey Productions! If you don't know us yet, you should, becuase we're doing things! Big Things! Well it depends on how you define big, but still-- things! 

Coffee & Whiskey was founded in 2014 by Matt Diel and Nic Wehrwein, two playwrights fed up with the traditional model of play readings, who decided to do something about it. Coffee & Whiskey wants to create something of real value for playwrights and audiences. Our goal is not only to create kick-ass entertaining theatre that makes you laugh and cry and sing along, but also to change the conversations that happen during new play development. Making them better... stronger... faster. We can rebuild them. We have the technology. But we need your help to do it.

 

What We Do

The Coffee & Whiskey season is made up of the Script Pub (our developmental reading series), and the Productions (our other endeavors, like variety shows, karaoke theatre, etc.)

Since the founding of the Script Pub, we've been fortunate to present an amazing array of fantastic plays, written by a collection of wonderful playwrights from all over these United States. We've showcased the work of O'Neill finalists, National Latino Playwrighting Award Winners, and Kilroy List honorees. We’ve seen ghost comedians and tragedy survivors; we’ve seen cosmic love stories; we’ve grappled with family secrets and personal revelations, and it has all been unbelievably awesome.

Hand in hand with the Script Pub are the Productions, which is our umbrella term for everything else that we do. Through the Productions initiative, we've presented several variety shows, as well as three original plays, including our signature show, Karaoke Night at Al Capone’s House of Pancakes! Every season is a chance to do something new, and we are always humbled and awed by the quality of work that we get to see and share with the world. 

 

Your Role in The Madness

As always, what we're in search of is a gigantic pile of money. Once obtained, we will take that pile of money and place it in an Olympic-sized swimming pool, and dive in a la Scrooge McDuck. Once we finish doing that, we will take the money out of the pool and exchange it for goods and services. Thus will the Coffee & Whiskey season be born!

Seriously though, each and every thing we do requires money, for such things as:

theatre space

rehearsal space

lots of cardboard

the time and talent of the artists involved

100% of the money we earn from this campaign will go directly to funding Coffee & Whiskey’s general operations fund—paying the artists, renting the spaces, set-building materials, all that coffee you drink at the Script Pubs, the whole shebang. And everything helps. Whether you have one dollar or a hundred dollars or ten thousand dollars, we can and will use it to make theatre happen. (Obviously, we’ll make a lot more theatre with the ten thousand dollars than with the one dollar, but hey, we work with what we have.)

And to entice you, we've procured some sweet perks for your enjoyment! Stickers and T-shirts and mugs and pint glasses and limited-edition gear and probably some other secret things that we can’t talk about now because the lizard people are everywhere, watching, waiting, the unblinking eye of the Illoumalnati always watching us....

Ahem. Sorry. Give generously, is the point here.

 

Why It’s Important

"Theatre is Conversation" is more than just a pithy motto—it’s our guiding principle. We believe in fostering the true, honest conversations that are so very vital to us as playwrights, as actors, as audience members, and as human beings. That only happens when everyone has an equal voice. At Coffee & Whiskey, we say come as you are, and screw all the people who say you can’t or shouldn’t. Raise your voice above theirs and join the conversation.

This is where they say we’re supposed to talk about our playwrights’ success and the great things we’ve accomplished and how generally cool we are. But we’d much rather let some of our collaborators speak for themselves:

“I have worked with Coffee & Whiskey Productions twice and had amazing experiences both times... without the feedback that I got from Coffee & Whiskey Productions I do not think I would have been able to make the progress on that play that I made.” – Casey Mraz, author of The Giraffe

“When so many submissions either go unanswered or are met with a simple automated rejection email, I greatly appreciated that they were willing to be honest with me, and that they saw something in my work that they felt was worth cultivating... I know for a fact that it is a much better play as a result of this process.” – Conor McShane, author of The Letter G

“...their minimalist production was eye-opening. The presentation, the audience reaction, the comments afterward and the new perspective, everything. As a direct result of all this, I turned Companions into an audio drama, which I think is the best single work I've ever done... I'm convinced that none of this would have happened in the same way if not for Coffee & Whiskey.” – Bob Koester, author of Companions

 

Risks & Challenges

The risk is that you’ll cause the downfall of man. We're talking extinction level event. Sure, you don't think that's possible--  but then it happens. That one playwright, the one who just needs a little encouragement, the one who could be a beacon of light and love for humanity... instead of the positive experience of a Script Pub, they receive one more rejection letter. Their heart becomes dark, and they turn to the cold embrace of science, free from morality and filled with bitter disdain for humanity. Next thing you know? It's apocalypse time. Will it be zombies? Robots? Robot zombies? A planet where apes evolve from man? You'll never know for sure. You'll just know that you could have prevented it, BUT YOU DIDN'T.

Seriously, though, your risk is basically zero. You get to help the arts flourish, we get to do what we love, and some deserving playwrights get the critical feedback they need to take the next step and hopefully win a Pulitzer or a Tony or something. Who wouldn’t want to be a part of that?

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute directly, you can still help us by getting the word out. Tell everyone you know about Coffee & Whiskey and the work that we do, and let them know how to support it. Share it on Instagram, share it on Facebook, tweet that mess! Everything helps.

Next time you come to see a Coffee & Whiskey show, bring two people along-- we'll thank you for it, and they might also!

story:
Wide Eyed loves Colorado! 

Wide Eyed Productions was conceived in Colorado and born in New York. Since 2007, founders Liz White, Sky Seals & Kristin Skye Hoffmann (all alumni from the University of Northern Colorado) have been driving Wide Eyed to produce terrific independent theatre for the artistic community of New York City.  Producing prolifically from day one, the company is currently dedicated to the exclusive focus upon new works by emerging playwrights.  So committed are we to this cause that we decided to go back to our roots and bring some of our work to the Denver theatre community.  

This fall, we will proudly present the Colorado premiere of theMumblings by Dan Kitrosser, Wide Eyed's Resident Playwright.  This beautiful two-person production follows JODIE and ALLEN, a charming couple with a bit of an unconventional arrangement.  You see, JODIE is straight and ALLEN is gay. They are best friends and they are married.  Join them as they show you what events in their lives led to this most perfect union as they play out other characters from one another's past. This subtly dark and very funny tale first premiered at the New York International Fringe Festival (FringeNYC) to critical acclaim.  

Starring original Wide Eyed Productions company member and current Denver resident Lauren Bahlman, UNC alumnus Lanny Boyer, and directed by Wide Eyed's Artistic Director, Kristin Skye Hoffmann, this production is sure to be a special addition to the artistic landscape of the great city of Denver.  

Our Design/Tech Team Comes from Colorado! 

Kenny Storms (Sound Design) - Kenny has most recently been working as Resident Sound Designer for The Edge Theatre Company, The LIDA Project and The Athena Project in Denver.  He has been a teaching artist and Children’s Coordinator for The Denver Center for the Performing Arts and served as the Artistic Director for the Denver Repertory Theatre Company and Freestyle Productions.  He taught theater/speech to both middle and high school students at the Academy of Charter Schools and the DCPA.  He has directed and self-produced numerous productions both regionally in Denver and abroad in Baltimore, Ireland.  He received his BA in Theatre Arts from the University of Northern Colorado.

Anshuman Bhatia (Scenic Design) - Mr. Bhatia’s designs for Dance, Opera and Theatre have been seen at Beijing’s National Center for the Performing Arts, Canada’s Royal Winnipeg Ballet, Soho Rep, The Public, The Atlantic, Arena Stage in Washington D.C., The Julliard Schoo, HERE Arts Center, LoftOpera, Ma-Yi Theatre company, Lincoln Center Director’s Lab, Infinity Theatre Company, The University of Denver, and The New School for Drama.  His associate designs have been seen at the New York Philharmonic, Central City Opera in Colorado, Washington Ballet, Roundabout Theatre, the Guggenheim Museum, Opera Theatre of Saint Louis and BAM.  Upcoming work can be seen at Bard, Brown, Julliard, LaMama, 59e59 and Adirondack Theatre Festival. MFA NYU.  www.bhatiadesign.com

Kevin Fulton (Lighting Design) - Kevin is a designer and collaborative theatre maker from Denver.  His work has also been seen in Poughkeepsie and Boston.  Recent credits include: The Most Deserving (Denver Center Theatre Co.), DEAD DRUNK: A New Play by Shakesbeer (Diebolt Brewing), Gruesome Playground Injuries (Triptych Theatre Co.), On the Edge Festival (The Edge Theatre), Fat Men in Skirts (Philalethieis Society).  Education: Vassar College, BA in Drama. 

Melissa McCallum (Costume Design) - Melissa is a costume designer and dresser working currently in Denver. Before her recent move to Denver, she worked with Norwegian Cruise Lines as a wardrobe supervisor and stitcher. Other credits include: Costumer Assistant for Casa Valentina (The Edge Theatre), Costume Shop Assistant at West Texas A&M University, and Costume Intern at Central City Opera. She graduated West Texas A&M University with a BA in Theatre.

Ashley Powell (Production Stage Manager) - Ashley is thrilled to make her reprise to the Denver stage with theMumblings. Her previous technical credits include stage management, run crew, and design with Paragon theatre. She was also a stage hand with Colorado Heights University event space. She attended Goucher College in Baltimore Maryland, majoring in theatre.  A Denver native, and a story teller, Ashley is proud to share this remarkable tale with you. 

A Note from the Director about theMumblings 

Playwright Dan Kitrosser gets people.  I’ve known him for a while and, in that time, I’ve been privileged enough to work on several of his plays. In each play, the evidence is there: Dan understands what humans are all about, and he puts that divine understanding in all his work.  He is sneaky about it, though.  He distracts you with humor or a story or a theatrical device that makes you think you’re in for something usual, something you’d expect to see at the theatre.  Then, with stealth and strategic methodology, he holds a mirror up to each individual audience member and reminds them who they really are.  It is my great honor to be one of Dan’s devices, a tool to help him hold up the mirror. 

I love theMumblings.  It is as special and dark and beautiful as life tends to be.  Certainly JODIE and ALLEN are unique individuals in an unconventional situation, but the more I work on this play, the more I realize that they are everyone.  Perhaps that is why they portray so many people from one another’s past.  Truly, who among us is immune to fear?  Who is so strong that they are able to side step it completely?  I’ve yet to meet that person, but I so wish I could because I would convince them to tell me their secret.  I believe that we as humans are worthy of everything life has to offer.  We each deserve support, companionship, success and romantic love.  Allowing trauma, dread, worry and fear to box us in is cheating ourselves and the people around us.  If I do my job right, both actors will travel deep into the truth of each and every character they portray, and mine out moments that will help every audience member access a feeling loneliness and fear so they may see it clearly before releasing it.  Or maybe, if we don’t inspire that level of self-reflection, perhaps we will just encourage a new level of acceptance for people who are living life a little differently than we are, and remember that not everything is as good or bad as it may seem from the outside. 

What it will cost to produce theMumblings 

Putting up a play is hard work, but more than that, it costs a little bit to fully realize the work.  Below, you’ll find a general breakdown of what we estimate it will cost to make theMumblings happen in Denver in fall of 2016 with a little breakdown of where that money actually goes.

With these estimated costs, our show will require approximately $18,220 to realize full production.  It is a large number, but it is not impossible to reach - not with the help of our community and supporters. Thank you for taking the time to look this over!

  -theMumblings Team

***

Renting our theatre for a 4-week run - $7367

We will be performing our play at The Bakery Arts Warehouse in the heart of downtown Denver. This is a small venue without many fancy frills but, artistically, it is perfect for what we are doing.  The cost of rent is based entirely upon our use of the space, and gives us exclusive rights to the venue.

(In comparison, a venue like this in New York would cost about $16,000 to rent for a 4-week run.)

Rehearsal space - $100

Something that Denver has plenty of is space and, with our small cast, we are able to make use of private residences and donated free space from different locations around the city.  We did put aside a bit of money just in case we are in desperate need of a legitimate rehearsal space. Most companies in Colorado have their own theatre in which they may rehearse.  This independent production company does not yet have their “home” in Denver, so we may have to invest a little in this area.

Marketing Fees - $1500

Since we are a new company to the Denver theatrical scene, it is important that we get the word out as best we can!  That means marketing. In addition to printing posters and postcards and putting them up all over town, we must purchase ad space in publications like The Westword, The Denver Post, and more.  We have even budgeted for a Press Representative to help us with this process so we can receive reviews from our colleagues in the industry.  We want this production to be well-attended and well-received, and that means we must get the word out in every way we can.

Concessions costs - $200

Not only do we want our audience to have a great night at the theatre, we want to bring in a little extra money to pay for all of this fun stuff.  We satisfy both objectives by providing beer, wine and snacks available for a suggested donation.  The way we begin this process is by buying candy, chips and soda in bulk at Costco or Sam's Club so we can get the lowest cost per unit.  If we are really lucky, we will be able get a beer sponsor - and that is definitely on our search list as we move into our next phase of production. (Would you like to be our beer sponsor? Do you know someone who would? Please let us know!)

Set design materials - $1000

theMumbings takes place in an apartment, and so we must transform The Bakery into said apartment.  Set Designer, Anshuman Bhatia, a graduate of DU and now resident of New York City, is thrilled to be able to make use of a beg, borrow and steal sensibility to make our set design as clean and impressive as possible.  We will be spending money on furniture, paint, lumber and more.

Costume design materials - $400

While there are only two  actors in our production, they play a great many characters.  When this convention is used in a play, it can sometimes come off as being silly or campy.  That sort of sensibility does not work for theMumblings.  Instead, we will use a basic outfit for each actor on which to build clear, clean, character-motivated pieces for each new persona.  Although this is not a period piece set in, say, the French Revolution or Renaissance England, sometimes contemporary pieces can be equally costly.

Sound and Lighting design materials - $200

Since The Bakery offers limited lighting instruments, much of our play will be lit with “practicals” or lights that are a part of the set, like lamps.  The items must mesh well with our set design concept and do their job at the same time.  We also have a top notch sound designer who may have to purchase rights to copyrighted sound files in order to create the world of the play with audible sound.

Transportation costs - $1400

Since this play brings our Director in from New York, transportation costs may seem a bit higher than most production budgets.  Getting to and from the east coast for auditions and rehearsals can cost a pretty penny.  We are lucky enough to have a playwright who is allowing us to do his play for only the cost of a plane ticket so that he may come see the show. In addition to airfare, the cost of gas and transportation for moving the set in and out of the theatre before and after our run adds up. Where we will save on rehearsal space, we will likely spend on transportation.

Designer Fees - $1550

Designers can make or break a production.  Luckily for us, we have an amazing team of talent to make our show visually and aurally effective before the actors even open their mouths.  The figure listed above is well under what professional designers usually get, but each of these artists are investing their time and talents into theMumblings because they believe in the work.  If it turns out we can pay them more, we certainly will. While designers are not required to be at every rehearsal, they do spend quite a bit of time drafting up design ideas and gathering pieces to make their vision a reality.  The investment of time is why their fees are smaller than that of the actors or directors who are required to be at every rehearsal and performance. 

Actor/Director/Producer/Stage Management/ Board Operator Fees - $5500

Our actors, Lauren Bahlman and Lanny Boyer, are taking on a HUGE task.  This is an 85-page script which will be investigated, picked apart, memorized and performed by two humans.  These two humans will be required to attend every rehearsal together and be at each and every performance.  Offering them each a mere $1000 for the task is more a gesture than anything else, but it will help them to pay for gas, meals, and a little extra. We’d give them each a million if we could. 

There cannot be a great production without a great Stage Manager.  The Stage Manager makes sure all props and costumes are safe and sound before and after each performance, keeps bandages and hair ties handy in case something happens, and “calls” our show - meaning they operate our light and sound board from a booth so that all the technical elements that the designers have so meticulously put into place are employed with perfect flow.  Again, this stipend is low compared to what many professional Stage Managers get,  but we are a low budget production with a lot of heart, and that tends to draw the best people out.

Our director/producer, Kristin Skye Hoffmann, has been the driving force behind this project from the beginning.  She has worked hard in pre-production, securing rights to the play, guiding a graphic design for the play, arranging a venue, interviewing designers, arranging auditions and casting the play,  setting up a fundraising campaign as well as doing her best to drum up interest in the project by promoting it on social media sites and beyond.  This job will continue well through the rehearsal process and into production.  In fact, she will away from her home in NYC for two solid months to be in Denver for each rehearsal and performance, as well as for the breakdown of the set once the show closes.  This role is by far the most time-consuming. 

***

If You Help Us...

Not only will you receive a giant dose of great karma in the grand scheme of things, your donation also gets you some perks! Claim your VIP seats when you get your ticket here in advance, snag a sweet, signed poster from our team, or enjoy a complimentary drink when you arrive at the show. It all adds up, friends, so give, give, give! As an added incentive, you can get a tax write off, because Wide Eyed Productions is a 501(c)3 not-for-profit organization. The more you give to the arts, the less you give the government! Nice work, you!
story_txt:
Wide Eyed loves Colorado!  Wide Eyed Productions was conceived in Colorado and born in New York. Since 2007, founders Liz White, Sky Seals & Kristin Skye Hoffmann (all alumni from the University of Northern Colorado) have been driving Wide Eyed to produce terrific independent theatre for the artistic community of New York City.  Producing prolifically from day one, the company is currently dedicated to the exclusive focus upon new works by emerging playwrights.  So committed are we to this cause that we decided to go back to our roots and bring some of our work to the Denver theatre community.  
This fall, we will proudly present the Colorado premiere of theMumblings by Dan Kitrosser, Wide Eyed's Resident Playwright.  This beautiful two-person production follows JODIE and ALLEN, a charming couple with a bit of an unconventional arrangement.  You see, JODIE is straight and ALLEN is gay. They are best friends and they are married.  Join them as they show you what events in their lives led to this most perfect union as they play out other characters from one another's past. This subtly dark and very funny tale first premiered at the New York International Fringe Festival (FringeNYC) to critical acclaim.  
Starring original Wide Eyed Productions company member and current Denver resident Lauren Bahlman, UNC alumnus Lanny Boyer, and directed by Wide Eyed's Artistic Director, Kristin Skye Hoffmann, this production is sure to be a special addition to the artistic landscape of the great city of Denver.  

Our Design/Tech Team Comes from Colorado! 

Kenny Storms (Sound
Design) - Kenny has most recently been working as Resident Sound Designer
for The Edge Theatre Company, The LIDA Project and The Athena Project in
Denver.  He has been a teaching artist
and Children’s Coordinator for The Denver Center for the Performing Arts and
served as the Artistic Director for the Denver Repertory Theatre Company and Freestyle
Productions.  He taught theater/speech to
both middle and high school students at the Academy of Charter Schools and the
DCPA.  He has directed and self-produced
numerous productions both regionally in Denver and abroad in Baltimore,
Ireland.  He received his BA in Theatre
Arts from the University of Northern Colorado. 
Anshuman Bhatia (Scenic
Design) - Mr. Bhatia’s designs for Dance, Opera and Theatre have been seen
at Beijing’s National Center for the Performing Arts, Canada’s Royal Winnipeg
Ballet, Soho Rep, The Public, The Atlantic, Arena Stage in Washington D.C., The
Julliard Schoo, HERE Arts Center, LoftOpera, Ma-Yi Theatre company, Lincoln
Center Director’s Lab, Infinity Theatre Company, The University of Denver, and
The New School for Drama.  His associate
designs have been seen at the New York Philharmonic, Central City Opera in
Colorado, Washington Ballet, Roundabout Theatre, the Guggenheim Museum, Opera
Theatre of Saint Louis and BAM.  Upcoming
work can be seen at Bard, Brown, Julliard, LaMama, 59e59 and Adirondack Theatre
Festival. MFA NYU.  www.bhatiadesign.com 
Kevin Fulton (Lighting
Design) - Kevin is a designer and collaborative theatre maker from
Denver.  His work has also been seen in
Poughkeepsie and Boston.  Recent credits
include: The Most Deserving (Denver
Center Theatre Co.), DEAD DRUNK: A New Play
by Shakesbeer (Diebolt Brewing), Gruesome
Playground Injuries (Triptych Theatre Co.), On the Edge Festival (The Edge Theatre), Fat Men in Skirts (Philalethieis Society).  Education: Vassar College, BA in Drama. 

Melissa McCallum (Costume
Design) - Melissa is a costume designer and dresser working currently in
Denver. Before her recent move to Denver, she worked with Norwegian Cruise
Lines as a wardrobe supervisor and stitcher. Other credits include: Costumer
Assistant for Casa Valentina (The Edge Theatre), Costume Shop Assistant at West Texas
A&M University, and Costume Intern at Central City Opera. She graduated
West Texas A&M University with a BA in Theatre.



Ashley Powell (Production
Stage Manager) - Ashley is thrilled to make her reprise to the Denver stage
with theMumblings. Her previous
technical credits include stage management, run crew, and design with Paragon
theatre. She was also a stage hand with Colorado Heights University event
space. She attended Goucher College in Baltimore Maryland, majoring in
theatre.  A Denver native, and a story teller, Ashley is proud to share
this remarkable tale with you. 

A Note from the Director about theMumblings 



Playwright Dan Kitrosser gets people.  I’ve known him for a while and, in that time,
I’ve been privileged enough to work on several of his plays. In each play, the
evidence is there: Dan understands what
humans are all about, and he puts that divine understanding in all his
work.  He is sneaky about it,
though.  He distracts you with humor or a
story or a theatrical device that makes you think you’re in for something
usual, something you’d expect to see at the theatre.  Then, with stealth and strategic methodology,
he holds a mirror up to each individual audience member and reminds them who
they really are.  It is my great honor to
be one of Dan’s devices, a tool to help him hold up the mirror.  
I love theMumblings.  It is as special and dark and beautiful as
life tends to be.  Certainly JODIE and ALLEN
are unique individuals in an unconventional situation, but the more I work on
this play, the more I realize that they are everyone.  Perhaps that is why they portray so many
people from one another’s past.  Truly,
who among us is immune to fear?  Who is
so strong that they are able to side step it completely?  I’ve yet to meet that person, but I so wish I could
because I would convince them to tell me their secret.  I believe that we as humans are worthy of
everything life has to offer.  We each deserve
support, companionship, success and romantic love.  Allowing trauma, dread, worry and fear to box
us in is cheating ourselves and the people around us.  If I do my job right, both actors will travel
deep into the truth of each and every character they portray, and mine out
moments that will help every audience member access a feeling loneliness and fear
so they may see it clearly before releasing it.  Or maybe, if we don’t inspire that level of
self-reflection, perhaps we will just encourage a new level of acceptance for people
who are living life a little differently than we are, and remember that not
everything is as good or bad as it may seem from the outside. 

    What it will cost to produce theMumblings 

Putting
up a play is hard work, but more than that, it costs a little bit to fully realize the work.  Below, you’ll find a general
breakdown of what we estimate it will cost to make theMumblings happen in Denver in fall of
2016 with a little breakdown of where that money actually goes. With these estimated costs, our show will require approximately $18,220 to realize full production.  It is a large number, but it is not impossible to reach - not with the help of our community and supporters. Thank you for taking the time to look this over!  -theMumblings Team
***
Renting our theatre for a 4-week run - $7367
We will be
performing our play at The Bakery Arts Warehouse in the heart of downtown Denver. This
is a small venue without many fancy frills but, artistically, it is perfect for
what we are doing.  The cost of rent is
based entirely upon our use of the space, and gives us exclusive rights to the
venue. 
(In comparison, a
venue like this in New York would cost about $16,000 to rent for a 4-week run.)
Rehearsal space - $100
Something that
Denver has plenty of is space and, with our small cast, we are able to
make use of private residences and donated free space from different locations
around the city.  We did put aside a bit
of money just in case we are in desperate need of a legitimate rehearsal space.
Most companies in Colorado have their own theatre in which they may
rehearse.  This independent production
company does not yet have their “home” in Denver, so we may have to invest a
little in this area. 
Marketing Fees - $1500
Since we are a new
company to the Denver theatrical scene, it is important that we get the word out
as best we can!  That means marketing. In addition to
printing posters and postcards and putting them up all over town, we must purchase ad space in publications
like The Westword, The Denver Post, and more. 
We have even budgeted for a Press Representative to help us with this
process so we can receive reviews from our colleagues in the industry.  We want this production to be well-attended
and well-received, and that means we must get the word out in every way we
can. 
Concessions costs - $200
Not only do we want our audience
to have a great night at the theatre, we want to bring in a little extra money to pay for all of this fun stuff. 
We satisfy both objectives by providing beer, wine and snacks available for a suggested
donation.  The way we begin this process is by
buying candy, chips and soda in bulk at Costco or Sam's Club so we can get the lowest cost per unit.  If we are really lucky, we will be able get a beer
sponsor - and that is definitely on our search list as we move into our next
phase of production. (Would you like to be our beer sponsor? Do you know someone who would? Please let us know!)
Set design materials - $1000
theMumbings
takes place in an apartment, and so we must transform The Bakery into said
apartment.  Set Designer, Anshuman
Bhatia, a graduate of DU and now resident of New York City, is thrilled to be
able to make use of a beg, borrow and steal sensibility to make our set design as
clean and impressive as possible.  We
will be spending money on furniture, paint, lumber and more. 
Costume design materials - $400
While there are only
two  actors in our production, they play a great many characters.  When this convention is used in a play, it can
sometimes come off as being silly or campy.  That
sort of sensibility does not work for theMumblings.  Instead, we will use a basic outfit for each
actor on which to build clear, clean, character-motivated pieces for each new
persona.  Although this is not a period
piece set in, say, the French Revolution or Renaissance England, sometimes
contemporary pieces can be equally costly. 
Sound and Lighting design materials - $200
Since The Bakery
offers limited lighting instruments, much of our play will be lit with
“practicals” or lights that are a part of the set, like lamps.  The items must mesh well with our set design
concept and do their job at the same time. 
We also have a top notch sound designer who may have to purchase rights to copyrighted sound files in order to create the world of the play with audible sound. 
Transportation costs - $1400
Since this play
brings our Director in from New York, transportation costs may seem a bit
higher than most production budgets. 
Getting to and from the east coast for auditions and rehearsals can cost a
pretty penny.  We are lucky enough
to have a playwright who is allowing us to do his play for only the cost of a
plane ticket so that he may come see the show. In addition to airfare, the cost of gas and
transportation for moving the set in and out of the theatre before and after our run adds up. Where we will save on rehearsal space, we will likely spend on
transportation. 
Designer Fees - $1550
Designers can make
or break a production.  Luckily for us, we
have an amazing team of talent to make our show visually and aurally effective
before the actors even open their mouths. 
The figure listed above is well under what professional designers usually get, but
each of these artists are investing their time and talents into theMumblings because they believe in the
work.  If it turns out we can pay them
more, we certainly will. While designers are not required to be at every
rehearsal, they do spend quite a bit of time drafting up design ideas and
gathering pieces to make their vision a reality.  The investment of time is why their fees are
smaller than that of the actors or directors who are required to be at
every rehearsal and performance. 
Actor/Director/Producer/Stage Management/ Board Operator Fees - $5500
Our actors, Lauren Bahlman and
Lanny Boyer, are taking on a HUGE task. 
This is an 85-page script which will be investigated, picked apart,
memorized and performed by two humans. 
These two humans will be required to attend every rehearsal together and
be at each and every performance. 
Offering them each a mere $1000 for the task is more a gesture than anything
else, but it will help them to pay for gas, meals, and a little extra. We’d give
them each a million if we could. There cannot be a great production without a great Stage Manager.  The Stage Manager makes sure all props and costumes are safe and sound before and after each performance, keeps bandages and hair ties handy in case something happens, and “calls” our show - meaning they operate our light and sound board from a booth so that all the technical elements that the designers have so meticulously put into place are employed with perfect flow.  Again, this stipend is low compared to what many professional Stage Managers get,  but we are a low budget production with a lot of heart, and that tends to draw the best people out.Our
director/producer, Kristin Skye Hoffmann, has been the driving force behind
this project from the beginning.  She has worked
hard in pre-production, securing rights to the play, guiding a graphic design
for the play, arranging a venue, interviewing designers, arranging auditions
and casting the play,  setting up a
fundraising campaign as well as doing her best to drum up interest in the
project by promoting it on social media sites and beyond.  This job will continue well through the
rehearsal process and into production. 
In fact, she will away from her home in NYC for two solid months to be in Denver for
each rehearsal and performance, as well as for the breakdown of the set once the show
closes.  This role is by far the most
time-consuming. 
***If You Help Us...Not only will you receive a giant dose of great karma in the grand scheme of things, your donation also gets you some perks! Claim your VIP seats when you get your ticket here in advance, snag a sweet, signed poster from our team, or enjoy a complimentary drink when you arrive at the show. It all adds up, friends, so give, give, give! As an added incentive, you can get a tax write off, because Wide Eyed Productions is a 501(c)3 not-for-profit organization. The more you give to the arts, the less you give the government! Nice work, you!

story:
Summary

Danza Fiesta: Baile y Teatro Puertorriqueño was created in 1998 by Gilda Rivera-Pantojas in NYC with the idea of sharing Puerto Rican culture with the rest of the world. The company has been fulfilling its mission through workshops and performances of Puerto Rican folklore and popular dances. Danza Fiesta features over 30 members, including dancers, musicians, singers and other creative contributors. They devote time and energy to the study of Puerto Rican folk and popular traditions, making it accessible to all people.

Now!, For the first time ever, Danza Fiesta has the honor to travel to Puerto Rico in June 2012 and make history by sharing the stage with local folk companies from around the island at the “Puerto Rico sabe a Cultura Festival”.

Gilda Rivera-Pantojas, founder, artistic director Mrs. Rivera-Pantojas was a dancer and choreographer for Gíbaro, served as director and choreographer for COPANI, and co-founded Ballet Isleño. In 1996 Mrs. Rivera-Pantojas received a MA in Dance Education from Columbia University Teachers College and joined Boricua College as an assistant professor. Mrs. Rivera-Pantojas work with the community has been recognized by organizations such as Comite Noviembre, Instituto de Puerto Rico, the Puerto Rican Heritage House and Union Square Awards. Her choreographic work reflects all the aspects of the Puerto Rican inheritance from the different cultures that arrive to the island and mixed to create what we know today as folklore. Since the 1970’s her work has been shown all over the world first with Gibaro de Puerto Rico, later with Ballet Isleño and now a days with Danza Fiesta: Baile y Teatro Puertorriqueño.

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $5,000 to support the travel expenses of the group from NYC to San Juan, Puerto Rico. This effort has been organized by Diversity in Arts and Nations for Cultural Education and Gibaro de Puerto Rico who has traveled the world as cultural ambassador for the Puerto Rican culture. By inviting Danza Fiesta the festival aims to pay homage the Puerto Rican living outside the island. The target amount is only a fraction the total cost but every bit is important and very special to us. Help us make history in Puerto Rico, we will share our experience through videos and photos.

See our special perks for your generous contribution!

Donations are tax deductible !

The Impact

This journey is not just a trip- it’s history in the making! It’s about building bridges between the Puerto Rican community living in the island and the Diaspora living in the mainland. This cultural experience is an opportunity to learn from a shared folklore and tradition in performance.

What happens once we get there? The possibilities are endless.

Welcome reception with Gibaro de Puerto Rico.

Workshops, exchange and networking with other artists participating in the festival.

Site visits, including the "Instituto de Cultura".

The main event, "Puerto Rico sabe a cultura" will be held on Sunday June 24th at the "Plazoleta del Centro de Bellas Artes" in Santurce. The event will be dedicated to the Puerto Ricans living in New York.

Other Ways You Can Help

Share this campaign with family, friends and everyone you know. Also be sure to share on Facebook, Twitter and Email. Share our story. Share the work of Danza Fiesta.

With much love we thank you for your generosity!

story:
A todos los amigos de Las 5 Estaciones:

Estamos muy agradecidos por su participación y apoyo a nuestro proyecto. Queremos contarles que por motivos de fuerza mayor, la Producción Ejecutiva tomó la decisión de posponer el proyecto de manera indefinida.

Para nosotros fue muy importante haberlos hecho partícipes. Esperamos que hayan tenido grandes momentos de emoción y diversión con cada una de las cosas que con mucho agrado compartimos con ustedes. 

Por el momento, debemos pedirles que no hagan más contribuciones a esta campaña.

No nos fue fácil tomar esta decisión y sabemos que pueden tener preguntas al respecto, así que no duden en escribirnos al correo las5estaciones.circo@gmail.com. Estaremos muy atentos en darles una respuesta oportuna. 

Un abrazo muy grande, 

El equipo de Las 5 Estaciones

------------------------------------------------------------------

To all our friends:

First of all, we are very thankful for your support to our project. It is important for us to let you know that due to unforeseen circumstances, the Executive Production has decided to pospone the show indefinitely. 

It was very exciting for us to make you part of Las 5 Estaciones. We hope that you had plenty of moments of fun and amusement next to us. 

For the time being, we must ask you not to make any more contributions to this campaign. 

This was not an easy decision for us, and we are sure that you might have questions to ask. Please do not hesitate to contact us at: las5estaciones.circo@gmail.com. We will be looking forward to give you an appopriate response. 

Warm regards, 

Las 5 Estaciones Team

story:
Hello beautiful people of the Internet.

We are members of the Devised Theatre class of 2013 at York University.

It's very nice to meet you.

Over the past few years, our class has created pieces canvassing such topics as:  cannibalism, rave culture, Canadian serial killers, nuclear family dynamics, the surrealist movement, the Earths carrying capacity and general raging against the machine.

Still with me?

We are a brand new program, which means that the budget for Theatre@York has not yet been fully expanded to accomodate 4 more fully-fledged productions. We have access to studio space, which is a blessing, but the rest of... well, everything, comes from us.

So where will the money go you wonder? The answer, dear internet, is simple. It will go straight into making these shows as thrilling as humanly possible.
That means:
creating costumes 
building the set
lighting the show
LOUD NOISES (sound design)
advertisements/ flyers/ posters (we love posters, posters are key... I'm gonna say posters one more time... POSTERS)
and all of our many props!

As you can see, this is quite a feat. We could do it alone, but only if we all gave up food and shelter for the next few months so please, help us out.

If you can't donate at this time, please feel free to share the campaign via facebook, twitter, email, carrier pigeon, smoke signal, interpretive dance, or however your little heart desires. Everything helps.

THANK YOU SO MUCH FROM THE BOTTOM OF ALL OF OUR HEARTS (we have very deep hearts, so that is a lot of love coming your way)

story:
We need your support!  It's really expensive to costume 16 Puritans!*

*and countless other expenses

Support Custom Made's Annual Fund, and deduct your generous donation for 2013*!

(*for gifts received before 12/31/2013. Otherwise, keep your receipt for 2014!)


For 15 amazing seasons now, Custom Made has been an essential part of your community. In order to keep producing quality, thoughtful, exciting theatre, we need your support more than ever!  

Only 50% of our revenue comes from ticket sales - we need campaigns like the 15th Annual Fund, Holiday Fundraiser to help us not only survive, but thrive.

Our Annual Fund supports every aspect of our company, and we are asking you to become a member. When you donate to the Annual Fund, you are ensuring the survival of independent theatre in your community!

When you give, you get!  Check out the great perks, from Custom Made schwag (LED keychains!, tote-bags!), to becoming a Producer on one of our shows!  We know this isn't why you give, but we love to be able to give a little joy back, and to let you know how much we appreciate your support.

For over 40 weeks out of the year, Custom Made produces a play, musical or workshop.    We employ hundreds of Bay Area actors, designers, directors and arts administrators.  Over 6,000 patrons see our shows. 

Your support of the 2013/14 15th Anniversary Season's Annual Fund also ensures Custom Made's growth.  We have ambitious plans, including producing more original, local work, an education program, and increasing stipends for everyone who works at Custom Made.  

Thank you so much for donating this year.  Any amount helps, from $10 to $2,500. We cannot do this without you!

What We Need & What You Get:

In order to pay our artists, the rent, and the multitude of costs associated with year-round live theatre production, all while maintaining a commitment to low ticket prices, we need to raise $10,000 for this season's Annual Fund. 

By helping us reach our goal, you are making sure ticket costs stay subsidized.  Without our donors, we would have to raise prices to over $50, and would no longer be able to heavily discount tickets to students, senior, artists, and teachers. 

Any amount helps, and we've got great perks at every donation level!  Just check out all the goodies listed to your right.

For those of you who really dig numbers, here's an idea of what it costs to keep Custom Made's doors open this season:

$25,000 covers roughly a seasons' artistic staff (actors, director, designers, etc.)

$2,025 pays one month of our subsidized rent and insurance

$1,500 buys materials for one production's set, costumes, etc.

$1,000 supports subsidized mail-house/postage to distribute each play's postcards

$500 spreads the word about a show 

Other Ways You Can Help

We mean it when we say every little bit helps - and you'll see your donation put to use on the stage just a few feet in front of you!

If you're a fan of Custom Made, please help us spread the word at no cost at all by:

  • Sharing this campaign with your friends, colleagues, relatives, etc.
  • Using the Indiegogo tools for easy sharing via Facebook, Twitter and other social media platform faves

Thank you for all you do to support your local theatre community!  We look forward to seeing you at Gough Street Playhouse all season long!

Happy Holidays!  Love, Custom Made

story:
Irreverently Aggressive Theater

Just in time for your end of the year good conscience holiday donations: We're back! 

The Rum & Coke Collective continues a new tradition with our second original work, Endlings.  This manic dark comedy wakes up February 6th at the Berger Coach House in Chicago and we need your help.  It was with the help of generous supporters that we were able to start our season with APPLES & ROOFIES this past August!  

THAT SHOW ROCKED! WHAT'S NEXT?

Four strangers awaken in a dank room.  Not knowing how they arrived or when they will be able to leave, they quickly form alliances, each playing the other for supremacy.  However, their efforts prove useless in the face of a charming, all-knowing adversary.  Viciously funny and destructively unapologetic, Endlings is the definition of irreverently aggressive theater.

Featuring Collective members Lauren S. Deaton (Blair), Jared West (Jack),Sam Albertsen (Roger), Emma Jo Schumacher (Wren) and Jeff Newman (Doorman) and under the direction of Artistic Director J. W. Brewer and Collective Member Elyse Dawson, Endlings is a viciously sharp thriller that examines the question "What do you really know"?

WHERE DO I COME IN?

Putting up a show isn't cheap.  And pimpin' ain't easy.  We need your help to pay for what goes on stage in February.

This includes building a floor that's safe for brutal fights, Props, Costumes and Costume Holders.  AKA Actors.  The Rum & Coke Collective believes in the bold idea of making new work of a professional caliber.  This includes compensating the talented folk that make us look good (and a crew that glues it all together).

WHAT'S IN IT FOR ME?

We will compensate YOU for making US look good!  Check out our perks, which include, but are not limited to: things to put in your mouth, tickets to Endlings, as well as a serenade.  Not to mention that giving releases feel-good feels into the bloodstream. (Source: www.goodpeoplelovedoinggoodthings.com)

Don't live in Chicago?  No problem!  Perks are transferable!

I HAPPEN TO BE A GOOD PERSON!  WHAT HAPPENS NEXT?

The Rum & Coke Collective is producing an entire 2013-2014 season of resounding work.  If we exceed our goal, funds will go toward renting space for our next play, The Best Intentions of Selfish Men.  If we don't make our goal?  The money is still going directly into the brutal awakening of Endlings.

In other words...

WE WILL CONTINUE TO BLOW YOUR MIND.

HOW ELSE CAN I HELP?

Introduce us into your vernacular.  Tell your friends, family, and good looking strangers on the CTA about The Rum & Coke Collective.

Like us on Facebook: The Rum & Coke Collective
https://www.facebook.com/rumandcokecollective

Follow our Twitter: @RumandCokePlays https://twitter.com/RumandCokePlays 

Visit our webpage: http://rumandcoketheater.wix.com/rumandcoke

Most importantly, 

SEE ENDLINGS FEBRUARY 6th-23rd!

story:
Gehring Dancetheatre is a modern contemporary dance company based in New York City.  Created in 2003 by Heather Gehring and Emily Edwards, our style uses ballet and ballroom technique and fuses it with a more athletic contemporary aesthetic creating work that is described as "elegant" (Broadway Baby.com) and "graceful and athletic...interesting and engaging" (The Skinny, UK).  

 

It's hard to believe it has been 10 years already and yet, here we are.  And we want to celebrate in a big way: by sharing the exciting works we have created over the past 10 years.  We have outgrown all the venues we have been using and feel this is a great opportunity to make the jump to the next level of venue.  This, however, also comes with a jump in cost.  We are trying to raise $10,000 over the next 8 months, with several fundraising efforts to fund this wonderful achievement. These funds will go towards the cost of the venue, hiring a publicist so the show can get the attention it deserves, and paying our dancers.

When you give to this campaign we are offering rewards, such as limited edition 10th anniversary posters signed by the dancers, tickets to the show in June, and of course, a receipt for a charitable donation as we are a registered non-profit company. 

With your help, we can reach a larger audience than ever before.  Part of our mission statement is to share our love of dance with our audiences and you will be helping to do this in a very real way.  We believe that dance connects with people in a way few other art forms can, and with your help we can prove it. 

Please share this campaign with all your friends, as word of mouth is how we will be successful in this fundraiser.  Thank you so much for all your help.  We could and would not be here without you.

 

Heather Gehring, Artistic Director

Emily Edwards, Executive Director

 

www.gehringdancetheatre.org

story:
ODC Theater welcomes French director and performer, Astrid Bas, and accompanying dancers and artists in the dance-theater performance , “Life? or Theater?.”

Bas and her performers utilize dance and movement to honor the memory, life and work of Charlotte Salomon, a young artist and painter, victim of the Nazi regime.   The creation of this contemporary piece was inspired by Salomon’s work consisting of a series of gouaches regrouped as a small operetta, also titled “Life? or Theater?” (Leben? oder Theater: Ein singespiel).

This project was previously performed at the Performance Art Institute in October 2012 at the newly relocated space in SOMA district. The piece has since evolved greatly allowing new dancers and musicians to participate. 

 Astrid Bas has played and directed  severals works of theater for the past 20 years in France , Spain , Italy , Germany , USA and India.

http://www.astrid-bas.com/

http://frenchmorning.com/sanfrancisco/2013/03/01/la-comedienne-et-danseuse-astrid-bas-en-residence-a-san-francisco/ 

This inspiring performance depends on your help!  Our first and foremost expense needing coverage is compensation for the dancers.  The second priority is the payment of the dancers, and the third necessity is remuneration of the dancers!

Costumes, lighting and equipment must also be purchased in order to be ready for the upcoming event in July at ODC Theater .

Bas and her group need your financial contributions to support this project.  Your generosity will aid in preserving Charlotte Salomon’s memory and concurrently supporting the larger concept of art prevailing as a vital cultural component of our society.

All donations are greatly appreciated.  Thank you so much for your gift.

 Have a good DAY !!

Please contact us with any questions at lifeortheatershow@gmail.com

story:
What is LA VOCE TO ME?

LA VOCE TO ME is an original play about the interconnection of Hans Christian Andersen (author of the original story of The Little Mermaid), Howard Ashman (lyricist and composer for Disney's The Little Mermaid), and the local playwright Jeremy Pace. The experiences portrayed in the original fairy tale are echoed in the lives of these three men across time. Each of their own stories reflect the others in themes of love, sacrifice, death, and rebirth while also dealing with the gay experience, addiction, HIV and AIDS, and recovery.

What does LA VOCE TO ME mean? 

The phrase "la voce to me" is a lyric from the song "Pour Unfortunate Souls" in Disney's The Little Mermaid. Literally, it means "the voice to me" and represents the moment that Ariel's voice was taken in sacrifice by Ursula the Sea Witch. 

Impact of your Support

Participation in the Capital Fringe Festival 2013 is a priceless experience, but it still has its costs. This IndieGoGo campaign will allow us to pay for registration and insurance fees required by the festival as well as costumes, set, and modest compensation for our actors and crew. 

In return, you will be rewarded based on the level of your support. From written recognition of your name or a name in memoriam in our program, to an invitation to share your own story in our LA VOCE TO YOU project, to a handmade piece of art or jewelry, to a Q&A coffee session with the writer, and even a bound copy of the original script. Check the right hand side of this page for a list of potential rewards for your contribution. 

Boosting the Signal

While financial support ultimately pays the bills, this is a play about sharing our stories and regaining our voices! If the idea of this play touches you, please boost the signal and share it with others. 

Showtimes & Location

Thursday, July 11th — 5:30-6:45pm
Sunday, July 14th — 5:15-6:30pm
Saturday, July 20th — 5:15-6:30pm
Wednesday, July 24th — 6:30-7:45pm
Saturday, July 27th — 3:45-5:00pm 

Goethe Institut – Gallery
812 7th St NW in Washington, DC
Corner of Eye St NW and 7th St NW
Nearest Metro: Gallery Place Chinatown

story:
Ladies, lovers, and gentlefolks,

Your friend and humble narrator comes before you today to beseech your aid. As some of you may know, in its 3rd year, the Steampunk Industrial Revolution has come to an end. This was a convention that many members of Karnevil were present for its mythic birthing, and are quite sad to see it go..

BUT like a mighty phoenix, another New England Steampunk convention, the Air City Expedition, has risen to take its place, and we at the Karnevil Krewe want nothing more than to be there to help it be a rousing and arousing success! Sadly, though the folks at Air City have been more than accommodating, they have reached the limit of what they can provide us with, we will still need the help of you, our loving fans and members of the steam community, to help us get there. As poor travelling performers, in a gas hog of an '87 dodge van, we need some start up capital to get us from Southern New Jersey to New Hampshire.

We are asking for the minimum amount of money this site will allow, we do not necessarily need to meet the goal, but every penny contributed will help us immensely with gas, tolls, food, and any other travel expenses that may occur. We beg that you graciously open your hearts and your wallets to give us a hand and help us make the first year of this amazing new event everything that it can be. We promise to work our hardest to make every single patron of Air City have the most splendid weekend in the history of future past. So please, if you be a fan of ours, vaudeville, steampunk, the arts, or New England, we hope that you can find it in you to spare a few dollars and help us help others make dreams come true.

Thank you,
Arson of Karnevil

story:
Hello world, I’m Casandra.  I’m an educator, graphic designer, performance poet and hoop dancer.  I’ve volunteered with and helped manage major non-profit festivals and special events in Palm Beach County and elsewhere since 1996, notably SunFest, Palm Beach Photographic Centre’s FOTOFusion, and the National Poetry Slam (2005, 2009, 2010, 2011). 

I currently enjoy working as Program Director for the Milagro Center, a non-profit arts-enrichment afterschool and outreach center for at-risk youth in Delray Beach, FL.

Florida Flow Fest 2012 is my most ambitious undertaking, and a true labor of love. The fest offers hour-long workshops in each of the following object manipulation, circus art and movement disciplines: poi spinning, hoop dancing/hooping, staff spinning, juggling, belly dance, African dance, Tai Chi, Capoeira, and yoga.  Additionally, this year a number of freshly emerging prop practices will be taught, such as: puppyhammer, rope dart and acro yoga combined with slackline balancing, a practice known as ‘slackro’. 

This year, the festival is in its second year, and has drawn upon tremendous support as a result of the joy generated by last year’s inaugural event.  The fire spinning, yoga and dance community state-wide relish this opportunity to learn and share together, and to broadcast the benefits of participating in the FLOW ARTS.  Many participants have been waiting ALL YEAR to rejoin this incredible community, a small slice of tropical bliss on the first weekend of Flow-vember!

We adore our sponsors: SpinBalls, Groovolution Dance Studio, Elemental Expressions Entertainment, The Kwak, Gratitude Training, Expand the Love, Master Ong's Prop Shop, Alternative Movement, Jai Healing Arts, All En Academy of Dance, Capoeira Karkara and Wisdom Method School of Yoga!!!

And, even with their loving support...

We need cash!

Because FloridaFlowFest is a PUBLIC festival, we are in need of financial support from the community to have it be OPEN to the general public.

$2,500 is needed to cover security for the festival

$1,200 is needed to cover the safety fees associated with spinning fire in public (from barricades, to permit fees and fire watch)

$2,300 is needed to cover the transportation fees of our artist instructors, many of whom travel from a great distance to share with our Florida community.

 

What YOU can get:

$50 gets you a custom designed hoola-hoop, made by Hoop So Fly master hoopmaker Danielle, and shipped directly to you!

 

$100 gets you 2 Florida Flow Fest 2013 tickets, (November 1-3, 2013) and our roster for next year is TRULY INCREDIBLE.  I don’t want to spoil the fun by naming names, but it will be a fabulous event, with some elements presented in tandem with the Ft Lauderdale Yoga Journal Conference, happening the SAME WEEKEND!

 

$500 gets you a private fire dance performance, 2 performers for a 1 hour performance, in any upcoming event in southeast Florida, from Miami to Melbourne.

 

Every little bit helps, truly.  If we don’t raise all $6000, we will STILL have our festival this year, and we will begin MUCH earlier for NEXT YEAR’S festival.  If we RAISE ALL $6000, and any is left after we pay our costs, that money will go into the start-up fund for our Florida Flow Arts non-profit.

 

WHAT ARE FLOW ARTS?

Flow arts are forms of movement and dance that utilize props to enter a state of flow, described by psychologist Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi as an exhilarating transcendent way of being in which effortless control and peak skill seem to erase a sense of time. Flow arts props include poi, staff and hoops; dancers manipulate props to add to the expressive qualities of their dance. The result is an awe-inspiring visual spectacle of improvised movement that inspires an audience to reconsider kinetic possibilities.

 

Our eventual goal for the Florida Flow Fest is convert it into a major fundraiser and programming element of a South Florida based FLOW ARTS non-profit that delivers cutting-edge curriculum in the flow arts to K-12 classrooms statewide, inviting young people to achieve higher levels of critical thinking, coordination and balance, while allowing them to explore the physical world through the lens of play and discovery.  Accessing the flow state of consciousness is a key element in developing a harmonious connection with all of life, and in expressing one’s purpose in life.

 

We are STILL selling tickets for this year’s workshops, so PLEASE spread the word:

“Hey friends, great event coming up: Florida Flow Fest NEXT WEEKEND at Bryant Park in Lake Worth!  3 days of flow arts, yoga, acro, capoeira and dance!  Buy your workshop ticket today: unlimited workshops Friday, Saturday and Sunday for $67!!! Enter promo code: FlowForAll”  www.floridaflowfest.com 

 

Instructors include international juggling festival stars and the nationally touring YogaSlackers.  Workshops are designed for adults interested in expanding their skill set and challenging their coordination, balance, concentration and creativity.   Attendees can purchase an all-access ticket to attend unlimited workshops throughout the weekend.  A free kidzone will open daily from 1pm-4pm for young people age 3 and up to sharpen and show off their hooping and juggling skills!

 

Find YOUR flow!

 

www.floridaflowfest.com and on facebook.com/floridaflowfest
story_txt:
Hello world, I’m Casandra.  I’m an educator, graphic designer, performance poet and hoop dancer.  I’ve volunteered with and helped manage major non-profit festivals and special events in Palm Beach County and elsewhere since 1996, notably SunFest, Palm Beach Photographic Centre’s FOTOFusion, and the National Poetry Slam (2005, 2009, 2010, 2011). 
I currently enjoy working as Program Director for the Milagro Center, a non-profit arts-enrichment afterschool and outreach center for at-risk youth in Delray Beach, FL.
Florida Flow Fest 2012 is my most ambitious undertaking, and a true labor of love. The fest offers hour-long workshops in each of the following object manipulation, circus art and movement disciplines: poi spinning, hoop dancing/hooping, staff spinning, juggling, belly dance, African dance, Tai Chi, Capoeira, and yoga.  Additionally, this year a number of freshly emerging prop practices will be taught, such as: puppyhammer, rope dart and acro yoga combined with slackline balancing, a practice known as ‘slackro’. 
This year, the festival is in its second year, and has drawn upon tremendous support as a result of the joy generated by last year’s inaugural event.  The fire spinning, yoga and dance community state-wide relish this opportunity to learn and share together, and to broadcast the benefits of participating in the FLOW ARTS.  Many participants have been waiting ALL YEAR to rejoin this incredible community, a small slice of tropical bliss on the first weekend of Flow-vember!
We adore our sponsors: SpinBalls, Groovolution Dance Studio, Elemental Expressions Entertainment, The Kwak, Gratitude Training, Expand the Love, Master Ong's Prop Shop, Alternative Movement, Jai Healing Arts, All En Academy of Dance, Capoeira Karkara and Wisdom Method School of Yoga!!!
And, even with their loving support...
We need cash!
Because FloridaFlowFest is a PUBLIC festival, we are in need of financial support from the community to have it be OPEN to the general public.
$2,500 is needed to cover security for the festival
$1,200 is needed to cover the safety fees associated with spinning fire in public (from barricades, to permit fees and fire watch)
$2,300 is needed to cover the transportation fees of our artist instructors, many of whom travel from a great distance to share with our Florida community.
 
What YOU can get:
$50 gets you a custom designed hoola-hoop, made by Hoop So Fly master hoopmaker Danielle, and shipped directly to you!
 
$100 gets you 2 Florida Flow Fest 2013 tickets, (November 1-3, 2013) and our roster for next year is TRULY INCREDIBLE.  I don’t want to spoil the fun by naming names, but it will be a fabulous event, with some elements presented in tandem with the Ft Lauderdale Yoga Journal Conference, happening the SAME WEEKEND!
 
$500 gets you a private fire dance performance, 2 performers for a 1 hour performance, in any upcoming event in southeast Florida, from Miami to Melbourne.
 
Every little bit helps, truly.  If we don’t raise all $6000, we will STILL have our festival this year, and we will begin MUCH earlier for NEXT YEAR’S festival.  If we RAISE ALL $6000, and any is left after we pay our costs, that money will go into the start-up fund for our Florida Flow Arts non-profit.
 
WHAT ARE FLOW ARTS?
Flow arts are forms of movement and dance that utilize props to enter a state of flow, described by psychologist Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi as an exhilarating transcendent way of being in which effortless control and peak skill seem to erase a sense of time. Flow arts props include poi, staff and hoops; dancers manipulate props to add to the expressive qualities of their dance. The result is an awe-inspiring visual spectacle of improvised movement that inspires an audience to reconsider kinetic possibilities.
 
Our eventual goal for the Florida Flow Fest is convert it into a major fundraiser and programming element of a South Florida based FLOW ARTS non-profit that delivers cutting-edge curriculum in the flow arts to K-12 classrooms statewide, inviting young people to achieve higher levels of critical thinking, coordination and balance, while allowing them to explore the physical world through the lens of play and discovery.  Accessing the flow state of consciousness is a key element in developing a harmonious connection with all of life, and in expressing one’s purpose in life.
 
We are STILL selling tickets for this year’s workshops, so PLEASE spread the word:
“Hey friends, great event coming up: Florida Flow Fest NEXT WEEKEND at Bryant Park in Lake Worth!  3 days of flow arts, yoga, acro, capoeira and dance!  Buy your workshop ticket today: unlimited workshops Friday, Saturday and Sunday for $67!!! Enter promo code: FlowForAll”  www.floridaflowfest.com 
 
Instructors include international juggling festival stars and the nationally touring YogaSlackers.  Workshops are designed for adults interested in expanding their skill set and challenging their coordination, balance, concentration and creativity.   Attendees can purchase an all-access ticket to attend unlimited workshops throughout the weekend.  A free kidzone will open daily from 1pm-4pm for young people age 3 and up to sharpen and show off their hooping and juggling skills!
 
Find YOUR flow!
 
www.floridaflowfest.com and on facebook.com/floridaflowfest

story:
Our Story

A pre-cursor to the National Matthew Shepard and James Byrd, Jr. Hate Crimes Prevention Act, the James Byrd Jr. Hate Crimes Act was passed in Texas in 2001. It served as a huge win for those fighting for human rights and was firmly planted as a reminder that together our potential to overcome adversity is stronger than a lone voice crying for help. However, it was the voice of one amazing woman that led the charge to include Gay Rights in the legislation. Suggested by actual events in Austin, Texas  Dennis Bailey's play is more than a history lesson, rather a celebration of the monumental win for Human Rights in Texas and the people who helped make it happen.

Since the bill was passed in Texas, there have been over 1,200 hate crimes reported, but only a dozen have been convicted.  

There is still work to be done. 

Theatre en Bloc is partnering with several LGBT organizations including Equality, TX to continue this necessary fight for justice and equality. 

The Impact

The fight for justice never ends. Homophobia and racism still exist. Hate Crimes still exist. And while there is much to celebrate in the passing of laws like The Matthew Shepard and James Byrd, Jr. Hate Crimes Prevention Act, this play is a reminder that the big wins only come by way of small acts of compaasion from dedicated individuals who refused to back down in the face of great adversity.

While this play will resonate wholly as the story of one woman's fight, we hope her story will inspire others to take up the sword and shield to defend justice for all people, no matter who they are. We are partnering with LGBT and human rights service organizations to create a movement of people who will not tolerate violence toward anyone predicated on hatred. 

We want to the ground to rumble with the sound of people stomping out the rhythm of equality! Where today people fear they might be harrassed or murdered for who they are - we want would be murderers to fear the multitude of people who stand together, ready to defend civil liberty!

The message of acceptance and inclusion is always necessary. This production lives perfectly in between a gripping night of theatre and a social call to action. We feel the reach of this project will be immense.

What We Need & What You Get

We are asking for $10,000 and we want to build confidence with you, our potential funders, by letting you know exactly where we're going to spend every dollar.

First, Theatre en Bloc is an itinerant company and we hve to pay for a space to do the show. Our venue contract is for $3900. That covers a three week run for a toal of nine perofrmances. 

Second we like to pay our artists for their time. We are a small, young organization and cannot pay the wages these talented folks deserve, but we we are offering them stipends. The actors, all nine of them, will receive $300 each. Our designers for the lights, costumes, sound and projections are each receiving $300 for their work as well. We also need to pay 3 individuals to help run the scene changes, light board and sound board. Those three folks will get a $100 stipend each. 

The total pricetag for these modest stipends is $4200.

We need to provide budgets for materials for the designers to use to execute their designs. The set design has an $800 budget. Costumes have a $400 budget. Sound has a $100 budget and lights have a $200 budget. The total budget for the materials for the show is $1500.

Lastly, we are going to need to promote the show. We have budgeted $900 to cover poster and print material printing, photos and a professionally filmed promotional video that will spread across youtube, vimeo and facebook. We also need to print out surveys to track our audience data for grant pruposes and for better marketing strategies as our small organization gets bigger.

The total comes out to around $10,500. So why aren't we asking for the full amount? Some of these expenses will be covered by in-kind donations. 

We also have some very simple and unique prizes that we are offering. Among them, Copies of the script, photo books commorating the show as well as personal video thank yous from the cast and production team including actress Beth Broderick.

Other Ways You Can Help

Today, we live in a world where our voices, when used with passion and shared widely, can make a difference. We have the power to make this world a better place one small action at a time. By reaching out to others and sharing your passion for the importance of this story and encouraging them to make any contribution they can, we can raise the funds necessary to produce this important, albeit unfortunately relevant play. Thanks again for listening to our story and thanks in advance for your support.

story:
My name is Samantha Duff and I'm a graduate of Mount Royal College's theatre diploma program and I have a bachleor of fine arts in acting from the University of Alberta. I recently started my own theatre company, Goodger-Pink Productions, and our debut production is an outdoor, all ages, "re-mix" version of Rumpelstiltskin, to be performed at Kinsmen Park in Okotoks.

This debut project is especially important to me because I grew up in Okotoks, a small town just south of Calgary and when I was 7 years old an improv troupe came to town and performed outdoors in the park by the library.  It was one of my first experiences with live theatre and I remember feeling so inspired by what these "cool kids" were doing. My mum took me to almost every show they put on that summer. They performed on a "Pay What You Can" donation basis, which made it financially accessible to everyone in town. It was an opportunity to share quality time with my family, out of the house, and to be exposed to something really unique in an otherwise small prairie town. Outdoor donation-based all-ages theatre builds community, creates opportunities for families to connect and is a fun way to spend a summer evening.

And that's where my project comes in...

A lot has happened since that improv troupe came to town. I've grown as an actor and a person. I moved away to Edmonton for school, started my professional acting career and traveled a great deal of the world. Okotoks has grown considerably too. New businesses have opened, the population continues to rise and it's become a bustling, vibrant place. Despite its growth one thing that hasn't changed is how much the people of Okotoks and the surrounding areas value community, family, and a welcoming small town feeling.  Since moving back I'm excited to re-connect with my hometown by offering the community something I'm passionate about, theatre.

My cast, including myself and fellow U of A acting graduates Holleay Rohm and Matthew McKinney, have a great deal of experience performing for children on a professional level, including Shakespeare school touring shows and residences in schools all over the province. To the best of my knowledge, nothing quite like this has been offered to the children and families of the Okotoks area since that improv troupe came to town more than 20 years ago. With your help I'm hoping to change that!

I am embarking on this project with no government grant money and with the intention to make theatre financially accessible for everyone by selling tickets on a "Pay What You Can" donation basis. Because of this I am relying soley on the generosity of others.

I have settled on a fundrasing goal of $700, the breakdown as follows...

$180- script and payment of royalties for script

$260- price of rental for Kinsmen Park for the four performances

$260- advertising costs: posters, handbills, space in local newspapers, ect.

We plan to be creative and thrifty with our set and costumes to keep the costs down, but if we are able to raise more money, it would go towards production costs like that.

Anyone who donates (any amount of money at all, we can use all the help we can get) will have their name posted on our show board at every performance, with a huge THANK YOU next to it. If donating money is not a possibility, we will thank you just as much if you support us by either coming out to see our show, or spreading the word to friends and families you think might be interested!

Show details...

June 28 at 7pm

June 29 at 2pm and 7pm

June 30 at 2pm

All shows at Kinsmen Park in Okotoks, so bring a blanket to sit on and some bug spray! Kinsmen Park is located at 110 Oak Ave with parking available at the south end and the west (McRae Street) end of the park.

The ability theatre has to excite, teach, and inspire young people should not be underestimated.

Thank you in advance for supporting this project in any way you can!!
