story:
Our History

Nicole Schalmo and Christina Sheehan met while performing together at The American Theatre of Actors.  In June of 2011 they had a crazy idea to mount their own minimalist production of A Midsummer Night's Dream.  Thus began an ambitious new company as well as a beautiful new friendship!

 

 

In our first year we have put up four successful productions, following A Midsummer Night's Dream with Romeo and Juliet, The Comedy of Errors, and Othello. Along the way we have built a company of talented, committed actors who repeatedly come back to us; while we continue to grow and always bring in new blood.

 

 

What We Do

What Dreams May Co. is dedicated to making the classics accessible to all.  Simple, minimalistic productions leave the focus on the language and characters, challenging the actors in the company to reach new levels and expand their knowledge of the classics. Passionate performances delve to the heart of the text, bringing the story to life in a way that connects with and immerses modern audiences.

 

 

We strive, above all, to bring the text to life; capturing the energy and excitement the plays had when they were first performed.  These plays were the popular entertainment of the day!  When a production is really true to Shakespeare's text, you begin to see that the plays are really full of outragous humor and bawdy sexuality. Ultimately, we make Shakespeare accessible, because we remember that it was always intended for the masses.  This author knew how to shock and excite his audience, and four hundred years later there are still surprises to be found.  There is never an excuse for making these plays stuffy or boring.

 

Our productions always have a modern sensibility, leaving the text untouched but presenting the action as if it was happening in today's world. We bring an immediacy and relatability to texts that could otherwise appear old and stale. We often employ gender swapping in our productions, giving actresses the chance to explore traditionally male roles and bringing a whole new take to both the individual role and the production as a whole.

 

 

What We're Up To Now

As we enter our second year of bringing Shakespeare to the people, we are tackling the big one, our namesake, Hamlet!

 

 

We want this production to be bigger and better than ever!  We are looking to give this production a longer run, giving our audiences more chances to come and see it!  We are also planning to grow our marketing program, so everyone knows where to find us!  Help us get people into those seats!

 

 

What You Get

You earn our undying gratitude and the satisfaction of keeping the arts alive and healthy in the heart of Harlem!  But, of course, we want to give back, too.  A donation of any size will earn you a personal thank you from Christina and Nicole on What Dreams May Co's facebook page and anyone who donates $25 or more will be on our list of donors, so we can show our deep appreciation.  In addition to the accolades, anyone who donates $30 will receive a souvenir program signed by the entire cast of Hamlet. For $50 you get two tickets to our production of Hamlet.  For a $70 donation, you will receive two tickets to opening night of Hamlet and a drink at the after party on the producers' tab! For $80 you receive two seat to Hamlet this spring AND Macbeth this summer!  For $100 receive two opening night tickets to both Hamlet and Macbeth and come to both after parties, where the producers will buy you a drink! Prepare to be right in the center of the action!

Other Ways You Can Help

Want to help out, but can't contribute?  We can always use volunteers!  You can help out with anything from working the box office to organizing props.  The most important thing anyone can do to help, is get the word out.  Tell your friends, give out postcards, come see our shows yourself!  This is why we can't do this without you, yes, YOU!!!

story:
Short Summary

The Somerville High School Drama Club are a group of 18-30 teenagers who, against all odds this year, managed to participate in the state play festival in March. With zero resources from their school, we're turning to our community to ask that you help us cover the expenses we incurred to attend Fest, and also help us make it on a field trip to see a professional play this spring!

  • We only need to raise about $500.
  • This covers the cost of props and sets, the busses we've rented and need to rent to get to shows, and the tickets for our field trip. Please help in any way you can!

The Impact

Many kids who struggle academically, socially, or emotionally are drawn to theater as a place where they can be themselves and learn how to work collaboratively on a long term project. The "drama program" at SHS is really the personal efforts of English teacher Curtis Eames, and the little attention and resources we are allowed officially are on the chopping block.

If we can show the school that our community wants us to exist, it will set a precident for the rest of the school year and into the future. The club particpants were thrilled to make it to the state festival this year, and hope to come back in 2014 as even stronger competitors.

Other Ways You Can Help

Share our video and this fundraiser with everyone you know who cares about Somerville, education, theater, kids, and knows these things can be a real life saver for young people!

story:
Come see what lies at the top of the hill, where the Lunar Labyrinth once stood. Will you be healed by the bright of the moon? Or blighted by the monsters hiding in her shadow?

Liars & Believers is collaborating with a dozen of our favorite performers to bring a new, unpublished short story by author Neil Gaiman to the stage on February 13, 2013 at Oberon in Harvard Square. Each collaborator is taking a part of the story and bringing it to life using music, dance, aerial performance, puppetry, poetry, storytelling, and more.

Neil’s short story is just shy of 3000 words, and we’re blowing it up into a feast for the senses. Director Steven Bogart is guiding the performers in unpacking meanings and themes – memory, identity, healing – and will put together all the pieces during our four day rehearsal period.

This talented group of artists includes Mali Sastri, Phillip Berman, Mary Bichner, Brett Cramp, Claire Davies, Jennifer Hicks, John J. King, Eileen Little, Corianna Moffatt, Masha Obolensky, April Ranger, and Karin Webb. You can read more about them at http://www.liarsandbelievers.com/Shows/Lunar-La...

Liars & Believers is an experimental theater company with a mission to expand the language of live performance. Through collaborations with exciting local artists, we strive to make Boston a center for theatrical innovation.

Join the enthusiastic audience that makes possible exciting new art in Boston. By supporting Lunar Labyrinth, you’re encouraging local artists to take risks and to challenge the status quo of what performance art can be.

Where does the money go?

We’re doing this with a minimal budget. The funds we raise are going towards

  • costumes and props ($200)
  • posters, postcards, and other artwork ($400)
  • technical staff ($500)
  • printing the program ($180)
  • other sundries ($500)

as well as Indiegogo’s fees (3% if we make our goal and 7% if we don’t) and credit card processing fees (3%)

As you can see, the cost of the show is more than the $1000 we set as our goal.

What about the performers??

All of our collaborators are being paid an equal share of the ticket sales, after expenses. The more expenses we cover from fundraising, the bigger the collaborators’ shares.

The performers have agreed to this model because they are excited about the project. By helping to cover production expenses, you are enabling them to be paid for their work. While few people become artists for the money, artists still need to eat. More importantly, you have the opportunity to make the statement that art has value.

Perks:

Social media shout-out: Liars & Believers will give you a shout out from our Facebook (www.facebook.com/liarsbelieve) and twitter (www.twitter.com/liarsbelieve) accounts to all of our fans and followers

**NEW** Demo digital download: Receive a digital download of the demo for a new song written by Mali Sastri (Jaggery) for Lunar Labyrinth.

Postcard: During downtime in rehearsals, one or more performer will write you a hand-written note on a Lunar Labyrinth postcard which we will send to you in the mail

Lunar Labyrinth dance floor ticket: Dance floor tickets are general admission standing-room tickets

Aerial Lesson with Eileen Little: Come and take a private lesson on the silks or the trapeze!  This hour long private lesson will be at ESH Aerial Arts in Porter Square.  All ages and abilities are welcome.  For more info go to www.eileenlittle.com. Lessons to be scheduled with Eileen after the campaign ends.

Custom Flask from John J. King: J-RexPlays Custom Flasks!  Each flask is 8 oz., stainless steel, and custom painted by the artist. http://www.j-rexplays.com/custom-flasks.html

Song-writing lesson from Mary Bichner: A one-hour songwriting lesson with composer and arranger Mary Bichner. Whether you've always wanted to pen a catchy pop song, a high-octane punk rock song, or a classical aria, Mary's your girl! :) Lessons to be scheduled with Mary after the campaign ends.

Lunar Labyrinth seated ticket: Seated tickets are assigned seats on the mezzanine at full-service tables

Icarus: Coming May 2013 is Liars & Believers' fourth full-run show, an original tale based on the myth of Icarus and set in a depression-era traveling circus. With music composed by Nathan Leigh (Song of Songs) and puppets designed by Faye Dupras

Signed poster: Neil Gaiman has graciously agreed to sign Lunar Labyrinth posters for contributors

Painting by Steven Bogart: An 18”x18” oil painting by director Steven Bogart, whose paintings have been exhibited as far away as Tokyo and more recently as a featured artist at the Decordova Museum in Lincoln, MA. Steve says: “Gamma is part of my continued organic associative encounters with cosmology, string theory and chaos.” See the painting here

Meet & Greet: Come schmooze with the cast (at our Top Secret T-accessible Rehearsal Facility between February 9-12) and we will bake you a cake - choose between chocolate, vanilla, strawberry, or carrot.

***Liars & Believers is a 501(c)(3) non-profit, so your donation is tax deductible***

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Sign up for our mailing list! Be the first to find out when tickets go on sale, get an exclusive discount code and updates from behind the scenes. You can sign up atwww.liarsandbelievers.com/mailinglist
  • Spread the word! Tell everyone you know. Post this to Facebook, twitter, even Google+!
  • Volunteer! We’re going to need some extra hands to pull this off. E-mail Rachel[at]liarsandbelievers.com for more information.
story_txt:
Come see what lies at the top of the hill, where the Lunar Labyrinth once stood. Will you be healed by the bright of the moon? Or blighted by the monsters hiding in her shadow?
Liars & Believers is collaborating with a dozen of our favorite performers to bring a new, unpublished short story by author Neil Gaiman to the stage on February 13, 2013 at Oberon in Harvard Square. Each collaborator is taking a part of the story and bringing it to life using music, dance, aerial performance, puppetry, poetry, storytelling, and more.
Neil’s short story is just shy of 3000 words, and we’re blowing it up into a feast for the senses. Director Steven Bogart is guiding the performers in unpacking meanings and themes – memory, identity, healing – and will put together all the pieces during our four day rehearsal period.
This talented group of artists includes Mali Sastri, Phillip Berman, Mary Bichner, Brett Cramp, Claire Davies, Jennifer Hicks, John J. story:
Who we are:

Boston Actors Theater has been producing since 2004 and is comprised of a group of Bostonian artists who come together to produce mostly new works by local playwrights. Our mission is to support the community; meaning producing local, hiring local designers, directors, and actors; as well as raising funds for a local charity during the run of our productions. We often take on challenging works for the audience and our artists. This production is one of those special works that needs the communities help to put up. Due to the technical demands and intense themes of this production BAT needs your help! With your donations we can reach this wonderful script’s potential!

What is Paper City Phoenix about?

Brenna’s soul mate is missing, but finding him is hard when she can’t stop mentally channeling Google searches. Gale tries to help her, but she’s got her own problems and her printer’s out of toner. Both women, an anti-tech cult, the FBI, and the Internet itself will be involved before it’s over, and the city will never be the same. PAPER CITY PHOENIX is an explosive comedy that looks at how we connect when we’re always connected, and what’s left when the universe hits the delete key.

“This is a big, crazy comedy,” says playwright McGough, “with big production demands and a comic-book aesthetic. But at its core is a character-driven story about the need for connection. I’m extremely lucky to work with such talented artists, bringing it all to life.”

What We Need & What You Get

We are hoping to raise $2000 to put towards our $3000 budget for this production. This will cover stipends for all the artists working on this project, as well as the costumes, sound, sets, and a complicated paint design elements. We will not only be creating a world of paper, but one inside of technology and a burnt out post-apocalyptic city, not to mention a very electrifying opening!

You can see some of the costume sketches in the gallery section! All the costume sketches are by our costumer Cara Chiaramonte, see more of her work at http://carachiaramonte.com

Every amount helps no matter how big or small to help us achieve our goal of creating a high quality production for everyone to experience!  In exchange we have some great things to offer you, from our gratitude, to tickets, to signed scripts, pieces written by Walt just for you, and coaching from Director Melanie! Everyone will be thanked on facebook no matter how large or small the donation. Even if it's $1! Check out everything and please give to this amazing project!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t help at this time please we understand. Still want to help? Spread the word to those who may be able to help out. Every little bit helps when approaching a work as big as this and every piece of help is truly appreciated!

story:
The Show

'Catch the Wall' is a new play that playwright Gabrielle Reisman and The NOLA Project have been passionately developing for three years.  This is a vibrant, fun, and passionate New Orleans story that doesn't deal in easy cliches, but tells the story of New Orleans today, in our post-recovery, back-to-life world.  The play will open at Dillard University's Cook Theatre on March 14 and run for two weeks.  Our hope is not only to tell our immediate community this amazing story, but to bring a well-deserved national spotlight on the first-rate theatre that has been growing in New Orleans since 2005.

This production will employ a team of twenty-two talented artists:

  • 9 New Orleans actors
  • 5 innovative designers (sound, video, scenic, lighting, costumes)
  • 2 stage managers (the hardest-working folks you might never see!)
  • 4 production specialists (the amazing folks that handle all the administrative needs)
  • 1 visionary director
  • 1 incredible playwright that made this whole thing possible

And that doesn't even include the dozens of people that have already lent their hands and souls as precious volunteers!

Needless to say, this is our largest production of a new play ever, and we need and want you, our supporters to have a monumental hand in seeing it come to life!

What We Need & What You Get

In additional to paying all of our working artists we need to pay for:

  • Theatre Rental.  Dillard's Cook Theater is a beautiful theater, but it ain't free!
  • Building Materials: lumber, nails, paint, caulk, scenic furniture...
  • Lights and gels (the things that make the lights cast pretty colors)
  • Projection technology.  We are using a new form of projection called 3-D mapping.  It's pretty awesome, and we can't wait to show it off!
  • Advertising like posters, postcards, ads, and emails so folks know about us
  • Sound equipment and music.  This is a Bounce play after all!
  • Costume materials.  We're building Mardi Gras indian suits y'all.
  • Insurance.  You know, in case a light falls on our head.

And for helping us meet these needs, please select from our great variety of donation perks!  Also remember that The NOLA Project is a 501c3 non-profit organization and your philanthropy is tax-deductible.

The Impact

Your contribution promotes not only the health of this production, but is a major impact to the cultural economy of New Orelans. New Orleans is a city defined by our culture, much of which can be contributed to our incredible artists.

Every year, The NOLA Project provides paying work for over 100 artists.  We believe that the artistic contributions of all our theatremakers is worthy of remuneration, and we continue to try and increase pay in order to promote professional working conditions for all the extremely hard-working and deserving artists.

Your donation helps make this effort a reality and helps keep amazing talent living and working in this incredible city.

 

Consider Yourself Invited!

We hope you can come see the fruits of our labors by attending 'Catch the Wall' this March!  For tickets and more information on the show, please visit The NOLA Project website!

Follow us on facebook, twitter, tumblr, and instagram @thenolaproject

And please, tell your friends about this show!  Theatre isn't theatre without an audience!

story:
Short Summary

My name is Angel Tucker and as an Expert Personality Profiler I have helped 10's of thousands of people realize the benefits of understanding different personality types. My best-selling book titled: Stop Squatting With Your Spurs On teaches people how to read personality types in less than 60 seconds. I am also the creator of the Award Winning children' book series titled: Four Pals. This project is based off the characters in these books. The purpose of this project is to perform a live show in the San Antonio, TX area for the children of our military families serving at three local military bases to include Randolph Air Force Base, Lackland Air Force Base. and Ft Sam Houston. We want to teach the children the importance of eating healthy and staying fit. These children, many of whom deal with challenges on a daily basis to include deployed parents, wounded parents, and sometimes parents who sadly never return from deployment rarely think about the importance of health and fitness. We want to show them how to make sure they take care of themselves physically. When children feel better physically, they are better equipped to deal with emotional things. We want to give them the tools they need to feel good about themselves, encourage others to feel good about themselves, and have a healthy mental outlook on life as well. By supporting this project, you are saying "thank you" to all the children who have sacrificed for our Country. This show will be free to all who attend. The seating capacity for the theatre is nearly 1000 and we want to perform for a packed theatre of well deserving children, many of whom their parents can't afford much in the way of extra entertainment. This project will have a positive impact on the lives and morale of thousands of people directly, and countless people indirectly who are giving every day to protect our freedoms.

What We Need and What You Get

All the funds raised for this project will be used towards the printing costs of flyers, posters and tickets as well as hiring actors, audio/visual staff, and providing props as well as tshirts for the volunteer staff on site and also for the kids chosen to participate in the show. The amount we are requesting is the minimum we need, but every bit - even the amount above the requested funds will be used towards the show. The more we raise, the more we can promote the show to get the word out and also provide tshirts for children attending.

Here is a breakdown of what you receive in exchange for your support. Support of ANY amount is greatly appreciated!

$10.00+  mp3 of Angel's Couples Communication seminar

$25.00+ Autographed copy of Angel's best-selling book: Stop Squatting With Your Spurs On!

$50.00+ Autographed copy for you AND an Active Duty Member who is deployed! We will not only send you an autographed copy, we'll send one to someone serving our country and put a note that the book was paid for by you!

$75.00 Augraphed set of Angel's Four Pals children's book series.

$200.00+ 20 minute coaching/consulting session with Angel Tucker OR all the items listed for lesser donation amounts.

$400.00+ Your business listed as a sponsor for the event on all flyers, posters and show website.

 

 

The Impact

I wish I could measure the impact that such a project has. The benefits are limitless. The military family benefits from being able to attend a free event that emphasizes habits that can increase their quality of life, the people in the lives of the military benefit from having someone with a positive outlook on life, and the people who donate benefit from knowing they have helped in immesurable ways to improve the lives of many.

Other Ways You Can Help

Share this on your social media. Tell companies you may be affiliated with so they can become a sponsor. Tell military families you know in the San Antonio area about it!

story:
World Bboy Classic Vancouver Qualifier

World Bboy Classic Championship celebrates their fifth edition in 2013. Since the start in 2009, the event has evolved to be one of the most prestigious 2vs2 battles worldwide, with a unique battle concept and high level competitors. World BBoy Classic requires a maximum effort from the dancer concerning creativity and innovative skills

After communicating with the organization of WORLD BBOY CLASSIC in The Netherlands, we, Boogaloo Academy & Streetrich, have been approved to organize one of the few Qualifiers in the world. For the North West this is a unique opportunity to promote and support the local breakdance scene. We are very proud that we will send two of the best dancers of the North West to Europe.

Trailer of Main event in Rotterdam, The Netherlands

World BBoy Classic 2012 Trailer:  http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dmcRZICxU4g

Goals

-          Supporting and improving a stronger and bigger Hip Hop community.

-          An event for all ages and people from different backgrounds.

-          To motivate youth to be creative and active in a way that is close to their normal daily life.

-          Supporting and building self-esteem of youngsters in the North West.

-          Creating a platform for youth to showcase creative expression through art.

-          Showcase of all the breakdancers in the North West to the rest of the breakdance world and giving them international exposure.

-          Embrace the true values of Hip Hop Culture : Peace, Love, Unity, Respect and Having fun.

Budget

2 flights to the Netherlands: $2500

3 Flights for International Judges ( Europe, East Canada, New York) : $2500

Accomodation guests: $ 1000

Local artist showcases: $ 700

Host: $200

2 Dj’s: $ 500

Rent room: $ 325

Insurance: $ 75

Sound equipment: $ 300

Grafitti supplies: $ 300

Merchandise: $ 200

Total : $ 8600

 

A Star Society/ Boogaloo Academy

A Star Society provides high level classes, events and workshops at Boogaloo Academy in Dance, Drama, Music and art. A multidisciplinary school for all ages and levels. After years of collaborative partnership focusing on quality education in the arts and developing leadership programs like Free Style Fridays, and High School High, Anita Perel- Panar and Jheric Hizon have joined forces to create Boogaloo Academy. Along with their unique talents, expertise and experience Anita and Jheric bring their strong educational philosophies, values and ethics to establish this state-of-the-art institution. Boogaloo Academy reaches out to dancers, musicians and artist to empower all to have a voice and shape the culture of dance and art in the lower mainland.

Streetrich

Streetrich hip hop organisation has its roots in Belgium. In January 2012 Mattias Boon started a Streetrich Vancouver chapter. Since then Streetrich organised different Hip hop events in the lower mainland. A few of these events was the breakdance competition for the youthweek in Vancouver, some events for the anti-discrimination program Citizen U and hosting Hip Hop workshops at Roundhouse Community Centre. Streetrich promotes and supports Hip Hop culture locally, nationally and internationally. Streetrich also organise the international breakdance competition ‘Unbreakable’ in Belgium. www.unbreakable.be

-

Sponsors/ Supporters
ART GOES EVERYWHERE
www.artgoeseverywhere.ca
https://www.facebook.com/artgoeseverywhere?fref=ts

EPHIN SDK
www.ephinstore.com
https://www.facebook.com/EphinSDK

story_txt:
World Bboy Classic Vancouver Qualifier
World Bboy Classic Championship celebrates their fifth edition in 2013. Since the start in 2009, the event has evolved to be one of the most prestigious 2vs2 battles worldwide, with a unique battle concept and high level competitors. World BBoy Classic requires a maximum effort from the dancer concerning creativity and innovative skills
After communicating with the organization of WORLD BBOY CLASSIC in The Netherlands, we, Boogaloo Academy & Streetrich, have been approved to organize one of the few Qualifiers in the world. For the North West this is a unique opportunity to promote and support the local breakdance scene. We are very proud that we will send two of the best dancers of the North West to Europe.
Trailer of Main event in Rotterdam, The Netherlands
World BBoy Classic 2012 Trailer:  http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dmcRZICxU4g
Goals
-          Supporting and improving a stronger and bigger Hip Hop community.
-          An event for all ages and people from different backgrounds.
-          To motivate youth to be creative and active in a way that is close to their normal daily life.
-          Supporting and building self-esteem of youngsters in the North West.
-          Creating a platform for youth to showcase creative expression through art.
-          Showcase of all the breakdancers in the North West to the rest of the breakdance world and giving them international exposure.
-          Embrace the true values of Hip Hop Culture : Peace, Love, Unity, Respect and Having fun.
Budget
2 flights to the Netherlands: $2500
3 Flights for International Judges ( Europe, East Canada, New York) : $2500
Accomodation guests: $ 1000
Local artist showcases: $ 700
Host: $200
2 Dj’s: $ 500
Rent room: $ 325
Insurance: $ 75
Sound equipment: $ 300
Grafitti supplies: $ 300
Merchandise: $ 200
Total : $ 8600
 
A Star Society/ Boogaloo Academy
A Star Society provides high level classes, events and workshops at Boogaloo Academy in Dance, Drama, Music and art. A multidisciplinary school for all ages and levels. After years of collaborative partnership focusing on quality education in the arts and developing leadership programs like Free Style Fridays, and High School High, Anita Perel- Panar and Jheric Hizon have joined forces to create Boogaloo Academy. Along with their unique talents, expertise and experience Anita and Jheric bring their strong educational philosophies, values and ethics to establish this state-of-the-art institution. Boogaloo Academy reaches out to dancers, musicians and artist to empower all to have a voice and shape the culture of dance and art in the lower mainland.
Streetrich
Streetrich hip hop organisation has its roots in Belgium. In January 2012 Mattias Boon started a Streetrich Vancouver chapter. Since then Streetrich organised different Hip hop events in the lower mainland. A few of these events was the breakdance competition for the youthweek in Vancouver, some events for the anti-discrimination program Citizen U and hosting Hip Hop workshops at Roundhouse Community Centre. Streetrich promotes and supports Hip Hop culture locally, nationally and internationally. Streetrich also organise the international breakdance competition ‘Unbreakable’ in Belgium. www.unbreakable.be
-

story:
The Indigo Theatre Project strives to produce high-profile play readings that benefit a specific charity aligned with each play. 

In the fall of 2012, Nick and Rachel became enamored with the idea of putting together readings of inspiring plays they'd never seen live. Along with Allison, we decided to present readings of these plays ourselves, but resolved do more than simply re-produce them: by combining our love for artistry with a desire to give back, we developed something both potent and powerful.

 

 The Beginning: Intimate Apparel

The premiere reading of the Indigo Theatre Project took place in January 2013 with Intimate Apparel by Pulitzer Prize winning playwright, Lynn Nottage at the Pershing Square Signature Center in New York City. Proceeds from the reading went to Donor Direct Action (DDA), a non-profit Lynn works with that strengthens women’s rights organizations around the world. With a star-studded dream cast (Quincy Tyler Bernstine, Joshua Henry, Ari Graynor, Tonya Pinkins, Condola Rashad, and Morgan Spector, with Dominique Morisseau reading stage directions), an up-and-coming director (Jade King Carroll), and accessible ticket prices, we sold out the 199-seat theater and made over $5,000 (read more about Intimate Apparel here). Being a relatively small organization, DDA's staff was overwhelmed by the support and publicity they received. Lynn, who was present to introduce the reading, expressed her gratitude for the reading by saying, “Your generosity of spirit is a gift. Please continue to do the work that you're doing, it is necessary and greatly appreciated.” Through the development of the Indigo Theatre Project, that is exactly what we intend to do. (Photo Copyright 2013 by Monica Simoes)

Now: Uncommon Women and Others 

Our spring reading of Wendy Wasserstein's Uncommon Women and Others, directed by Leigh Silverman and featuring an all-star cast will take place on May 13th at 8 PM at the Theresa Lang Theatre at Marymount Manhattan College. The reading will benefit TDF Open Doors, a mentoring program co-founding by Ms. Wasserstein and Roy Harris that “matches dozens of distinguished theatre and dance professionals with small groups of high school students with no prior exposure to theatre.”

Told in the signature voice of Wendy Wasserstein at the very inception of her illustrious career, Uncommon Women and Others is a poignant story about the intimate connection between who you were, who you are, and who you want to be. For more information, read our press release at Playbill.com. 

 

In order to give 100% of our proceeds to our next charity, we are asking for your help!

In the case of our first reading, we accumulated a variety expenses that had to be paid out of our profits. For Uncommon Women, we are hoping to give 100% of our proceeds to TDF Opens by raising our own $2,000. This will cover:

  • The Theatre Rental
  • Rehearsal Space
  • Program Printing
  • Event Insurance
  • Play Licensing

...and all the odds and ends in between!


With your tax-deductible donation to the Indigo Theatre Project, you will be offering us the time and space to present this high-caliber reading of Uncommon Women and Others to an audience and allow us to fully support this inspiring mentoring program!

For those who believe in the work we do and/or are unable to attend our readings, this is a tremendous way to help us make the Indigo Theatre Project to thrive!  

Thank you for your time and support--hope to see you at the reading!

 

All our love,

Nick & Rachel, Co-Artistic Directors

Allison, Line Producer

story:
The Chess Lesson: Fundamentals

Slightly Altered States is a not-for-profit theater company made up of actors, writers, and improvisers. We are devoted to darkly funny, slightly-absurd material that deals truthfully with the extraordinary in everyday circumstances.

In THE CHESS LESSON, three very different parents have come to take a chess class with their children's teacher. Despite everyone's best intentions, the adults keep turning into children, the class keeps slipping out of control, and the teacher is one romance novel away from a nervous breakdown. Four strangers all at a crossroads in their life, alone together in a classroom for children, have no choice but to examine who they are, and remember who they were

Written by Sari Caine, a former Chess Champion and "The Best Beginner Teacher in NYC"-Mommypoppins.com, and Directed by Elizabeth Miller, THE CHESS LESSON stars David Crommett, Sari Caine, Meg Fee, and David Rigo, with a production team that includes Daryl Embry (set), Derek Wright (lighting), Andre Fratto (sound), Zach Tait (stage manager) and Sonya Sobieski (dramaturg). It was developed through residencies at Space on Ryder Farm, Jimmy's No. 43, IRT, and with a donation from the Sidney and Beatrice Albert Foundation.

Doing low-budget theater in NYC is expensive. We pay everyone involved with our projects, and want to offer YOU a high quality show.  Being a dedicated artist of any kind, anywhere, is tough.  We are trying to do all we can to make living art at as close as we can get to a living wage (which sadly is not that close).

Chess Praxis: What We Need and How We Will Use It

A Rough Breakdown of SOME of our expenses looks something like this:                Theater Space: $3,600                                                                      

Rehearsal Space: $1000

Cast and Crew and Press: $4,000

As you can see, our expenses will already be above the $7,000 pledge we're asking for, and we haven't even gotten to props, programs, postcards, and booze for the bar ... Not to mention the truck rental fee for transporting our set... But we can make it work with your help!

We are offering Free Drinks, Free Tickets, Chess Lessons, Massages, Discounts at Chess Forum, Volunteering Time... Pretty cool stuff if we do say so ourselves!

If we do not reach our entire goal, all proceeds will go to everyone and everything involved, and we will make it work somehow... After all, this is theater... you know the rest!

Other Ways You Can Help

And if you can't contribute, please do not worry!  Come out to see the show, spread the word to anyone you can about our show and our campaign.  Every little bit helps.

This has truly been a project of love for everyone involved, and SAS is so grateful to be working in an atmosphere of such enthusiasm and support.

story:
Our Story

Théâtre Sans Fond

Théâtre Sans Fond produces theatrical performances inspired by rock music history. The first performance of the series, “Zeppelin c’t’un cover band”, was first produced in French in November 2006 at Mainline Theatre (Montreal), and remounted for the 2007 Montreal Fringe Festival. The English version, « Zeppelin Was a Cover Band », became one of the hit shows of the Montreal Fringe in 2008, and was also performed at Centaur Theatre (Montreal) in January 2009 as part of the Wildside Festival. The company’s most recent production, "Autobiomusicograph(y)ie", was nominated for the Cirque du Soleil « Best Original Production » award at the 2010 edition of the Montreal Fringe. In 2011, "Autobiomusicograph(y)ie" has been adapted into a series of shows that are performed regularly in various Montreal resto-bars.

 

All I Want is U2

After telling the story of the blues through the music of rock group Led Zeppelin, the creator of "Zeppelin Was a Cover Band" presents a new theatrical chapter of rock history, taking over where Jimmy Page’s mythical rock band began to disintegrate. In 1976, in the midst of the punk revolution, four high school boys from Dublin started a band. In 1987, a thirteen year old teenager discovered the music of U2. Mixing lecture, storytelling and theatrical performance, featuring a live DJ, and directed by Stéphanie Pelletier ("Ombilic", "Terre confite"), "All I Want is U2" is the story of Irish rock band U2 as seen and heard through the eyes and ears of writer/performer Stéfan Cédilot.        

 

The embryo of « All I Want is U2 » was first produced at Université du Québec à Montréal (UQÀM) in May 2009, as part of Stéfan Cédilot’s thesis in theatre. Firmly planted in a university context, the performance that came out of it was a testimony to the intellectual process of a masters’ thesis, and exposed the results of the author’s analysis of the conceptual evolution of U2’s concerts.

 

From this chronological analysis of a rock group’s live use of iconic imagery, which left little room for the writer’s own biography, « All I Want is U2 » has become an intimate performance in which the visual explosion of the U2 concert contrasts with personal anecdotes from Stéfan Cédilot’s own biography. A new performance for a new stage and a new audience. 

 

"All I Want is U2" is scheduled to perform at Mainline Theatre, from September 28th to October 1st 2011.  

 

The Impact

We at Théâtre Sans Fond are convinced that we have created an original and innovative form of theatre, a result of 5 years of hard work during which many shows have been developped, each one presenting a new aesthetic to fit with the subject of the performance. "Zeppelin Was a Cover Band" having become a cult hit in Montreal, we are aiming to better that show with this new performance. We have evolved as artists and are getting better at what we do, so we are hoping to reach a larger audience than before. But, as is the case with the arts in general, funding is often lacking, and consequently, so many quality shows have been stuck in the underground, with limited visibility, because the artists are unable to rent a well known, well attended venue, or can't afford to pay for adequate promotional material that would give them extra visibility.

 

We are confident in our work and in our capacity to deliver the goods, but we are also aware that we need better publicity to get the word out, to get people in the seats, to get the media interested, and, ultimately, get the positive response we've worked so hard for, in order to eventually reach a larger market by performing in larger venues or by touring.

 

Mainline Theatre has proven over the years to be one such launchpad, as many artists who have performed there have gotten enough audience and media attention to move on to larger Montreal venues, eventually making a name for themselves in other cities, provinces, and countries.


What We Need & What You Get

Mainline Theatre has offered to co-produce the show, cutting the $2000 rental fee for five performances in half. We still need to pay $1000 in order to perform at Mainline, and this is where your financial contribution comes in!

 

We are already working hard to get money from various corporate and cultural sponsors, which has so far allowed us to rent a space where we have been rehearsing full-time since June. As we now enter the second phase of production, the money we have can either be used to pay for the Mainline rental, or pay for better publicity and a higher quality set design, but we cannot afford both!

 

Our objective is to raise as much money as we can on Indiegogo so as to divert as little as possible of our current budget to the venue rental fee. The more money you give, the more we can spend on the show's design and promotional material.

 

One of the coolest scenes of "All I Want is U2" is when Stéfan Cédilot describes U2's 1997 Pop Mart Tour, using what has come to be called the "U2 POP MART '97 ACTION FIGURE SET", which consists of a scale model of the Pop Mart tour's stage (6' wide x 3 1/2' high with the arch) and hand-made U2 action figures, created by our awesome designers, Jean-François Morel and Anne-Marie Taillefer.

 

Depending on your level of contribution to this production, we will send you a signed poster, tickets to the show at Mainline Theatre from September 28th to October 1st 2011, one of our hand-made U2 action figures, or a package including all 4 action figures with their instruments: the Bono action figure comes with a mic stand, The Edge and Adam come with a miniature guitar or bass, and Larry comes with a mini drum kit. (The action figures are actually modified '"80's G.I. Joe" type action figures and are very cool!)

 

To anyone crazy enough to give us the full $1000 we need to perform at Mainline, we are crazy enough to send you THE WHOLE "POP MART '97 ACTION FIGURE SET", with the stage, the action figures, and a mirror ball lemon!!! (The mirror ball lemon is made out of a Nerf football! Very very cool!!)

 

What can you do with a 6' x 3 1/2' U2 stage? When it is not being used in an "All I Want is U2" performance, Stéfan has already turned his into a bookshelf!!

 


Other Ways You Can Help

 

Please share this page with friends and anybody you know who might be interested in encouraging and financing innovative, cutting edge theatre! Also, if you know any hardcore U2 fans, tell them about the hand-made "Pop Mart '97 Action Figure Set". You can't get those on ebay!

story:
about the project.

On January 20 & 21, 2012, Artists Repertory Theatre in Portland, OR will produce a staged reading of a world premiere play entitled Dear Galileo, written by Portland playwright Claire Willett (the 2011 Oregon Literary Fellow for Drama and the summer 2011 Writer-in-Residence at the I-Park Artists Colony in Connecticut), as part of the 4th annual Fertile Ground Festival of New Work.  The theatre is committed, the director is on board, the cast is set and the script is close to finished.  We just need your help with funding the expenses of putting this project onstage – artist salaries, materials, and the administrative costs Artists Rep is taking on out of their own budget to make it happen.  Very few theatres these days have unlimited funds for new project development.  Like everyone in this economy, arts organizations are feeling the pinch, and it's incumbent upon artists to fundraise for themselves in order to see their projects through. 

 

We want to do our art.

 

We want to bring this play to life.

 

We want you to come see it. 

 

Will you help us out? 

about the play.

Three women in three different times wrestle with their identity, the conflict between science and religion, and what it means to be their fathers’ daughters.  In Renaissance Italy, Celeste Galilei lives under house arrest with her elderly father Galileo, the disgraced astronomer who wants to defy the Pope yet again by publishing one last book.  In a small town in Texas, creationist author and TV pundit Robert Snow is at a loss when his ten-year-old daughter Haley’s newfound passion for science begins to pull her away from the Biblical teachings of her upbringing.  And in Swift Trail Junction, Arizona, home of the Vatican Observatory’s U.S. outpost, New York sculptor Cassie Willows arrives to find that her estranged father, world-renowned astrophysicist Jasper Willows, has gone missing.  As the three stories move towards their point of convergence, the destinies of each become inextricably bound with the others, linked through time by love, family, grief, faith, the search for identity, and the wonder of the stars.

 

Click here to read an excerpt.

 

Click here to read more about Claire. 

 

why it matters.

Staged readings are gold for playwrights.  They’re a chance to get your work in front of an audience when it’s just at that stage when it’s mostly set but still a little soft and flexible, that stage where you’re ready for smart people to watch it and listen and tell you what you think. 

 

It’s even better when you have a really smart director.

 

It’s even better when you have a cast of really smart actors.

 

It’s even better when you have the opportunity to produce a staged reading at a theatre you’ve been in love with since you were a high school drama geek, a theatre where you worked after college and saw dozens of plays and have a giggly fan-girl crush on the artistic staff.  I would have to sit down with you over coffee and scones and talk for an hour with huge, expansive hand gestures and bucketloads of superlatives to fully convey to you what it means to me as a writer that after three years of self-producing – of setting up hundreds of folding chairs in coffeeshops and warehouses and tearing my own tickets at the door – one of the largest theatres in the state wants to produce this show. 

 

I’m incredibly excited. 

 

We’re all excited. 

 

We want to do this right. 

 

We want you to be a part of it. 

 

We hope you’ll consider making a donation.  If you can’t, we hope you’ll join us for the show if you live in or near Portland.  Come watch a play about parents and love and the Vatican and physics, and then stick around and tell us what you think.  

 

about the festival.

Do you live in Portland?  Do you have friends, family, coworkers, former lovers, pen pals or old college roommates who live in Portland?  Do they like theatre?  Do they especially like inexpensive, grassroots, locavore theatre?  The Fertile Ground New Play Festival is an amazing organization and you should drag everyone you know to every performance you can.  Last year there were over 70 productions in the festival, from fully-staged productions to scrappy low-budget readings in warehouses (like mine).  I strongly encourage you and your aforementioned loved ones to buy a festival pass (a ridiculously good deal at $50) and come to Portland for a week (or even just a long weekend) of coffee, microbrews, world-class food and a dizzying menu of performing arts. There's nothing like watching art in progress.
story_txt:
about the
project.
On January 20
& 21, 2012, Artists Repertory Theatre in Portland, OR will produce a staged
reading of a world premiere play entitled Dear
Galileo, written by Portland playwright Claire Willett (the 2011 Oregon
Literary Fellow for Drama and the summer 2011 Writer-in-Residence at the I-Park
Artists Colony in Connecticut), as part of the 4th annual Fertile
Ground Festival of New Work.  The theatre
is committed, the director is on board, the cast is set and the script is close
to finished.  We just need your help with
funding the expenses of putting this project onstage – artist salaries,
materials, and the administrative costs Artists Rep is taking on out of their own
budget to make it happen.  Very few theatres
these days have unlimited funds for new project development.  Like
everyone in this economy, arts organizations are feeling the pinch, and it's
incumbent upon artists to fundraise for themselves in order to see their
projects through.  
 
We want to do our
art.
 
We want to bring
this play to life.
 
We want you to
come see it.  
 
Will you help us
out?  
about the
play.
Three women in
three different times wrestle with their identity, the conflict between science
and religion, and what it means to be their fathers’ daughters.  In Renaissance Italy, Celeste Galilei lives
under house arrest with her elderly father Galileo, the disgraced astronomer
who wants to defy the Pope yet again by publishing one last book.  In a small town in Texas, creationist author
and TV pundit Robert Snow is at a loss when his ten-year-old daughter Haley’s
newfound passion for science begins to pull her away from the Biblical
teachings of her upbringing.  And in
Swift Trail Junction, Arizona, home of the Vatican Observatory’s U.S. outpost,
New York sculptor Cassie Willows arrives to find that her estranged father,
world-renowned astrophysicist Jasper Willows, has gone missing.  As the three stories move towards their point
of convergence, the destinies of each become inextricably bound with the
others, linked through time by love, family, grief, faith, the search for
identity, and the wonder of the stars.
 
Click here to read an
excerpt.
 
Click here to read more about Claire.

matters.

it.

story:
Our Story

Flower to Flower was immaculately conceived in Stan Denman's playwriting class at Baylor University in 2006 as a young woman's rant against the status quo. Several years and an MFA later, it was reopened with the Brimmer Street Theater Company in Los Angeles, and the idea grew and grew-- into a piece investigating the negotiations we make with God, each other, and ourselves about love and sex. We know love is kind, we know it's not boastful, but, Corinthians aside, there's still a whole lot to figure out. 


We have an incredible ensemble from the esteemed Brimmer Street Theater Company,  John Ennis directs, Christina Cigala's long mulled-over words, and our brilliant company of actors; including Marie Lively, Joseph Roberts, Jessica Makinson, Ben Fuller, Patrick Baker, Emilia Richeson, Amy Harmon, and Tyler Jenich, 

Maarten Cornelis lights it all up beautifully, Greta Svalberg takes us to Plano with her design, Christian Svenson dresses them up in our love with his costuming, Michael Bulger and Marie Lively produce, and Mitzi Delgado is our everlasting light as our stage manager.

Impact

Plays are expensive. They cost. You need three things in the theater-- the play, the actors, and the audience, and each must give something. They cost emotionally, they cost time, and they cost money. The money raised in this campaign is needed to cover the last leg of production costs.

What happens if the money isn’t raised in time?

We will still receive most of the money donated up to that point, just not all of it.  So we want to not only reach our goal, but surpass it! You can help by forwarding this to your friends using the helpful social networking bar below.

Who does the money go to?

Every penny (minus the fees for IndieGoGo’s awesome support) will go directly to the production budget - i.e. Your money goes directly to the play Period. You're not buying us coffee, you're paying for real production costs.

Other Ways You Can Help/Info

Come see the play! Give us a shout out!!! Check out our tumblr!! Or just post the link!!!!!! Don't want a perk? Fine!! Be that way! Want a perk that's not on here?!?!? Maybe you want to I-Chat with Joseph Roberts or take Amy Harmon to work on casual Friday? Ask and you shall probably receive!!

at El Centro Theatre – Chaplin Stage
804 N El Centro Ave., LA 90037

May 5 – June 4, 2011
Thursday – Friday – Saturday at 8pm
CLICK HERE TO BUY TICKETS

story:
Jess Barbagallo's new play Saturn Nights is coming to the St. Mark's Church-in-the-Bowery January 27-February 5, 2011 as part of Incubator Arts Project and needs your help getting there!

Directed by Meghan Finn


FEATURING:

Lucy Alibar, Emily Davis, Joseph Gregori, Nic Grelli, Laryssa Husiak, LaToya Lewis, Rachel Murdy, Kristen Sieh, Anna Foss Wilson & Greg Zucculo


Produced by Wayne Petro & the longest lunch

Set Design by Mary Chan

Sound Design by Chris Giarmo

Video Design by Jared Mezzocchi

Lighting Design by Paul Toben

Costume Design by Michael De Angelis


That slut Linda's just come home and Dad is still meditating near a mysterious hole in the backyard. But when daughter Dallas climbs underground to get a better look, her dying religious community is rocked to its core.

A lesbian-American origin story, a meditation on longing, fractured religiosity and unsettled sex in the Obama era, a shudder along the fringes of the modern media machine. A self-branded icon consumed in the excess of her paraphernalia/propaganda. Cults of spirituality and personality, tribalism, cement trucks and sink holes. Vast, ambitious, vulgar and poetic, Saturn Nights is an oddly-rhythmed beast of a play.


Help us bring this beast to life!

Your donations will support:

-Rehearsal space

-Set, prop and costume creation

-Sound, light and video projection instruments

-Marketing and publicity materials

-Compensation for the theater makers


Make a donation today and snag one or many of our VIP Perks!


TELL YOUR FRIENDS!

We are incredibly appreciative of any kind of support you can give us, and continuing to spread the word is a huge help to this project. So, blog/tweet about us, post this on facebook, tell your neighbors, call your mom, and we'll see you at the theater!

story:
Short Summary

Shorts! A Los Angeles Playwrights' Festival is the 1st annual play festival for the Red Brick Road. We have gathered five different playwrights, directors, and, musicians, a collection of actors to perform these Shorts! for the local Los Angeles community. We need your help to making theater accesible to people of all ages. Our event will take place the third weekend in June. June 15th- 17th). Our plays range from comedy to drama, to absurdism with always a great time! We will have live music and bands before the festival!

Who we Are:

The Red Brick Road Theatre Company is a non-profit theatre company based in North Hollywood, California. The company was formed in November 2007 by a group of five strong willed and dedicated actors. The company has grown to a group of 14 talented, hard working actors, producers, writers and directors. Red Brick Road’s mission is to produce and explore artistically challenging and widely inspirational works, encourage diversity and develop existing and new original pieces.  The Red Brick Road ensemble seeks to bring attention to shows that feature strong and relevant themes within today’s society, as well as new works that focus on the use of the ensemble to deliver a message. The Red Brick Road Theatre Company recently completed their second full season of productions which included The Flu Season by Will Eno, All in the Timing by David Ives, and In the Blood by Suzan-Lori Parks. We just finished producing Lobby Hero at the Avery Schreiber Theater in North Hollywood.

What We Need & What You Get

We need as much support as possible to make this happen! We are not only creating something different and accessible but growing and challenging our mission as a theatre company. If you donate, your prizes will range from special thank-you's, to a haiku, snacks, to season tickets to our shows!

The Impact

Los Angeles is a busy city of entertainment. Sometimes relaxing and seeing a theatre show is all you need to realize life is good. Come enjoy the beginnings of summer, while supporting local artists and supporting theatre without charge.

Other Ways You Can Help if you can't donate today!

  1. Add Red Brick Road on Facebook and get up to date information!
  2. Tell your friends to come see our festival supporting artists from all over LA!
  3. Come see the show yourself!

story:
Our Story

 We are 2 dancers/performance-artists from Denmark, who have been working together for several years. Through this project, we want to address both the question of originality within art (what is original, is originality needed to create artistic quality and is anything truly original) as well as the need for spreading the open-source mentality into the arts; in our case, the performing arts.

 Through all of 2012, we keep an online video-notebook, where we upload 1 idea per person and day. These ideas are rough sketches for characters, choreographies, situations and other performance-related things. In addition to the vide-notebook, we also upload at least one short text per day, with a minimum length of one sentence.

 All of the material we upload is open-source, which means that anyone can use it, copy it, re-make or re-work it and be inspired by it for their own work. We demand nothing in return, other than that we be mentioned as inspiration and are told if you use the material.

 We also welcome comments, either written or in the form of video-comments. All comments will also become a part of the project, and will be free for us and others to use.

 In the beginning of 2013, we will collect all of the material and create a performance using it. This performance will open in Copenhagen, Denmark, but we also hope to take it to other countries if it is a success here. The process of creating the performance will also be documented and will be uploaded as an open-source video for others to use or be inspired by.

 

The Impact

 We hope that this will open more artist to the idea of sharing their work and methods with others so that the performing arts can progress more and keep developing. We want our performance to be everybody's performance, with the chance of all the material we use, to have already been used by others.

 We will finish the project no matter the amount of money we manage to raise. But of course, the finished performance will only be able to go as far as the funds allow.

 

What We Need & What You Get

 We are asking for USD 10.000,-. In addition to this, we are funding through a Danish web-site, and are applying for funding through the Danish Arts Council as well as some private donors.

 The entire project has a budget of USD 38.000,- which are to cover the following expenses during the production period in the beginning of 2013:

 

Renting a rehearsal space

Wages for 2 performers (during rehearsals)

Wages for a stage technician

Renting a stage

Paying for costumes

Paying for set-design

Paying for the building of sets, including materials

Transport of materials to/from workshops and stage

PR, including web-design, adds in newspapers and online, posters and flyers

 

 We will create the best possible performance, using the funds we raise, and anyone supporting us, who is in Copenhagen when we open will receive free opening-night tickets.

 In the event that the performance is a success and we go abroad with it, any funders, regardless of the amount of money they have contributed with, will receive free tickets if we are in their home-country or a country where they happen to be at the time.

 Anyone who contributes, will get his/her name on the poster, even if this means that the poster has to be enormous:-). And if you don't want us to mention you, just say so and we won't.

 We will, as stated above, create a performance, no matter how much money we raise. But, the finished performance will be easier to create, and have more production time, the closer we get to our total budget.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 You can help us, by having a look at our YouTube channel and commenting the videos that have been uploaded, to help create the actual performance. Also, please don't hesitate to link to our home-page, YouTube channel or our funding page here on Indiegogo. Thank you!

story:
Building on our work in the US and India, we are planning this year to push further into North America, South America, Europe, and other areas in South Asia.  I am hoping to raise a minimum of $3000 through this first campaign - $3000 in 3 weeks - just in time to take it off your 2012 taxes!

Help bring our boundary-breaking performances to an ever-widening audience. 

If you’re broke right now, fear not!  This is only Phase One!  Our work is ongoing, and several layers of projects are in production already. AND THERE ARE OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP.

The past year has been incredibly productive for ANIKAI Dance Theater, due in great part to the inspiration of completing our 2011 India Tour, and to a wealth of recognition and support. 

It’s time to take our work to the next level.  

In the coming year we have the following projects:

International Performances:

  • India Tour 2013 – The Knocking Within and He Who Burns including:
    Bharat Rang Mahotsav Theatre Festival in Delhi, Jan 17
    International Theatre Festival of Kerala, Jan 21
  • Latvia, February 2013 – the first phase of a new collaboration with Gertrudes ielas teatris, a contemporary theater company in Riga.
  • Montreal Fringe Festival 2013 – The Knocking Within

Upcoming US performances:

  • Harvard University, April 11-13 - He Who Burns sponsored by the Harvard College Pakistani Students Association, the Harvard Pakistani Students Group, with support from the Office for the Arts
  • Green Space, Queens, NY, May 18, 2013 – the premiere of the evening-length incarnation of Lilith as part of the Taking Root series
  • Watertown Center for the Arts Blackbox Theater Sept 4-15, 2013 – a two-week run of The Knocking Within

US Residencies 2013:

  • Brown University
  • Gallaudet University
  • National Technical Institute for the Deaf

In The Pipeline:

  • An additional residency/performances of He Who Burns pending at Lousiana State University
  • We are also actively planning with presenters for performances and residencies in Brazil, Pakistan and Bangladesh in 2013-2014.
  • I am about to embark on a multi-year collaboration with the theater and dance departments at Gallaudet University, National Technical Institute for the Deaf and Brown University to create a new approach to visual theater, incorporating elements of Deaf performance and traditions from around the world.  We’re starting in the US but hope to take this work, and students from these institutions, abroad with us within the next few years. 

Recent Recognition:

  • Brother Thomas Fellowship from The Boston Foundation
  • Choreography Fellowship from the Massachusetts Cultural Council. 
  • Creative Artist Fellowship from the American Institute for Indian Studies - to support the creation of a new work on the legendary Rani of Jhansi, in collaboration with composers Fred Ho and Marie Incontrera. 
  • Commission from the Ammerman Center for Art and Technology for the creation of the first ten-minutes of a new solo work with kinetic sculpture and projection, Lilith.

In order to continue to expand this work and take it to new audiences around the world, we need your support.

Ways you can support our work:

Give to the indiegogo campaign!

If you're not comfortable with online giving, send a check to: 

ANIKAI Dance/Akhra, Inc.
67 Dane St.
Somerville, MA 02143

You can also sign up on clickandpledge for a recurring donation for as little as $1 every two weeks.  Every little bit counts!  Of course, you're also welcome to donate more...

Tell your friends!!  The most important way you can support our work is by coming out to our performances and bringing your friends.  So, watch for updates about upcoming performances in your area. We hope to see you soon!

Montreal Fringe Festival 2013 – The Knocking Within

Upcoming US performances:


Harvard University, April 11-13 - He Who Burns sponsored by the Harvard College Pakistani Students Association, the Harvard Pakistani Students Group, with support from the Office for the Arts

Green Space, Queens, NY, May 18, 2013 – the premiere of the evening-length incarnation of Lilith as part of the Taking Root series

Watertown Center for the Arts Blackbox Theater Sept 4-15, 2013 – a two-week run of The Knocking Within

US Residencies 2013:

Brown University
Gallaudet University
National Technical Institute for the Deaf
In The Pipeline:

An additional residency/performances of He Who Burns pending at Lousiana State University

We are also actively planning with presenters for performances and residencies in Brazil, Pakistan and Bangladesh in 2013-2014.
I am about to embark on a multi-year collaboration with the theater and dance departments at Gallaudet University, National Technical Institute for the Deaf and Brown University to create a new approach to visual theater, incorporating elements of Deaf performance and traditions from around the world.  We’re starting in the US but hope to take this work, and students from these institutions, abroad with us within the next few years. 
Recent Recognition:


Brother Thomas Fellowship from The Boston Foundation


Choreography Fellowship from the Massachusetts Cultural Council. 

Creative Artist Fellowship from the American Institute for Indian Studies - to support the creation of a new work on the legendary Rani of Jhansi, in collaboration with composers Fred Ho and Marie Incontrera. 


Commission from the Ammerman Center for Art and Technology for the creation of the first ten-minutes of a new solo work with kinetic sculpture and projection, Lilith.

In order to continue to expand this work and take it to new audiences around the world, we need your support.
Ways you can support our work:
Give to the indiegogo campaign!
If you're not comfortable with online giving, send a check to: 
ANIKAI Dance/Akhra, Inc.67 Dane St.Somerville, MA 02143
You can also sign up on clickandpledge for a recurring donation for as little as $1 every two weeks.  Every little bit counts!  Of course, you're also welcome to donate more...
Tell your friends!!  The most important way you can support our work is by coming out to our performances and bringing your friends.  So, watch for updates about upcoming performances in your area. We hope to see you soon!

story:
About This Project

My name is Rich Wexler. I am the executive director and founder of Project Arts. We need your help. Our main mission is to provide professional theater experiences for teens who don't have access to theater, music, or the arts. We work in a unique manner in which we provide thorough education and training in a variety of theater and performance skills. We do this through a multidisciplinary educational process that includes workshops that focus on teaching skills, group dynamic activities, vocal and acting training, and multiple performances to give our cast a realistic experience of theater. Our casting process targets LGBT teens, students of various socioeconomic backgrounds, and diversity in culture.

Project Arts chooses alternative musicals that deal with social justice issues and address those issues throughout our production. This gives our cast a unique understanding of their characters and the context of the show. Avenue Q, in fact, is a version of Sesame Street that delves into topics more relevant to adults.

We have completed three musicals in our seven years of existence. We are currently producing "Avenue Q School Edition" at The Rotunda. The experiences of the kids who were in our last production, "Rent School Edition" were life-changing. The experience changed my life profoundly as well: I witnessed the teens hard at work, spending hours learning and rehearsing and, as a result, performing at a professional level.

Inspired by Rent's success, I completed graduate school at Drexel University with a Master's of Education and a certificate in Special Education so that I could run Project Arts as a teaching professional and offer additional opportunities for youth. I also worked for Spiral Q Puppet Theater and performed independently as a puppeteer. Hence, upon graduation, I decided to begin a third production.

We need enormous support for this endeavor. Massive budget cuts to schools in the Philadelphia region eliminated arts programs. Even the High School for Creative and Performing Arts (CAPA) almost canceled their yearly musical due to lack of funds. This is why our program is essential and we're seeking your financial support.

Please give if you can. A contribution of even $5 would help us a great deal.


How you can help us and what the money will be used for

Our minimum goal is to raise $5,000. If we exceed this amount, however, it will further support our endeavor. We have a budget of $21,000 dollars. This may sound like a lot of money, but for a show of this magnitude it covers only the basics. We have costs for a full set, puppet rentals, rights for the performance, and hiring professional teachers for our workshops. (Here is a link to our wonderful staff: http://projectarts.info/aboutstaff.html).

We believe in paying our employees a fair wage, because mostly people in theater work for free or very little money. Working in this manner would make our theater company sustainable for our employees. We have additional expenses that include promotions, posters, playbills, etc. Anything you can contribute would facilitate us in giving our cast a life-changing experience and prepare them for a future in the arts. They perform seven shows and work intensely for eight weeks.

Here is a general breakdown of our costs. We were able to get half from grants from our partner organization The Rotunda. But that only covers half the budget.

Budget Breakdown (for the rest of the major costs)
Stage - $1500 (we got a professional stage donated by Mazeppa productions who put on Avenue Q last year) We just need to hire a team to put it together.
Puppet Rental - $1,300
Mic Rental - $2,200
Pay for Employees - $4,000
Posters/Programs -$500

Perks - We have great perks to offer you. We have a silk screened original poster made by Box Brown, who is a very well known comic artist in the United States working out of Philly www.boxbrown.com We also are offering free tickets, advertising space in all our promotions, dinners with the staff, and invite to cast party!

The Impact Of The Project

I invite you to watch clips from our last production to illustrate the impact and quality of our projects. Our educational process, theatrical process, and social justice training make this a life-changing experience for our teens. We also are one of the only theater companies in Philadelphia that works with such a diverse cast. We work with LGBT teens, teens of all races, teens of varying socioeconomic backgrounds, as well as teens that our new to performing. Avenue Q will have the same impact with your support.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't afford to give anything we understand. Instead please spread the word on our theater company. Here are our various links.

Facebook Group
https://www.facebook.com/groups/775969642432114/

Facebook Fan Page
https://www.facebook.com/RichVJYakovWexler

Twitter
https://twitter.com/Projectheater

Ticket site
http://projectartsavenueqschooledition.bpt.me/

Video fundraiser link

http://youtu.be/525Ff-xsT3M

Indiegogo Page

http://tinyurl.com/nvnew2f

Ticket Sales page

http://projectartsavenueqschooledition.bpt.me/

Website

www.projectarts.info

story:
At the beginning of the Cold War, top Russian scientists are extracted from their homes, placed within a secret Soviet Laboratory, and forced to make the first atomic bomb. Pressured to create this destructive weapon, one man faces a grave decision to either inflict this invention on the world, or to escape, putting both his and his child’s life in grave danger.

We are Pinch of Salt Theatre and we really need your helping hand! We are a physical theatre company based in the United Kingdom. We have the opportunity to tour our brand new show ‘The Chase’ internationally, taking it to Italy, Ireland and Amsterdam. As an international ensemble consisting of multi-cultural performers we share the vision in creating low tech – high impact theatre, making it accessible and understandable to all languages, thus breaking any cultural barrier. We have Naomi, Joe and Steph, from England, Julie, from Israel, and finally Cri from Italy. We all met whilst attending an MA in Physical Theatre (International Ensemble). Become part of the Pinch of Salt Theatre family, here’s how you can help:

What We Need & What You Get:

Raising £250 will cover all our expenses to Galway Fringe Festival (Ireland)

Raising another £1200 will guarantee us a place at Rome Fringe Festival (Italy)

Finally another £550 would pay for us to get to and perform in the Amsterdam Fringe Festival (Netherlands)

Any donation will help, from £5 to £1000! In return for your generous contributions, we have some exciting rewards for you ranging from: becoming a ‘Special Friend’ of Pinch of Salt Theatre, to receiving exclusive footage from our touring and rehearsal process, or even the chance of Pinch of Salt Theatre hosting a private event or workshop of your choice.

No contribution is too small: If we don’t make our full goal, all of the funds still go to the development of ‘The Chase’ and our goal of touring our work internationally.

Our Touring Schedule:

With your support and generous contributions, this is where we are hoping to go:

* Premiere at Tristan Bates Theatre, London in June 2014.

* Playing at Rome Fringe Festival, Italy in June/July 2014

* Playing at Galway Fringe Festival, Ireland in July 2014

* Playing at Amsterdam Fringe Festival, Netherlands in September 2014

* Finishing our tour with a final show at Drama St Mary's Theatre, St Mary’s University, Twickenham in September 2014

Other Ways You Can Help:

If you can’t contribute towards our campaign, that’s fine. However there are many ways in which you can still help us. Spread the word! You can do this by using the Indiegogo share tools or share our campaign on your Facebook and Twitter in order to let your friends and family know about us. Please also join our Facebook page so you can keep up to date on all the latest information (www.facebook.com/pinchofsalttheatre) and visit our website (www.pinchofsalttheatre.wix.com/post2).

And last but not least, please come to see our shows. We would love to see your beautiful faces in our audience. We will endeavour to keep everyone updated about when and where we perform, once the details of the tour are solidified. 

Thank you.

story:
Our Project

   Rebel Knock Out Productions is a brand new theatre company located in gorgeous Victoria, BC. Established by four local professional actors, RKO aspires to create theatre that is sharp, polished, and off-beat. In a city so full of art, RKO aims to stand out from the herd by producing unconventional shows which have just enough of an edge to them to pique the interests of the “average Joe", to light a spark in the imaginations of the artistic, and to reel the public into a world of mischief and madness.

   We are delighted to have chosen The Rocky Horror Show  as our inaugural production! This vivacious cult classic provides a wonderful opportunity to connect with the community and share a deliciously demented and delightfully uninhibited story.

  As we are a new company, we are still developing contacts and sourcing materials. We are greatly in need of an extra boost to help make our show a reality. This is where you come in...

   Putting on a show of this magnitude isn’t easy... or cheap. On top of the initial investment for rights ($6500) and a space ($6300), we must consider the cost of costumes, props, building a set, marketing, sound and lighting equipment rental, as well as paying our actors, musicians and production team. One of our goals as an artist collective is to hire both emerging and established artists and pay them by industry standards.

   The amount of time, energy, and heart that everyone is already putting into this production is indicative of amazing things to come, and we would absolutely love the help of our community to succeed in this exciting new endeavor!


Why Fund Us?

Because The Rocky Horror Show is a Screaming Good Time!

   For forty years, audiences have been shocked, excited, and thrilled with the phenomenon that is The Rocky Horror Show. When The Rocky Horror Show first opened in London in 1973, its startlingly intense popularity enabled it to run in its original glory for seven years. Two years after its initial stage release, The Rocky Horror Picture Show was immortalized on the silver screen, jettisoning an all-star cast into their now hallowed Hollywood roles. Soon, the majority of the Western World was singing along to the “Time Warp”, and watching as the conservative Brad and Janet were coaxed out of their narrow minded ways and into the weird and wonderful world of uninhibited thinking. Though The Rocky Horror Show is commonly associated with a cult like following, you don't have to be as insane as Frank N' Furter to enjoy the show. With rip roaring rock and roll numbers like “Sweet Transvestite” and “Hot Patootie”, this crazy, colourful musical will win the heart of even the most timid of audience members.

   For decades, the people of Victoria have been attending the Halloween screenings of The Rocky Horror Picture Show at the Roxy. Now, they'll have a chance to take that experience to the next level with this thrilling live performance. This show will provide all the nostalgia of that intimate yet integral part of our city's culture, and add the spice of life for Victoria's “Rocky Horror” fans!

To Support the Arts!

   By donating as little as ten dollars you are making a huge contribution to this effort! You are not only helping us make our dream a reality; you are reinforcing the need and desire for great live theatre in Victoria. 

    British Columbia has suffered significant cuts to the funding of the arts, and one of the only ways to fight this decline in funding is to band together and create powerful art which inspires the citizens of BC to battle this decision, and allows for the artists in our community to continue to work and grow as performers within their own city. Victoria is home to the Canadian College of Performing Arts, a nationally renowned musical theatre college from which roughly forty professionally trained singers, actors, and dancers graduate every year. As a brand new, local artist collective, RKO will provide employment for these emerging artists, and help to sustain the wonderful, creative culture that Victoria has so long been recognized for.

   Every single donation will receive a shout-out on Facebook and broadcast to the entire community that you want Rocky to be birthed, touch-a-touched, and, (spoiler alert), to ultimately perish. Take a look at the rest of our fantastic incentives, many of which include tickets to the show!

   OR, if you are unable to donate but would still like to help us, please share this campaign with your friends!


Our Team

Director - Britt Small

Musical Director - Steph Sartore

Choreographer - Sarah Murphy

Production Designer - James Insell

Production Manager - Kelly Hudson

Marketing Director - Candace Woodland

Stage Manager - Noelle Antonsen

Producer - Griffin Lea

Cast

Dr. Frank N' Furter - Griffin Lea

Janet - Sarah Murphy

Brad - Randall Peters

Riff Raff - Kelly Hudson

Magenta - Steph Sartore

Columbia - Candace Woodland

Rocky - Lindsay Robinson

Eddie/Dr.Scott - Alex Judd

Criminologist - Jacqueline McLaughlin

Phantom - Sadie Evans

Phantom - Joseph Goble

Phantom - Trevor Hinton

Phantom - Jana Morrison

Usher/Phantom - Andy Liu

Usher/Phantom - Paul Shortt
