story:
Short Summary

I am the Artistic Director for Imagine, Write, Act!  Original Theatre Arts Program and this Fundraising Program will enable students to participate in a highly engaging Theatre Arts program this summer where they will create an original showcase highlighting their creative talents.  Students of all levels are welcome.

I have taught Theatre Arts with the Cal Poly Summer Arts Academy in downtown Pomona and I have experienced first hand the transformative aspect of students being seen, heard and valued through their creativity.

My Original Theatre Arts Program is established and proven.  

I have students of all ages who have benefitted from developing their skill to Imagine, Write, Act!

Your donation will change the lived experience of another and you will receive tangible gifts for your participation.

Each donor, in addiion to their pledge gift, will be a valued audience member for the Imagine, Write, Act! Showcase in mid-August in downtown Pomona.

Funds raised will help provide tuition and production costs.

I have extensive experience in producing entertainment and educaton.  

A letter of recommendation from the Improv Comedy Club is posted on my website www.ConspireToInspire.us

The scope of the program will be determined by the amount of funds raised.  

Regardless of the funding goal being met or exceeded,

I commit to providing a dynamic Theatre Arts experience for students of Pomona.

I have had seven elementary school principals from Pomona Unified School District study with me, valuing their transformative experience of expressing their creativity.  Imagine, Write, Act!

story:
GreenStage

Blood Drive for

The Bacchae is one of the great Greek tragedies. A central figure is the young Greek God Dionysus,known by the Romans as Bacchus, the wine god. His parties were so wild the term bacchanalia was coined to describe them, and The Bacchae includes gods with mommy issues, wild Maenads, drunken revelry, lust, jealousy, revenge, cannibalism, cross-dressing, sex, drugs, rock and roll, and blood.

When the script calls for blood, we always feel more is better.

Our goal: $5,000

GreenStage aims to raise $5,000 through this Indiegogo campaign to cover the productions costs of The Bacchae so that our performances can remain FREE and accessible to all who wish to enjoy a play, regardless of their financial means.

What we need

Our $5,000 goal will cover two main expenses:

·  Rent of Stage One Theatre at North Seattle Community College, where we will perform The Bacchae from Oct. 12–Nov. 2. It costs a lot more to rent a theater with walls and a ceiling than it does to show up in a park!

·  Stage Blood—lots of it, for rehearsals, performances, and to splatter on anyone crazy enough to sit in the first row or to wear white to the show.

Amounts raised beyond the $5,000 goal will help us build sets and props, wash all of that blood out of the costumes every day, compensate our cast and crew, and support our educational programs.

Impact

GreenStage’s mission is to inspire our audiences to engage in live theatre as part of their recreation. We wish to instill and foster in our community an appreciation for live theater. GreenStage is committed to presenting quality productions of classical theater in a manner that is available to all—performing for free in order to reach the largest audience possible. Your contribution will help us continue to attract larger audiences and build our theater and educational programs.

Generous supporters have helped us achieve that goal over the years, to thrive, and to put on outstanding, fun theater without ever charging a penny for a ticket. Your help will boost us to bigger and better things in our second quarter-century!

You can help

In addition to your financial help, please spread the word about GreenStage’s Indiegogo campaign. Tell your family and friends, and anyone who loves theater fun, and ask them to chip in to make The Bacchae a bloody good time.

HARD BARD History

GreenStage, Seattle’s longest-operating Shakespeare company, has been doing Shakespeare in the Park for 25years. Back in 1995 we went indoors for a Halloween special show, producing an over-the-top, blood-splattered version of the Bard’s Titus Andronicus.

We revived the Hard Bard brand in 2009 with a remounting of that hilarious bloodbath, and since have done an annual show filled with gallons of blood, violence, mayhem, and all manner of inappropriate behavior: Macbeth in 2010, The Revenger’s Tragedy in 2011, and Cardenio, Shakespeare’s lost play, in 2012.
story_txt:
GreenStage 
  Blood Drive for

The Bacchae is one of the great Greek tragedies. A central figure is the young Greek God Dionysus,known by the Romans as Bacchus, the wine god. His parties were so wild the term bacchanalia was coined to describe them, and The Bacchae includes gods with mommy issues, wild Maenads, drunken revelry, lust, jealousy, revenge, cannibalism, cross-dressing, sex, drugs, rock and roll, and blood.
When the script calls for blood, we always feel more is better.
Our goal: $5,000
GreenStage aims to raise $5,000 through this Indiegogo
campaign to cover the productions costs of The
Bacchae so that our performances can remain FREE and accessible to all who
wish to enjoy a play, regardless of their financial means. 
What we need
Our $5,000 goal will cover two main expenses:
· 
Rent of
Stage One Theatre at North Seattle Community College, where we will perform
The Bacchae from Oct. 12–Nov. 2. It
costs a lot more to rent a theater with walls and a ceiling than it does to
show up in a park!
· 
Stage Blood—lots
of it, for rehearsals, performances, and to splatter on anyone crazy enough
to sit in the first row or to wear white to the show.
Amounts raised beyond the $5,000 goal will help us build sets
and props, wash all of that blood out of the costumes every day, compensate our
cast and crew, and support our educational programs.
Impact
GreenStage’s mission is to inspire our audiences to engage
in live theatre as part of their recreation. We wish to instill and foster in
our community an appreciation for live theater. GreenStage is committed to
presenting quality productions of classical theater in a manner that is
available to all—performing for free in order to reach the largest audience possible.
Your contribution will help us continue to attract larger audiences and build
our theater and educational programs.
Generous supporters have helped us achieve that goal over
the years, to thrive, and to put on outstanding, fun theater without ever charging
a penny for a ticket. Your help will boost us to bigger and better things in
our second quarter-century!
You can help
In addition to your financial help, please spread the word
about GreenStage’s Indiegogo campaign. Tell your family and friends, and anyone
who loves theater fun, and ask them to chip in to make The Bacchae a bloody good time.
HARD BARD History
GreenStage, Seattle’s longest-operating Shakespeare company, has been doing Shakespeare in the Park for 25years. Back in 1995 we went indoors for a Halloween special show, producing an over-the-top, blood-splattered version of the Bard’s Titus Andronicus. 
We revived the Hard Bard brand in 2009 with a remounting of that hilarious bloodbath, and since have done an annual show filled with gallons of blood, violence, mayhem, and all manner of inappropriate behavior: Macbeth in 2010, The Revenger’s Tragedy in 2011, and Cardenio, Shakespeare’s lost play, in 2012.

story:
We are starting a revolution and we need your help. Philadelphia needs more interactive, imaginative, site-specific theatrical productions geared towards families; productions that invite

children and adults to realize the power of their imaginations by becoming part of the action alongside some of the best performers in the city. And so, we bring you Seek and Hide…

A child arrives at the Playhouse at Smith Memorial Playground excited to play with her mom, but when Mom leaves her on her own with just her imagination and a house full of toys, she’ll need to make the magic happen herself – and she’ll need the audience to join her on a special quest in search of a mysterious being. Along the way, they’ll meet a drill sergeant who’s very serious about playing, the Trikings who rule the river, a train conductor who’s wild about bubbles, and other quirky residents of a land that is only accessible by believing it exists.

Seek and Hide has been created especially for Smith Memorial Playhouse by writer P. Seth Bauer along with director Suzana Berger, designers Chris Bresky and K. Moriah Smith, and the endlessly inventive acting ensemble: Taysha Canales, Jamal Douglas, Kevin Rodden, Lynnia Shanley, & Isa St. Clair.

Dragon’s Eye Theatre creates adventurous theatrical experiences celebrating the power of imagination for audiences of all ages and backgrounds. By producing this kind of theatre in a space that is already a favorite of children and families from everywhere around the Philadelphia area, we hope to share the magic of theatre with people of diverse backgrounds and make it easy for all to participate. We are thrilled to be partnering with Smith whose mission surrounding the importance of imagination and play directly aligns with ours. 

With this Indiegogo campaign, we’re asking for your support to raise funds for this exciting, magical project. A generous donor has offered us a matching gift of $1000. Raising this money will ensure that we can meet all our needs in advance.

 

Let the revolution begin!

 

With huge gratitude,

Suzana Berger & Miriam White

Seek and Hide Co-Producers

story:
Short Summary

Hi, I’m Josh Klipp, creative director and co-founder of the Freeplay Dance Crew, a 13-year old hip-hop dance company based in the Bay Area.  We’d like to ask your help with our new full-length dance show called “Re/Genesis” that will debut April 12 and 13, 2013 in San Francisco.  

This show is a big step up for us as a company, collaborating with another company Prince on Point, exploring deep ideas and concepts of spirituality, and making them come alive on the dance floor for our audiences.  There’s so much involved in putting on a successful dance show, from costumes to stage props, lighting, sound engineering, marketing and more.  Anything you can contribute will be greatly appreciated... and we’ve got some great perks at various levels!

 

What We Need & What You Get

This is an all-volunteer effort from both dance companies, and there’s lots to do!  Costumes are particularly expensive and time-consuming to create, so your support will help us look as fantastic on stage as possible.  We’ve also got some stage props, lighting and programs to print that will be costly to produce.  Lastly, we’d love to have a well-made video documentary about this show.

If we don’t raise the full amount, we’ll make do with a scaled back performance.  But we’d hate to do that, give the importance of the subject and the hundreds of dancer hours involved in preparing for this production.

We’ve got some fantastic perks for those of you who give at different levels, including:

  • Hip-hop classes with Josh Klipp and Shereen Prince
  • A $50 gift certificate for Saha fusion Arabic cuisine in SF!
  • Professional dog-walking services by Charlie Bennett
  • Life coaching / counseling sessions with Rachel Grant and Jeremy Lautan
  • An exclusive invitation to the tech rehearsal of the show and a chance to meet our dancers

 

The Impact

For over 13 years now, Freeplay Dance Crew has performed as a company.  We started out as just a bunch of people who wanted more dance in our lives than weekly dance classes offered.  We wanted to choreograph, create, pick out music, find places to perform and people to share it with.  After a few years of making fun pieces and challenging ourselves to perform alongside some incredible local hip hop companies, we began evolving in a new way.  Instead of just creating pieces that were cute and high energy, we started creating work that held meaning to us, personally, and communally.  We began making performances around our personal expressions – of gender, sexuality, relationship, race, culture, heritage, and very intimate personal experiences.  And we started putting these things on stage.  And as a company we evolved from short hip hop performances that made statements about gay marriage, to evening length shows that explored the cycles of death, dying and rebirth, the relationship of gender to political activism, and the interconnectivity of human experience.  And what we found along the way was that not only were WE as a company more invested in the work we created, but that the authenticity of our voices coming through our work resonated with the people who came to see us perform.  We weren’t trying to make an impact, we just DID.  Because it was real, and honest and true.

Along the way, we met and befriended P.O.P. (Prince On Point), a collective of eclectic dancers with roots in everything from Ballet and Modern to Old Skool Funk and House. Founded in 2009 by lead choreographer, Shereen Prince, these dancers share a fondness for getting down and bringing their whole selves to the work. From speech therapist to neurobiologist, from fierce activist to nurse practitioner, from life coach to students of life and love, these dancers rock it on the dance floor and off. We are so excited to be dancing with P.O.P.!

So here we are in 2013.  And now it makes sense why we’re doing this show about spirituality.  Because Freeplay doesn’t just make shows around abstract concepts, we make shows about what is needed and happening in our lives right now.  And right now the world is disconnected from its spirit.  In a place where connection is defined by updated statuses and tweets, we are more isolated than ever, and struggle to find true connection with one another; we’re grasping for the thread that connects us all as human beings, globally, universally.  That thread is our spirituality, literally, our spirits.

This is the idea behind our upcoming show, “Re/Genesis” -- a performance on the re-discovering and re-claiming of spirituality.  Spirituality as every individual experiences for themselves.  And each experience, different and diverse from someone else’s, still comes from the same heart space which we all have. That space in our chest that leaps when we hear certain kinds of music, or words, or when we meditate, or when we  move.

This isn’t a show about religion, it’s a story about how we are all spiritual beings no matter how that manifests, and this spirituality which, no matter how hard we try to use it divisively against one another behind a curtain of religion, is in fact a connective tissue between us all as living things.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that you might not be in a position to contribute financially at this time. But there are many other ways you can help us make “Re/Genesis” a success:

  • Spread the word to your social network on Facebook, Twitter, your school, work, neighborhood, etc.
  • Post flyers around different neighborhoods, dance schools, churches and other venues
  • Volunteer to help out at the show
  • Drop us some positive vibes in the comments
  • Come to the show April 12 and/or 13!

We're on Facebook and Youtube, and have a email list, if you want to stay up to date on this show and future performances:

  • Join our Facebook Event Page
  • Like Freeplay's Facebook Page and P.O.P's Facebook Page
  • Subscribe to Freeplay's YouTube Channel
  • Join Freeplay's (non-spammy) email list

 Thanks for reading all of this, and keep playing!

story:
The Dance Spot is a small town community Dance program that was established in Alma Kansas in 2011. We have been using the community center as our base of operations for dance classes and are proud to announce that we have acquired the use of a new building off of main street in Alma.

The reason for the fundraising is to help us fund some upgrades to this new building that offers two spaces for offering dance classes to the Alma & Wamego area communities. We are looking for help with finding funds to provide some basic building of a parent lobby area, front office space, mirrors for the walls, ballet bars, paint for the walls and sanding up the floors.

Currently we host over 30 students for our dance programs and just recently provided a cheerleading program for local students as well.

We are looking for volunteers and donations of any kind from materials to financial support to help get the new building ready for our upcoming spring dance classes that will resume February 1st, 2015 at our new location in Alma.

story:
Our Show & Story

On leave from her Banraku puppet piece on Amelia Earhart, Violet Foster brings the Berkshire Fringe her tour de force inquiry into the life of Bill Viola and a personal look at obsession. Guerrilla video, emotional ballad and ground-breaking performance art converge to ask THE ONLY QUESTION THAT MUST BE ANSWERED.


After productions at the Hangar Theatre and Ars Nova's ANT Fest, we're thrilled to bring What Happened to Bill Viola? to the Berkshire Fringe Festival. We have spent a whopping five years expanding and rewriting this show, adding songs and dances, and performing in various venues in and around New York City.


Now that it's starting to pick up some steam, we need your help to make it to Great Barrington for our run at the Fringe, after which we hope to mount it for a longer run as our NYC premiere. So, New Yorkers: if you can help us take it to the Berkshires, we just might be able to bring it home to a theatre near you very soon!


The Impact

We need your help so that we can cover our major and necessary travel and production expenses without having to scale down our production dreams, or reduce compensation for our fantastically talented actors, designers, and other creative team members. If you're able to help us out, your money will go straight towards the essentials, and nothing else.


What We Need

Economically, times are tough for all of us, but if you can give—on any level—it will certainly make a difference. A ten dollar donation will help us pay for one of the several costume and prop pieces we need to purchase. Fifty dollars will cover the printing costs for our beautifully designed custom newspapers, courtesy of the brilliant Brett Banakis. A donation of one hundred dollars or more will help us cover the costs of travel and compensation for the cast and creative team. In short, every little bit counts, and will help us make our way to the Berkshire Fringe.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you like what you see here and want to help get the word out, post this link on Facebook, Twitter, or the social media site of your choosing. Help us spread the word and take our bigger and better show to a brand new audience!

And if you're in the Berkshires this summer, come check it out! We run from August 10th-14th, and you can view the entire calendar and purchase tickets here: http://berkshirefringe.org

story:
The Story

In February 1944, a 2nd Lt. American bombardier named Warren Arieux was shot down and taken prisoner by the Nazis. He was taken to Barth, Germany to the Stalag Luft I POW camp.  Upon arrival, the YMCA gave each prisoner a journal called the Wartime Log. Since there is nothing to do in prison, every time a man received an interesting letter, wrote a poem, created a recipe, could draw a picture, wanted to share information about his hometown, etc., he would do it in everybody’s journal.

My grandfather Warren survived the camp and allowed us a glimpse of his painful—and sometimes humorous—past through the worn pages of his Wartime Log. Based on the rich material found in this journal—and other information collected about the Stalag Luft I camp—a new play has been developed by myself and an ensemble of four men.

The ensemble has transformed a seemingly disjointed, jumbled book into a story of brotherhood, loss, love, greed, hope, and sacrifice.


The Impact

We are rapidly losing the men and women who served in WWII.  Each day more and more of The Greatest Generation die.  It's vital we tell this story, share this experience while they're still here.  Bring your grandparents to see the show with you!  Talk to them about their WWII experience before it's too late.

I was struck by how rare this story is.  We've all seen movies or plays set in the WWII era covering the holocaust, the battlefield, death camps, Nazis and occasionally the horrors of the Japanese POW camps.  But how often do we see or hear about the Allied POWs in Germany?  This play provides a rare view inside the day-to-day life of a Stalag Luft.


What We Need & What You Get

This money will go directly to the production designers and actors in the show.  Each designer and actor will receive a $500 artistic fee.  Additional funding comes from a grant from the City of Houston through the Houston Arts Alliance.  The grant primarily covers the production costs of renting the theater space, equipment and promotions.  We need your help to pay the artists!

Check out the right column for ticket perks :)


Other Ways You Can Help

Tell your friends and family about this special way to celebrate Veteran's Day this year!  Tickets can be purchased on my web site.

story:
Our Story

Tom Lee, the main character in Tea and Sympathy, is a school boy ostracized for being different.  Because he often plays the female character in plays and tends to have a sensitive side, the school culture labels him as a homosexual.  Society’s tendency to stereotype, hate and fear that which is different takes center-stage in this drama that explores sexuality, ethics, and the power of mob-mentality.  We, as a theatre company, are dedicated to bringing to life this story, while asking the question "What does it mean to be a man?"

 

Rehearsals are beginning in January and the show plans to open Mid-March in a quaint venue space in Manhattan.  There is already a driector, stage manager, and marketing professional hired.  Everyone on the production team is dedicated to creating a phenomenal production. 

 

The Impact

This show will be presented to those in the local community in addition to many schools groups.  We are committed to creating a dialogue amongst teenagers to address how they can show the utmost compassion to their classmates and what hatred, ridicule, and mob mentality can do.  In addition, a portion of the box office proceeds will be benefitting the Trevor Project: an organization for preventing teen suicide amongst LGBT youth. 

 

Without theatre to raise awareness, the local community may not be aware of how much an issue this is and students may engage in hateful/violent activities without being aware of the impact of their actions.   


What We Need & What You Get

Here is our budget:

 

Theatre Rental $2000
Concessions $300
SUBTOTAL $2300
Postcard Printing  $100
Playbill Printing

$100

SUBTOTAL $200
Director $500
Stage Manager $500
Photography/Video $500
SUBTOTAL $1,500
Set $300
Costume & Prop  $500
Miscillaneous $200
SUBTOTAL $1000
TOTAL $5000


Rewards will include videos and free tickets.  All contributions are tax-deductible because we are a fiscally sponsored project with Fractured Atlas.

Rehearsals are beginning in January and the show plans to open Mid-March in a quaint venue space in Manhattan.  There is already a driector, stage manager, and marketing professional hired.  Everyone on the production team is dedicated to creating a phenomenal production.  
 

The Impact
This show will be presented to those in the local community in addition to many schools groups.  We are committed to creating a dialogue amongst teenagers to address how they can show the utmost compassion to their classmates and what hatred, ridicule, and mob mentality can do.  In addition, a portion of the box office proceeds will be benefitting the Trevor Project: an organization for preventing teen suicide amongst LGBT youth.  
 
Without theatre to raise awareness, the local community may not be aware of how much an issue this is and students may engage in hateful/violent activities without being aware of the impact of their actions.   


What We Need & What You Get
Here is our budget: 
 







Theatre
  Rental
$2000



Concessions
$300 



SUBTOTAL
$2300








Postcard Printing 

$100 



Playbill Printing
$100 



SUBTOTAL
$200 








Director
$500 



Stage Manager
$500 



Photography/Video
$500 



SUBTOTAL
$1,500 








Set
$300



Costume & Prop 

$500



Miscillaneous
$200 



SUBTOTAL
$1000













TOTAL
$5000 





Rewards will include videos and free tickets.  All contributions are tax-deductible because we are a fiscally sponsored project with Fractured Atlas.

story:
Story

Mia can be anybody she wants to be without a drink in her hand or a pill down her throat. Her soul is as old as Detroit’s Motown Records, yet as vibrant and ageless as Betty White. Mia was preparing to travel the world, until the world closed in and shrunk to the size of her studio apartment. Can she overcome her biggest fear that grandpa can't help her shake?

Meet the creative team:

Mia Raye Smith  (WRITER/ACTRESS/PERFORMER)



Creative. Artistic. Visionary. Mia Raye Smith is a writer, performer, and actress as well as a proud graduate of the William Esper Studio. Mia’s most recent work includes the role of Lisa in the Web Series “Black Actress”. While enrolled in Matt Hovermen’s “Go-Solo” workshop, Mia wrote, developed, and performed her One Woman Show, “I Am Hope”, which was featured in the Emerging Artist Theatre Festival in October 2014. Her next performance will be at the United Solo Festival in the fall of 2015.



Where Your Money Goes


Advertising and Publicity: $1,000

Rehearsal Fees:$1,700

Stage Manager: $300.00

Postcards: $200.00

Video Production: $250.00



The Impact


This show fits into a larger cultural conversation in how it examines a mental health disorder.  I have suffered from debilitating anxiety and panic attacks. Two years ago I was enmeshed in my mind and homebound.  I am grateful that I was able to seek treatment  and healing - and now tell my story. By freely discussing my battle without shame I hope to reach people suffering in silence.  "I Am Hope" will take the audience on a worthwhile journey -  full of fear, faith, and humor.

Other Ways You Can Contribute

You can send my funding campaign to your family and friends and also use social media outlets to help spread the word.

Keep in touch by following my Facebook fan page

https://www.facebook.com/Miarayesmith 

Links To My Work!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qXhrzhl3QYQ

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4SAzrHgQe0M


No donation is too small! Thank you!!!

story:
Who BAMSS is and What We Do!

 --Ben Harney  BAMSS Founder/Director - Tony Award Winner-Dreamgirls     

"For the last 14 years, we have helped transform the lives of children through their participation in our artistic programs. This summer is no different.

Through our Fund-a-Child campaign, you can help a child attend our summer theatre workshop.

Did you know theatre skills teach life skills? BAMSS Theatre Works uses multiple theatre disciplines to help young people and adults gain an understanding of their value and service to their community as creative communicators.

In our summer workshops, participants sing, dance and act as we engage them in the exciting process of storytelling. Young people explore who they are, through a theatrical experience they will never forget."  

“This company has taught me that I can do great things. I was offered so many academic summer internships but I turned them all down because I wanted to come back to BAMSS." --Brittney

Join BAMSS Theatre Works www.bamsstheatreworksny.org in helping Britney and others like her grow through an amazing musical theatre workshop. Youth and young adults spend 5 weeks singing, dancing and acting. The workshop culminates in a production that a great time for the entire family. This year is no different! We are producing a summer workshop of The WIZ a time honored story that teaches us the value of family and friends and to believe in ourselves.

                       

We Need You To Help other Boys and Girls like Britney!

BAMSS prices are kept low to include as many young people as possible. Our tuition is only $650 plus a $25 registration fee. That’s $28 a day for a 5-week program. This is a deal that is like nothing else in NYC, and yet, every year there are kids who want to participate in our program, but can't because money is an issue for their families.

THIS year, you can help!

Here on Indiegogo, you have the opportunity to sponsor a child for our summer workshop. Here are the testimonials of three young people who's lives have been changed by our programs:

"...This program challenged me in so many ways. Even though I've been in plays before, this program was different. I met so many new and interesting people. Working with so much talent in one place challenged me to work even harder throughout the program and my life."

- Brittney

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

"...When I entered BAMSS...for a summer theatre workshop, it totally changed my whole perspective of performers and performing... I went back in 2008 to do their junior production of Annie. I really have been blessed to be able to work with these incredible people. I am going to be a senior this fall because of the foundation...that I've gotten being in this program (BAMSS) , I am going to pursue it in college and as a career."

- Dakota

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

"What BAMSS means to me is pretty much everything. Acting and singing is my life, so to have both of them put together (and I don’t get this a lot) is pretty awesome. I first joined BAMSS when I was 10 years old, and I never left. I was really shy back then, but now I have made a lot of new friends and I'm a lot less shy now. BAMSS is my happy place."

- Kristiana

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

What We Will Do For You!

â€¨We're sure you will agree that the joy of sowing into the life of a child is reward enough, but we have some gifts to say thank you just to show you how much we appreciate your help, and to keep you up to date on the fruits of your giving.

We offer 6 different packages as thank-you’s to our donors. You can be a(n):

  • Tornado
  • Munchkin
  • Yellow Brick Road
  • Gate Keeper
  • Royal Gate Keeper
  • *The Emerald City Citizen Special

 

 *Emerald City Citizens are eligible to purchase 2 tickets for the price of 1 to the "Tenth Anniversary WIZ Reunion Celebration" Honoring Mr. and Mrs. Ben Harney on August 18, 2012 at the Tropical Paradise Ballroom, 1367 Utica Ave. Brooklyn, NY 11203. This semi-formal affair will include dinner, dancing, singing and hilarious WIZ skits performed by the 2002 cast members and much more. With the purchase of one $50 ticket you will receive the second one free. Celebrate with us, Fund-a-Child and continue the legacy.

Tenth Anniversary WIZ Reunion Celebration Tickets are limited!! 

Don't be left out!!!

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

 

To Register for this Summer's 2012 Musical Theatre Workshop of The WIZ, for additional information about BAMSS Theatre Works Inc., our programs, and affiliations or to leave us a message, please visit our website:

www.bamsstheatreworksny.org

Visit us on Facebook:

http://www.facebook.com/pages/BAMSS-Theatre-Works-Inc

Watch us on Youtube:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YHAHk8Cnj3k&feature=youtu.be

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1xqSSq1jQ8s&feature=relmfu

For additional information about the location of our summer program, directions, or to find out about the programs Catherine McAuley H.S. offers, please visit:

http://www.edline.net/pages/CatherineMcAuleyHS

     Be a part of changing a child's life and make a

          donation to BAMSS Theatre Works. 

         You too can "By All Means Save Some".

  BAMSS Theatre Works Inc. is a tax exempt, non-profit 501c3 organization.

story:
69 Love Scenes

Austin's performance community is known nationally for two things--exciting, innovative new plays and improv. Gnap! Theater Projects is the only company in Austin doing both.


Last year, we did a workshop production of a new show called 69 Love Scenes. The play is inspired by the Magnetic Fields' triple album 69 Love Songs, and each scene in the play drew it's title from one of the titular songs on that album, drawing from elements of the album such as the space between sincerity and insincerity, wry humor, and an effortless ability to slip into any genre. It's a whirlwind of a play about love, love songs, and the use and abuse of both.


We learned a lot from that production, we've rewritten and revised a lot, and now we're remounting the full production. It's by far the biggest show we've ever undertaken, and we're asking for your help to make sure we can pull this show off at the level it needs to make it not just good,  but perfect.

What Your Contribution Would Mean to Us

We'll be honest with you--we're a lot more used to doing improv shows whose technical needs are modest to non-existent. A scripted show relying on tons of costumes, props, and a set is not cheap. We're in a position where we can and already have made the production come together out of our normal operating budget. By gaining your financial support for this show, though, we can make sure that our other, less expensive shows later in the year aren't hampered by too much of our budget going for this one. Kind of twofer, really--help this show and you help other shows, too!


What We Need & What You Get

The money we're raising is all going toward the production costs of this show--things like the props, costumes, and set construction costs. And if we make our goal, this will allow for the money we make at the box office to be used to pay for our lovely cast, not just for lovely objects.


In exchange, you get access to all kinds of great stuff, including tickets and print materials from the show, to season passes to Gnap! Theater Projects shows, and more.


Other Ways You Can Help

Whether you give or not, we'd also love it if you passed on word of our endeavors to any fans of theater, improv, or the Magnetic Fields in your life. It's easy to share links for the campaign on Facebook and other social media outlets. 


Thanks a million!!

story:
About us.

What does it mean to be a Beast?

We all have something to say. We all have something to fight. We all have something to hate. We all have something to love. We are human; we are animals. We live in a polite, confined society where we avoid conflict, fear physical contact and communication, and our Prime Minister shakes his own children's hands when he drops them off at school. We're taught to repress what is natural to us so much that what is primal instinct now feels unnatural and strange. To be a beast of the theatre is to explore the animal that lives inside all of us, to go back to square one, how we all started, and journey through the things that truly make us human without the social constructs of society. Our work is to encourage each other to set that beast free. Feel everything. Repress nothing and truly discover what makes us more alike than we think.

There is a beast inside all of us, the question is — will you let it roar?

Beasts of the Theatre is an emerging theatre collective stemming from a group of graduates from the University of Guelph. In September 2011, Lindsay Finnie and Andrew Cromwell met for coffee to discuss the ever-so-popular question, "what do we do with theatre degrees now that we've graduated?"

Within hours, we decided to create rather than wait for an opportunity to find us. In the months to follow, Adam Pellerine, Meredith Henry, Robin Wright and Erika Thompson joined and completed the Beasts Production Team. Together, we are striving to develop and promote the works of new Canadian artists and are currently producing our first play 'Grey Ground' at the 2012 Toronto Fringe Festival.

In an effort to help raise money for our upcoming production we would like to ask you for a donation that will go directly towards the costs of the project.

So what's 'Grey Ground' all about?

Molly has attacked someone. She is a loner, a loser, and now a monster. Standing hated on the outskirts of life, she has no one. There are two sides to every story and Molly is caught in the grey ground in between. Blending traditional dialogue based theatre with choreographed movement and physical storytelling, 'Grey Ground' examines when is the right time to stand up for yourself in a place where everyone listens, but no one really sees?

The world premiere of 'Grey Ground' will be staged at the Helen Gardiner Phelan Playhouse.

Thursday, July 5, 2012 - 10:30pm
Friday, July 6, 2012 - 3:00pm
Sunday, July 8, 2012 - 5:00pm
Monday, July 9, 2012 - 4:30pm
Tuesday, July 10, 2012 - 8:15pm
Thursday, July 12, 2012 - 2:00pm
Friday, July 13, 2012 - 7:00pm

Run time approx 90min.

More information on how to buy your advance tickets is on its way.

Click here for a map of the Helen Gardiner.

Where the Money is Going.

Our participation in the Toronto Fringe Festival is being done entirely not-for-profit. Many of the costs associated with putting on this production are currently coming out of pocket. Your donation would go directly towards the production and will help us to recover some of our costs. 

Our expenses include:

Rehearsal Space.

  • This is where the bulk of the proceeds will go. Many rehearsal spaces in the city range in price from $15 to $20 an hour to rent. The average theatre production has between 60 and 80 hours of rehearsal.

Publicity

  • Printing of Posters and Postcards, Web domain maintenance.

Set. 

  • Though we will have a minimal set, there are certain props that we will need to purchase.

If we don't reach our goal, we will still take what our donors have generously donated and apply it towards the costs of production.

The Impact

Your contribution has several benefits. On the one hand it will help us as we work through the creative process of bringing our production to the 2012 Toronto Fringe Festival. On a larger scale it demonstrates your support for the arts, and your support for Canadian artists.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to make a donation, that's ok. There are other ways you can help. One of the most effective ways to lend a hand to us is by word of mouth. Spread the word about our show. Come show your support during the Festival (July 4th - 15th, 2012). Or tell your friends and family to look us up online. With your help, we can encourage people to support Canadian theatre.

Theatre is about the relationship between theatre creators and the audience. Without you, the audience, theatre couldn't happen. 

Thank you for your support. We really appreciate it.

Sincerely,

Adam Pellerine, Lindsay Finnie, Meredith Henry, and Andrew Cromwell

 

Want to follow along with the progress of Grey Ground?

Check us out: http://www.beastsofthetheatre.com/index.html

Find us on Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/BeastsOfTheTheatre

or follow our Playwright's Blog: http://setthebeastfree.tumblr.com/

story:
"Faith in Shackles" Written and Directed by Justin Giachetti.

A Breaking Through The Box Production

World Premiere at Luna Stage in West Orange, NJ

November 11-13, 2016- Friday and Saturday at 7:30 pm, Saturday and Sunday at 2:00 pm

Half Hour Talk Backs with the Writer/Director and Cast after Every Performance

Tickets: $15 for Students and Seniors and $20 for Adults

 

We are Breaking Through the Box, a new non-profit theater company making a name for ourselves in the tri-state area. Founded and run by young professional artists in the summer of 2016, BTTB has a simple yet strong mission statement: to produce new work, or new takes on old work, utilizing the skills and talent of young, up and coming artists. In tandem with this vision, BTTB would like to establish ourselves as a place for education. We plan to create an environment of artists from all aspects of theatre to encourage and teach children and young adults to follow their passions- and embrace their individuality while doing it. 


 

BTTB made our official debut this past August at the Flea Theater in NYC with the original play Inferno: A New Work About Sin. This season, we have returned to our home base of NJ to produce three shows and share with the immediate theatre community what we represent. Please like Breaking Through the Box Theater Company on Facebook to stay up to date on all of our season information and for opportunities to work with the us. 

 

As a start-up company and a non-profit, any and all donations are sincerely appreciated. Your generosity helps pay for the rental of our space, our props, costumes, and technical equipment, and most importantly to pay the amazing artists who dedicate their time and talent to this company. Once these funds cover our initial budget for this production, they will go on to support the other productions of this season: Almost, Maine in February 2017, and Titus Andronicus in June 2017. 

 

It is with much gratitude that we thank every single donor for their support, and their belief in us and the art we are creating.
story_txt:
"Faith in Shackles" Written and Directed by Justin Giachetti.
A Breaking Through The Box Production
World Premiere at Luna Stage in West Orange, NJ
November 11-13, 2016- Friday and Saturday at 7:30 pm, Saturday and Sunday at 2:00 pm
Half Hour Talk Backs with the Writer/Director and Cast after Every Performance
Tickets: $15 for Students and Seniors and $20 for Adults
 
We are Breaking Through the Box, a new non-profit theater company making a name for ourselves in the tri-state area. Founded and run by young professional artists in the summer of 2016, BTTB has a simple yet strong mission statement: to produce new work, or new takes on old work, utilizing the skills and talent of young, up and coming artists. In tandem with this vision, BTTB would like to establish ourselves as a place for education. We plan to create an environment of artists from all aspects of theatre to encourage and teach children and young adults to follow their passions- and embrace their individuality while doing it. 
 
BTTB made our official debut this past August at the Flea Theater in NYC with the original play Inferno: A New Work About Sin. This season, we have returned to our home base of NJ to produce three shows and share with the immediate theatre community what we represent. Please like Breaking Through the Box Theater Company on Facebook to stay up to date on all of our season information and for opportunities to work with the us. 
 
As a start-up company and a non-profit, any and all donations are sincerely appreciated. Your generosity helps pay for the rental of our space, our props, costumes, and technical equipment, and most importantly to pay the amazing artists who dedicate their time and talent to this company. Once these funds cover our initial budget for this production, they will go on to support the other productions of this season: Almost, Maine in February 2017, and Titus Andronicus in June 2017. 
 
It is with much gratitude that we thank every single donor for their support, and their belief in us and the art we are creating.

story:
Who Is First N Last Productions?

 

Kate Loomer: Director

Kate Loomer started doing theatre at a very young age, but began directing in Grade 9. She graduated in 2011 from SMUS, and enrolled in the University of Victoria Theatre Program with a specialization in Directing. Her first major directing credit was Birdwatching, which was featured in the 2015 SATCo season. That same year she wrote and directed her own piece, You've Got To Hide Your Love Away, as part of the 4th Year Director’s Showcase. Her final major credit in the Theatre Department was acting as Assistant Director for UVic’s production of Wild Honey. Other theatre credits include acting as assistant stage manager (The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe, 2014), and assistant sound designer (Arbutus, SATCo 2016). Outside of school, she was a summer intern at Theatre SKAM (2013), the box office manager for Theatre SKAM’s Bike Ride/SKAMpede (2013-2015), and is currently doing box office work for The Belfry Theatre, Ticket Rocket and the University of Victoria’s Ticket Centre. After graduating, Kate wants to focus on producing plays with First N Last Productions and learning more about arts administration.

Jack Hayes: Playwright

 Jack began acting in Grade 9 with the SMUS Alternative Theatre Company as well as in the yearly musicals. Jack and Kate first worked together there, on the 2011 production of Miss Saigon. Jack graduated from SMUS in 2013 and enrolled in the University of Victoria Theatre Program, where he specialized in acting. His main-stage production credits include: Baron Van Swieten in Amadeus (2014), Crook-fingered Jake in Threepenny Opera (2015), and Mikhail Vasilyevich Platonov in Wild Honey (2016). Jack has also acted in several SATCo productions, including: Goblin Market (2014), Welcome to Misery (2015), and The Pound (2015). Additionally, he has written two plays that were staged through SATCo: Birdwatching (2015), and Arbutus (2016). Recent non-UVic credits include Victoria Fringe shows Two (2015, winner of Favourite New Play) and Wyrd Sisters (2015, winner of Favourite Dance Piece), and Theatre SKAM’s production of the The Lab (2015). This summer has seen the revision of his play Birdwatching, which is set for the stage this August in the 2016 Victoria Fringe. 

 

Creative Team

 

Starring

Emma Grabinsky as Nolan

Rachel Myers as Tannis

Alex Judd as Edgar

Brett Hay as Kenzie

Taryn Yoneda as the Crow

With

Costumes by Delaney Tesch

Set by Sean Thompson

Lighting by Nicholas Beamish

Sound by Carl Keys

And

Assistant directed by Molly Powlowski

Stage Managed and Dramaturged by Kat Taddei

 

What Is The Show?

 

Nolan is being watched. Only, the past and present have gotten so foggy since she moved from Vancouver to Toronto, she can’t tell whether the eyes on her back are real or imagined. Birdwatching moves seamlessly between dance and dialogue as Nolan struggles to ground herself in the here and now.

Birdwatching was the first full-length play Jack Hayes had ever written, and, shortly after completing it, he was lucky enough to have it produced by the Phoenix Theatre's Student Alternative Theatre Company as a part of its 2015 spring season! In the year and a half since then, Birdwatching has grown and developed along with its author, transforming from a first to a second and then third and final draft during its Fringe rehearsal process. The Victoria 2016 Fringe will be the first time that this new version of Birdwatching takes the stage - and the whole creative team cannot wait to share the final product.

 

So, Why An Indiegogo Campaign?

 

Currently, we are looking for an additional $700.00 in funding for our show. This money is going straight to our Costuming and Marketing costs. Thanks to our current sponsors the Honey-Do List Guys, Matt n' Natt, and Newport Property Management, we have been lucky enough to cover the costs of our set and the initial Fringe application fee. Below are our remaining costs.

  • $300 - This money will go directly into bolstering our marketing campaign, covering the cost of printing posters and business cards to get the word out!
  • $400 - We are lucky enough to have the amazing Delaney Tesch as our Costume Designer, who is making us an original crow mask from scratch, as well as sourcing the rest of the costumes. However, a cast's worth of costumes and a custom built mask aren't cheap! Not to mention we would love to pay Delaney for all the hours of hard labour she has put into her fantastic design. 

One of the great things about the Fringe Festival is that 100% of the ticket sales go directly back to the artists involved in the shows. This is why one of our goals has been to cover the costs of our production so that we can pay all these emerging artists for the dozens of hours of hard work they have put into this production. On our team we have eleven UVic Phoenix students, and this project is an invaluable learning experience, especially for those about to enter the field in earnest once they graduate. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

Even if you aren't able to contribute financially, we would really appreciate if you could spread the word to your friends about the show and this campaign - everything helps. 

Thank you so much for taking the time to visit our campaign page. We hope to see you out at the show!

 

First N Last Productions

story:
"Not just another Tribute Show! We're not Elvis Live! It's so much more than just a concert. It's unique"

How Can I Keep from Singing pays tribute to the music of Eva Cassidy – A North American treasure. Featuring the talented and versatile vocalist, Cayla Brooke, the show takes you on a journey from Eva Cassidy’s humble beginnings in Washington DC, to some of her most magical moments on stage and ultimately her untimely death in 1996.

“People have either heard of Eva – and are devoted fans,” commented Cayla Brooke. “Or they have yet to be! For both groups, this show is a magical experience.”

Featuring over 25 songs it’s an audible feast of musical styles ranging from jazz and blues, to gospel, country and folk. “Just none of that pop crap,” as Eva would say. Where else can you hear Songbird, Over the Rainbow, Wayfaring Stranger, Fields of Gold and Danny Boy all in setting? Cayla deftly blends these songs together seasoning them with her own brand of wit and sparkle.

Cayla is joined on stage by the charismatic and gifted vocalist Tom Pickett adding some funk and good old fashioned soul to the mix. The four piece band is led by Bill Sample on piano and featuring Rene Worst on bass, David Ivaz on guitar and Buff Allen on drums.

We are not backed by a big theatre company or corporation. Its just us. A Group of musicians and performers who believe in this project. The money donated will go towards the start up costs of putting on another run of the show in the Spring of 2014. It is during this very important run that minor changes to the script and music will be made in an effort to get the show tour ready. We are happy to announce that "How Can I Keep from Singing" has been booked for a one week run in September 2014.



By helping us, you will not only be supporting the arts, but you will help this little show that could get up and running for real. You put the power back into the production. We wholeheartedly believe in what we have here. We've given our hearts, soul, time and money and you can now help us bring our dream to fruition, by aiding us with our start up costs. Taking the pressure off financially so that we can do what we do best. Perform. We know we've got a hit on our hands, we could feel it in the premier run. There was electricity in the air.

So this is what is all about:

In reality, the show costs about $12,000 to put on. That's a lot of cash. We've only asked for $5000, but we certainly could use more and wont say no.

The money donated will go towards the start up costs of putting on another small run of the show in the Spring of 2014. It is during that very important run that we will tweak a few things, pare other things down and get the show tour ready. It will go towards things that need money before we receive a penny from any ticket sales. Things like ...

  • Booking a theatre
  • Advertising.
  • Posters and handouts and programs
  • Changes to music charts and creating new ones
  • Simple set pieces
  • Costumes and props
  • Hiring a choreographer
  • Hiring a lighting designer

What do you get out of it?

  • If you live in the Vancouver area you can get tickets to the opening night of the show. They'd make a great stocking stuffer!
  • A hand written thank you note from either of the stars of the show
  • A promotional CD of the May performance (not for public distribution)
  • An autographed photo from our premier performance in September 2013.

  • Tickets to the Invite only wine and cheese party opening night! Fancy Schmancy.
  • Your named mentioned in the program or even on the poster!
  • A T-Shirt! Really? Yes. An awesome T-Shirt!

How can your few dollars help?

Ever shop at Costco? Then you know how saying "Ooh that's such a good deal!" a few times turns into "Oh my God! How did my bill get so high?" Every dollar adds up and helps us enormously. If 100 people donate $25 that's $2,500 right there! And boy, would that go a long way to getting this show up and running. We can book a theatre with that!

FAQ

Q. If the show was so popular why do you need financial help?

A. Good question. The start up costs to putting on a new show can be high. There's all that rehearsal time, getting the music together, getting the costumes things like that. Also, just because the audience loved it doesn't mean that the seats were completely full. We were getting there, and will be there next time.

Q. Why don't you have a date for the next show?

A. Another great question. We haven't booked a theatre. We haven't booked a theatre because we don't have a down payment. Which is why we're asking for help. Theatre's are booked months in advance. After this campaign is over we will look to see what is available in the Vancouver area and book. We are hoping for a May 2014 show.

Q. How long will the next run be?

A. We're not sure. It depends on how well this campaign goes and other fundraising efforts we will do. Two or three nights more than likely.

Q. After this run then what? 

A. This next run is a very important one. When we did the first show,, we were able to look at it with a critical eye and see what needed to be changed (which isn't a lot) and where things could be pared down. We are happy to announce that we will be doing a one week run of the show in September as the opening show for a theatre house's upcoming season. We want to do another run so that we can work these changes and be ready for the run in September.

Q. Why don't you just get a producer?

A. We may. But for right now we are trying to do it on our own. Everyone on board right now understands the project and its uniqueness. Our past experience showed that people with the money have power and that can bring power to change things. We want to give the production the power so that the integrity of the show remains the same.

Q. What's to say that you won't just spend the money on a vacation?

A. Nothing. Except that we wont. There has been too much blood sweat and tears that have gone in to this show. If we're anything we're persistent and determined. The money will be deposited into a separate bank account specifically to be used on the budgeted start up costs for the next run.

Other Ways You Can Help

We know not everyone has money. Ha! Believe us we know! Every dollar helps, but we're not into taking food off of tables, a Starbucks latte ... yes ... but not food. So, if you can't afford to give you can certainly help by spreading the word. Like Thornton Wilder said "Money is like manure, it's not worth a thing unless it's spread around encouraging young things to grow." So spread the word. Share us on Facebook. Tweet away. Send us out in an email. We thank you for it!

story:
Short Summary

My name is Daniella Khoury and I am the Logistics Director of the Roswell High School Theatre Troupe. Our troupe is devoted to creating amazing shows and has plans of producing a few shows soon such as A Midsummer Night's Dream and our own student-written student-directed festival called Short Attention Span Theatre. A main component to our productions is our amazing lighting design. Our lighting expert has created amazing designs for shows such as Hairspray, Antigone and Crimes of the Heart, all with a lighting board around 23 years old. We would like to replace the old board with a new Element lighting board and buy a Macbook Air to use as a monitor. 

What We Need & What You Get

We need:

- an Element lighting board(http://www.etcconnect.com/product.overview.aspx?Id=22010) 

- a Macbook Air to serve as our monitor for levels(http://store.apple.com/us/browse/home/shop_mac/family/macbook_air)

Contributors to the project will be recognized in this year's production programs and they will recieve a DVD of this year's shows with a special thank you from the cast, as well as posters of the show. 

If the goal is not met, the money will go directly to scholarships for our enthusiastic senior graduates. 

The Impact

As a troupe, we believe that theatre is an art, and a special one. We believe in producing shows that can help put a smile on someone's face and in turn, allow us to smile. We've been dedicated to creating a name for ourselves in the world of theatre, and although we are just a high school organization, we believe that allowing our actors and techies to be familiar with this modern equipment will allow the ones interested to further persue theatre in college. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help spread the word! Every cent is appreciated. Thank you so much.

story:
Move For Megan

About Megan:

Megan Heeringa is a 17 year old senior at Kenowa Hills High School who has been dancing since she was 4 years old.  She loves all styles of dance but has a particular passion for jazz.  In addition to being a company dancer at the Dance Network she is a member of Kenowa Hills dance team.

On January 3, 2013, Megan was diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia.  She spent 64 days at Helen DeVos Children's Hospital.  She has undergone two very intensive rounds of chemotherapy done inpatient.  In addition, she is currently undergoing a round of outpatient chemotherapy. She has yet another round of chemo immediately prior to a bone marrow transplant which will take place soon at Mott's Children's Hospital in Ann Arbor, MI.

 

How you can help:

When thinking of a way to show support for Megan, a dance inspired benefit felt like the perfect solution.  Move For Megan is a benefit we are holding as dancers responding to leukemia.  On March 23rd dancers from across West Michigan are invited to Move For Megan; a series of master classes being held at Grand Valley State University. 

There will be 10 classes offered in ballet, modern, jazz and hip-hop taking place from 10:30 am-4:45 pm.  Please see the link below for the class schedule.  It is recommended dancers arrive 30 minutes prior to their first class to register and stretch.  A liabilty form MUST be filled out for each dancer prior to partcipating.  Forms will be available the day of.

Location for the event:

Grand Valley State University

1605 Performing Arts Center
1 Campus Drive
Allendale, MI 49401

PLEASE CHECK OUT THE FACEBOOK & MASTER CLASS SCHEDULE LINKS BELOW.

All proceeds will go towards Megan and her family. 

We want everyone dancing for Megan! Even if you do not intend on taking a master class on March 23rd you can still offer Megan your support by donating any amount you see fit!

"There is a vitality, a life force, an energy, a quickening, that is translated through you into action, and because there is only one of you in all time, this expression is unique."  Martha Graham


We thank you for your support. 

Love, dance and blessings!!!

She has yet another round of chemo immediately prior to a bone marrow transplant which will take place soon at Mott's Children's Hospital in Ann Arbor, MI.
 
How you can help:
When thinking of a way to show support for Megan, a dance inspired benefit felt like the perfect solution.  Move For Megan is a benefit we are holding as dancers responding to leukemia.  On March 23rd dancers from across West Michigan are invited to Move For Megan; a series of master classes being held at Grand Valley State University. 
There will be 10 classes offered in ballet, modern, jazz and hip-hop taking place from 10:30 am-4:45 pm.  Please see the link below for the class schedule.  It is recommended dancers arrive 30 minutes prior to their first class to register and stretch.  A liabilty form MUST be filled out for each dancer prior to partcipating.  Forms will be available the day of.
Location for the event:
Grand Valley State University
1605 Performing Arts Center1 Campus DriveAllendale, MI 49401
PLEASE CHECK OUT THE FACEBOOK & MASTER CLASS SCHEDULE LINKS BELOW.
All proceeds will go towards Megan and her family. 
We want everyone dancing for Megan! Even if you do not intend on taking a master class on March 23rd you can still offer Megan your support by donating any amount you see fit!
"There is a vitality, a life force, an energy, a quickening, that is translated through you into action, and because there is only one of you in all time, this expression is unique."  Martha Graham

We thank you for your support. 
Love, dance and blessings!!!

story:
***STRETCH GOAL***

Thanks so many, we reached our goal in one week! A HUGE thank you to our 58 backers for their amazing donations, and appreciation for helping spread the word, liking our posts on FB, or telling us that you believed in our artistic voice.

With 20 days left in the campaign, and lots of excitement, we'd like to announce a stretch goal. If we can raise $5250 total (an extra $1500), we will be able to document TaikoWorks 2017 show documented by a professional videographer, and create video excerpts of the performance that can be shared with all. 

We hope you will join this exciting journey with us!

Goodbye, Hello: A new artistic leap for Unit Souzou

As we emerge into our 3rd year of sharing relevant stories through drum and dance, we are excited to break new ground in our work. We ask for your support to activate our first-ever annual TaikoWorks show. Beginning a new yearly tradition, TaikoWorks will be an opportunity to celebrate and showcase our most current ruminations of both finished and unfinished work.

This 3rd year represents big transitions in the life of our company in which we leave behind the start up nature of our “youth” and bloom into a new phase of growth and beginnings. Help us say goodbye to the past, and hello to a new era in Unit Souzou’s artistic journey. Your contribution towards our Goodbye, Hello campaign will truly bring to life the multiple meanings of souzou - “creation,” “imagination,” and “noisy” in new and exciting ways.

About TaikoWorks 2017

On August 30th, Unit Souzou will present TaikoWorks 2017, our first-ever annual showcase of current artistic ruminations. As our inaugural year, we will ignite our creativity and imagination by hosting a site-specific performance exploring themes of goodbye from sacred formal farewells, casual everyday parting, and unforeseen, sometime tragic transitions.

The site of this work has deep and layered significance for Unit Souzou. It will take place at the Jade APANO Multicultural Space (JAMS), which has been our home since our inception. In the fall, JAMS will close down in its current form as it begins transformation into a new affordable housing and community space. While we are excited for this important new community project, it will be a bittersweet goodbye to our artistic home of the last three years. Using the unique shape and layout of the building, this performance will span three rooms, inviting the audience to physically embody the act of parting. It will also be a symbolic and meaningful goodbye to this gathering space, allowing us to create a sacred and intentional farewell for all attending.

TaikoWorks will feature exciting artistic milestones:
  • Debut of the Unit Souzou professional ensemble in Portland
  • Premiere of new composition, Entangled, composed by ensemble member, David Wells for the Unit Souzou community group
  • Performance of thematic works inspired by the sacredness of goodbye created by the Unit Souzou professional ensemble

TaikoWorks 2017 will take place Wednesday, August 30th 8:00 pm at the Jade APANO Multicultural Space (JAMS), 8114 SE Division Street, Portland, OR.

It takes a village to make art!

We love to create new work, but we can't do it without community support. Contributions to the Goodbye, Hello campaign will allow UNIT SOUZOU to fully embrace and realize a new artistic milestone. We hope you will join us on this journey.

About Unit Souzou

'Souzou' can be written in three ways meaning 'creation' (創造), 'imagination' (想), or 'noisy' (騒々), alluding to a force by which new ideas are born and take shape in the world. Inspired by these words, the mission of Unit Souzou is to build creative, imaginative works while honoring the history and roots of the taiko art form. The core of Unit Souzou’s artistic voice is personal and authentic, sound shaped and inspired by form and by movement. The essence of Unit Souzou is an expressive blend of taiko and Japanese folk dance, forging new traditions for evolving communities. In addition to creating groundbreaking professional theatrical works, Unit Souzou is deeply committed to share taiko through community performances and collaborations, public classes for adults and youth, and school-based education programs.

Unit Souzou was founded in 2014 by co-directors Michelle Fujii and Toru Watanabe, relentless innovators at the forefront of a growing artistic movement within the worldwide taiko community. Fujii and Watanabe met at Warabi-za, Japan’s foremost traditional folk dance troupe based in Northern Japan. The two have worked with premiere North American taiko groups including San Jose Taiko, On Ensemble, Portland Taiko, TAIKOPROJECT, and Shasta Taiko

Unit Souzou has received support from Regional Arts & Culture Council and the National Performance Network (NPN), and was a featured showcase performer at NPN’s 2015 Annual Meeting. UNIT SOUZOU has toured across the west in Oregon, Washington, California, Montana, Utah, Arizona, and Wyoming, performing professional theatrical work and teaching taiko workshops. They are founding teaching artists with the Right Brain Initiative and are on the teaching artist roster with Young Audiences of Oregon & SW Washington.

story:
I have been accepted to present at the American Society for Theatre Research's (ASTR) 2013 conference in Dallas, TX as part of their Shakespearean Performance Research group. If you know me personally, you know how big of a deal this is for me, how excited I am to have this opportunity, and how honored I am that my thesis work has been accepted in such a manner.

Presenting my research would make a great impact on my scholarly presence in this field. This research has already began having an effect in the scholarly community of Staunton, VA, mainly among those at the American Shakespeare Center, and I believe that it is important to spread my research as far as I am able. The claims I make are significant in the world of Shakespearean and early modern theatre history. Below you can find the 200-word abstract describing my findings.

The conference is held November 7-10th, and costs a hefty amount of money to get there, including registration fee, hotel accommodations, and flight arrangements. Due to the high amount of dedication and work required of those of us currently in the Mary Baldwin College Shakespeare and Performance MFA company, I am no longer employed as I have been for the last two years. Funds are tight for me this year, and any donation you are able or willing to make is greatly appreciated!

Paper Abstract:

"Stephen Orgel has taught us that it was not illegal for women to act in the early modern period, and Pamela Allen Brown has provided examples of multiple ways women participated in performance events across England but, as of now, no coherent argument has emerged to explain why women were excluded from the early modern English commercial stage. "‘Youth in Petticoats’: the Early Modern Boy Actor, the All-Male Stage, and Female Performance” argues that the all-male stage of early modern England was more a result of economics and practicality than illegality and ideology. The early modern commercial stage turned to all-male companies in response to the available labor conditions, namely the apprentice system that prevailed in London livery companies and not as a way to distinctly bar women from performing. A change in the way scholars perceive theatre of the early modern period is now needed as a result of these findings. As a result, scholars and educators should pass along the information that women were allowed to act in the period, and begin showcasing what really was occurring: the sensible use of a system that was fiscally responsible for the playing companies. By doing so, students will have an opportunity to better explore the period, potentially awarding early modern women more agency than scholars in the past have given them."

story:
About Our Perks

We are going to vandalize stuff for you. Whether that be making a stencil just for you, scrawling your name on the Brooklyn Bridge all depends on how much you give. Want us to get creative? Feel free to donate more than $10! 

 

Here We Are

The How is a multidisciplinary NYC-based performance ensemble. 

We seek out collaborators who expand our aesthetics and our politics.

We prioritize dialogue, provocation and improvisation to create original works. 

Vandals is a piece unlike any other. It breaks down moulds of ‘character’ and authorship to create a theater that is surprising, formally experimental, and socially exigent. Developed last December at Dixon Place, The How is looking to premiere its new piece this Spring, and we need your help. 

Here's Where We're Going

This will get Vandals through its next development phase and ready for New York stages. If you want to follow the money, we've laid it out for you.

  • Pay our artists --- We worked with a group who refracted and reflected different experiences and viewpoints on vandalism as protest. Our team totals 10 in all, and while the $2,000 we have budgeted won't let us pay them anywhere near what they deserve, it will at the very least be a measure of gratitude for their creativity and virtuosity.  
  • Take care of the Venue --- We have a wonderful arrangement with the curators at Arete Gallery in Greenpoint who are doing a lot to make this show a reality. $300 of our budget will go towards transforming this non-traditional space. 
  • Help us reach new audiences --- We work fiercely to promote our shows. We put the word out through guerilla techniques like wheatpasting or enlisting bar patrons to vandalize art for instagram, as well as more traditional means like paid advertising. While paying artists is always our highest priority, throwing $650 into Return-On-Investment doesn't hurt. 

Here's What You'll Accomplish

New York City brings artists from around the world and from across America together. The How gives them a context in which to create, teach, experiment, and thrive.  

  • As we finish development on Vandals, we are already beginning work on another multidisciplinary theater piece, Equivalents.
  • We put on workshops and classes taught by our diverse and storied collaborators, geared towards performers of ever stripe. 
  • Every single month we go off leash with Howl, a multidisciplinary performance series that pops up around Brooklyn featuring the best minds of our generation. 

Here's What We're Up Against

Without your support, the chances of us getting caught in a cycle of works-in-progress is high.  We benefit from curatorial opportunities that allow us to pioneer new ideas. Meanwhile, the face of the underground is changing. 70 performance spaces have disappeared from New York in the past decade, with 10 more in danger of foreclosure.

Bringing a work to premiere is harder than ever, but we are carving out our way one show at a time, all thanks to our fabulous network of friends, fans, and supporters. Thanks to people like you, the candle keeps burning, no matter the attempts at sanitization, gentrification and cultural erasure the developers push forward.

​

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're jingling change in your pocket wondering if you can afford a deli coffee, you're probably not going to throw $10 onto our Indiegogo. We get it. Keep fighting.

Posts are free, though. So if your heart is in the right place and last week's paycheck didn't pass muster, consider throwing in a good word, a retweet, a like, or a share on social media. Or just tell a friend about us. Or someone whose standing next to you. Or whatever. Chances are we're all going to the same place. 

Thanks for reading,

The How

story:
“I had decided to allow no room in the universe for something which shamed and frightened me. I succeeded very well—by not looking at the universe, by not looking at myself, by remaining, in effect, in constant motion.”

James Baldwin, Giovanni’s Room

 

My name is Andrew Skeels and I am a dancer and choreographer with Les Grands Ballets Canadiens de Montréal.  I am starting work on a new choreographic project: a dance adaptation of James Baldwin’s Giovanni’s Room.  Published in 1956, Giovanni’s Room is a provocative and controversial work well ahead of its time, which explores sexuality, repression, isolation and masculinity in society.  In order to distance himself from his family and society, David, an American too ashamed to accept his sexuality, moves to Paris where he meets—and falls in love with—Giovanni.  His intense love for another man deeply frightens David, leading him to make a decision to leave Giovanni in order to marry an American woman.  What ensues is Giovanni’s downfall and subsequently David’s.  Many of the book’s themes remain profoundly relevant, and I am convinced that this emotionally charged storyline will make a very stirring ballet.

The piece will be developed over a five-week intensive rehearsal process beginning late May 2013.  Featuring five dancers from Les Grands Ballets Canadiens de Montreal, the work will premiere in September as part of Montreal’s Festival TransAtlantique.   

I am asking for help to bring this project to fruition.  I am seeking to raise $3,000 in this fundraising campaign, enough to pay one of the five dancers involved with this project.  Exceeding this goal, of course, would greatly help in the subsequent fundraising phases.  

This production has the potential to be truly exceptional.  The dancers, all current and former soloists of Les Grands Ballets, are well acquainted with and thoroughly invested in my creative process.  These artists are distinguished by their professionalism and matchless talents, and I know each one of them will deliver a riveting performance.  Andrei Przybytkowski, a Montreal-based composer whose striking music has been used by a number of contemporary dance choreographers, is composing the score for the ballet.

As a donor, you will be supporting a unique dance project.  Choreography has been my vehicle of artistic expression for 15 years.  My works have been presented by dance companies, festivals, universities, and museums throughout North America, including Colorado Ballet, Festival Ballet Providence, WestWave Dance Festival San Francisco, Museum of Contemporary Art Denver, and Colorado State University.  It is my hope that you will consider supporting this project. 

I invite you to search my name on www.youtube.com to view some of my recent works or visit my website, www.andrewskeels.com.

Warmly,

Andrew Skeels

P.S. Special thanks to Bérenger Zyla, Travis Becker, and Allen Birnbach whose photos are used in this web campaign.

story:
Center Stage Dance And Cheer - Mini Dance

We are really excite that our Center Stage Dance & Cheer Cherry Bomb dance team has been invited to participate at the U.S. Finals in Virgina!

The girls took home #1 in Mini Hip Hop and Best Choreography at JamFest Nationals in Gatlinburg Tennessee earlier this month.

 

The trip for the team is expensive with Travel, Hotel, Competition fees. We would really like any help that we can get to help parents and team members get there! It looks like it's going to cost us around $2000 to get the girls there to compete.

Any amount helps!
