story:
In Short:

A chamber-size company known for innovative ballets, Dances Patrelle (dP) is honored to celebrate our 25th New York season with Shakespeare's 450th birthday (drama is our game, alas we aspire to such a name)! This September we plan to present a thrilling revival of Romeo & Juliet. Following dP's tradition of educating children and nurturing professionals in the art of ballet, our Romeo & Juliet casts aspiring ballet students alongside some of the most celebrated dancers of our time. This vision needs your help.

  • What: Francis Patrelle's choreography, based on Shakespeare's Play & set to Prokofiev's Score
  • Where: The Kaye Playhouse at Hunter College, E. 68th Street 
  • When: September 11 - 14, 2014 (Rehearsals begin in June) 
  • Who: Dances Patrelle
What We Need & What You Get

JOIN US! There has never been a more exciting time to be part of the dP family. Check out the great perks available here: anniversary merchandise, special tickets and events. Plus, as a 501(c)3 organization, all contributions to dP are fully tax-deductible. 

THE GOAL: Pay the artists, Rent the theater, Lower the ticket prices 

We have set a $25,000 fundraising goal for the end of June, which will allow us to begin production on Romeo & Juliet. Our total project budget is $75,000, with $40,000 going directly to artists' salaries. Other expenses include theater rental and restoration of original costumes and sets. Additionally, to make the creative genius of Shakespeare and extraordinary dance accessible to all, we aim to offer ticket prices in the $40 range. 

THE PRODUCT: 

Don't miss this evening of dramatic dance, performed by a diverse cast of the highest quality. Romeo & Juliet will provide the perfect platform for life enhancing artistic experiences and audience engagement. Featuring:

  • Star Guest Artists
  • 20 professionals
  • 10 pre-professional ballet students
  • 20 children
  • Original costumes by Rita Watson and sets by Gillian Bradshaw Smith

Jennifer Dunning says in the 1993 NY Times “Francis Patrelle gives the traditional tale ingenious twists…the stories behind the stories.” 

YOUR IMPACT

Your generous contribution to this project will allow us to honor and continue all parts of our mission, now and for years to come: 

  •  invigorating the exceptional art form of professional dance by presenting original works which synthesize movement, music, and drama in a ground breaking way.
  • developing the next generation, by providing an opportunity for students and young dancers to perform alongside the greatest artists of our time, sharing in mentoring relationships and exploring artistic depth. 
  • engaging diverse, underserved audiences through unique, intimate performances, at more accessible ticket prices.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate at this time, you can still help! Please share this campaign with friends, family, and co-workers, via word of mouth and social media. Share our quick link on your Facebook page and Twitter accounts: igg.me/at/dancespatrelle-RJ2014 

Also contact us for volunteer opportunities at director@dancespatrelle.org.
story_txt:
In Short:A chamber-size company known for innovative ballets, Dances Patrelle (dP) is honored to celebrate our 25th New York season with Shakespeare's 450th birthday (drama is our game, alas we aspire to such a name)! This September we plan to present a thrilling revival of Romeo & Juliet. Following dP's tradition of educating children and nurturing professionals in the art of ballet, our Romeo & Juliet casts aspiring ballet students alongside some of the most celebrated dancers of our time. This vision needs your help.

What: Francis Patrelle's choreography, based on Shakespeare's Play & set to Prokofiev's Score


Where: The Kaye Playhouse at Hunter College, E. 68th Street 

When: September 11 - 14, 2014 (Rehearsals begin in June) 

Who: Dances Patrelle

What We Need & What You GetJOIN US! There has never been a more exciting time to be part of the dP family. Check out the great perks available here: anniversary merchandise, special tickets and events. Plus, as a 501(c)3 organization, all contributions to dP are fully tax-deductible. THE GOAL: Pay the artists, Rent the theater, Lower the ticket prices We have set a $25,000 fundraising goal for the end of June, which will allow us to begin production on Romeo & Juliet. Our total project budget is $75,000, with $40,000 going directly to artists' salaries. Other expenses include theater rental and restoration of original costumes and sets. Additionally, to make the creative genius of Shakespeare and extraordinary dance accessible to all, we aim to offer ticket prices in the $40 range. THE PRODUCT: Don't miss this evening of dramatic dance, performed by a diverse cast of the highest quality. Romeo & Juliet will provide the perfect platform for life enhancing artistic experiences and audience engagement. Featuring:
Star Guest Artists

20 professionals


10 pre-professional ballet students


20 children

Original costumes by Rita Watson and sets by Gillian Bradshaw Smith
Jennifer Dunning says in the 1993 NY Times “Francis Patrelle gives the traditional tale ingenious twists…the stories behind the stories.” YOUR IMPACTYour generous contribution to this project will allow us to honor and continue all parts of our mission, now and for years to come: 
 invigorating the exceptional art form of professional dance by presenting original works which synthesize movement, music, and drama in a ground breaking way.


developing the next generation, by providing an opportunity for students and young dancers to perform alongside the greatest artists of our time, sharing in mentoring relationships and exploring artistic depth. 


engaging diverse, underserved audiences through unique, intimate performances, at more accessible ticket prices.

Other Ways You Can HelpIf you can't donate at this time, you can still help! Please share this campaign with friends, family, and co-workers, via word of mouth and social media. Share our quick link on your Facebook page and Twitter accounts: igg.me/at/dancespatrelle-RJ2014 Also contact us for volunteer opportunities at director@dancespatrelle.org.

story:
Short Summary

  • My name is Shayleigh Sihlis, founder of Gasping Hands Theatre, and theatre arts student at Rosebud School of the Arts in Alberta, Canada. I'm also producing and performing in this show.
  • Rated RSO: The View From Here is a show putting together the evocative music and lyrics of Ryan Scott Oliver to tell my own story. It will be one-of-a-kind; a compiled journey of songs sewn into a story from impactful events in my life. It is about growing up, loss, and self-empowerment.
  • This show is my final project at Rosebud School of the Arts. A final project is self-produced and is a course that must be completed in order to graduate from the 4-year Theatre Arts Programme.

Playing August 29-30 on the outdoor stage by the Opera House in Rosebud, AB.

By contributing, you will help me complete my education at Rosebud School of the Arts.

What We Need & What You Get

  • Funding is needed to help compensate the amazing team, buy rights for the music, pay for equipment, market the show -- pretty much everything.
  • Available perks include shout outs on social media, a photoshoot, or a personalized sing-a-gram!
  • In the case we do not reach the complete goal, funds raised will be prioritized towards what will best allow the show to go on!

*Please note due to Covid-19 there will not be a "day in rehearsal" perk.

The Impact

  • This project is vital as a final stretch of my theatre training. If you love musical theatre or independent work, are passionate about female-powered stories, or want to tangibly support an emerging artist, you will make a difference with your contribution.
  • My goal as an artist is to use music and theatre to help people heal and grow from trauma. If this vision excites you, consider contributing.

Risks & Challenges

There are, of course, potential challenges along the way.

  • This is my first time officially producing something.
  • Covid-19 has been a challenge to work around, but I hope that as I had to postpone the original dates (in May), the flexibility displayed to ensure safety and care will allow this event to go on and be a safe and positive experience for all who attend.
  • I'm surrounded by a team and community who are helping me on this journey in immeasurable ways.

While ensuring precautions are in place with updates around the Covid-19 situation, I am dedicated to bringing this show to life when hope and joy is needed most. Your contribution will be essential!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate, there are other invaluable ways to support:

  • Simply share and tell others about this campaign and Rated RSO: The View from Here.
  • Get tickets to the show! (sales to be launched by August 8.)

Official Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/gaspinghandstheatre/

story:
What We're About

The Education Project is giving a voice to those who are involved in our educational system. The audience will be thrown for a loop by interview, dialogue, monologue, and personal experience coming from the students, parents, and teachers that witness the day-to-day battles. This is not a project that will simply bring more faults in our education to the surface, but instead it will shed a light on the answers we have found to the ultimate question, "What is 'getting an education?' "

What You Can Do

  • Make a choice. 
  • Help us out through your bank account.
  • Show up. 
  • Ask questions.
  • Answer questions.
  • Give us some more money..
  • Tell people about what we're doing. 
  • Start a conversation.
  • ...Keep giving us money.

story:
LET US TELL YOU A STORY


When actors Smith and Jones take on the seemingly innocuous roles of Hal and Hubble, respectively, the stage runs red with more than dramatic lighting. A totalitarian regime, eponymously named the Party, has run roughshod over the politics of the day, taking over the theaters while threatening the very fabric of life and artistic certainty. But is it just the nation's minds that are threatened? A black comedy by Tim Ginley SO2SPEAK pulls back the curtain on a deadly realm where art and politics collide, and body counts mount. Directed by the frenetic mind of Stewart Matthew (Die Zombie Die, Lonely Bear) this dark comedic journey is a movement piece that meets the Pinteresque toe to toe, never letting up until the final curtain cull is complete.

WHO WE ARE

S02SPEAK is the debut piece from an new theatre company in the Ottawa area, incite:LAB.  We have mandated ourselves as a new creation collective that intends on building a healthy competitive theatre community: one new play at a time. 

WHY SHOULD YOU HELP

Herein lies the importance of this campaign to me. My name is Tim Ginley and this is my company. I am a writer/actor/director impassioned by the creation of new and challenging theatre, but more than that I wish to create cohesion and  community among creative theatre practitioners. A successful show, with paid actors, director and stage manager and no debts to move forward brings my company one step closer to creating a community of creating individuals.

In light of economic realities and in the spirit of DIY theatre incite:LAB seeks merely the money required to pay for our stage and fees for our director and stage manager. Thereby increasing a net profits for the actors to share. 

    • $1000 will pay for the venue
    • $300 will pay the director and stage managers their nominal fee
    • $200 will pay for advertising and with that a company moves forward without debt.  

And a community gets stronger because one company has made good. Thanks to contributors like you. 

WHAT DO YOU GET

As a contributor to incite:LAB and the success of SO2SPEAK each kind and generous heart gets:

             * automatic membership to incite:LAB which will feature an emailed    newsletter and free admission to reading and draws for tickets to staged events

Seeing as anyone who has given to a new work collective must be interested in seeing new playwrights write contributors will be offered judging privileges at future readings and directed presentations. Further perks include

    • free tickets
    • invitation to all incite:LAB events
    • signed posters
    • good karma

But the reality of theatre is an expensive one. Should incite:LAB not makes its $1500 goal it shall then be left to move forward as all theatre does. Judge on the success of the piece itself, alone and the funds from the producers pocket will severely restrict the future.

WHAT DO WE GET

I have self produced plays before and while it is a labour of love, it is economically intensive. Shortfalls come out of the pocket, and failure wears away the ability to continue to create. Audience can only help so much. It is the one of the realities of the marketplace. And while I would love to brag of success after success, but as this is the first, I cannot. I do however believe it will be the first of many. Reaching out to the world makes the communal spirit of theatre more real, more palpable. Sadly not every one can get out to see what the world of theatre provides so contributing a few dollars helps to grow the world of creation.

TELL SOMEONE WHO CARES

And if you cannot help financially then tell those who can. Tell those interested in theatre that a company needs help to build a community of story tellers. Share with them our request and encourage them to give what they can to make small dreams into big realities.

AND THANKS SO MUCH FOR YOUR TIME.

Founder of incite:LAB

Tim Ginley

story:
Our Story

We are Bandwagon Productions - a small entertainment start-up founded by husband and wife team, Charlotte Cohn & Jason Odell Williams. This play, BALTIMORE IN BLACK AND WHITE, is our first production under Bandwagon, but we know it will not be our last. The play is an outrageously hilarious, laugh-out-loud comedy about racism, set against the backdrop of Baltimore, Maryland in 2007 and 1987. Eight actors play 17 different roles in a tapestry of scenes that focus on a Jewish girl and a black guy who reconnect after 20 years, date, fall in love, and get married. Their friends and family however are not all excited for the impending nuptials. The play deals with what you can and can't say when it comes to race and and how far we've come (and how far we haven't come) over the past 20 years. If you haven't already, we recommend watching the video above, and then visiting our website, www.baltimoreinblackandwhite.com.

The Impact

Your dollars will go directly into the production, specifically the rehearsal space, costume and actor budget. So if you'd like to see actors on stage with clothes on, please donate generously!


What We Need & What You Get

We had a free rehearsal space that fell through. And though we've been given an excellent deal, Manhattan is very expensive, so we need $2500 for rehearsal space, $1500 for costumes, and anything extra goes directly to our cast and crew who deserve way more than the tiny stipend they are getting for 6 weeks of their blood, sweat & tears.


Other Ways You Can Help

After you give, tell people about it! Facebook, Twitter, email, even the old word-of-mouth on the street works wonders! Get your friends excited, and they will give too and you can go to the theatre together and enjoy the fruits of your dollars.

story:
About the Campaign

The success of this $7000 goal will help support our partnership with the Vanport Mosaic Festival’s mission to involve and educate the community to ensure that this piece of Oregon history is not forgotten. COTTONWOOD IN THE FLOOD will act as a vehicle to join Vanport survivors, educators, students and community members, creating a platform for civic engagement to explore both the historical and present-day impacts of the city of Vanport on the social landscape of Portland.


"The Price of the Ticket"

The live theatrical arts afford a unique expression of the human condition.  Your $25 contribution, “The Price of the Ticket,” will help ensure that this production of Cottonwood in the Flood achieves its aim to enrich the lives of students and seniors across the city of Portland.

$7000 makes possible:

  • Free Private Matinee for Public Schools: Your donation will subsidize a free student-only matinee, to support the developing of Vanport-centered curriculum at Portland Public Schools, targeting Roosevelt, Jefferson, Madison and Grant High Schools

  • Community Outreach: Your donation will subsidize a community outreach plan to underserved schools, churches, and senior centers based in North/Northeast Portland that will encourage their participation in a source of entertainment that isn't normally afforded in their community.

  • Discounted Public Tickets for Seniors and Students: In addition to a free PPS student matinee, your donation will subsidize a significant percentage of heavily discounted ($5) tickets available to students and seniors at each public performance.

  • Public Panel Discussion and Talkbacks:

Your donation will subsidize post-matinee panels featuring former Vanport residents, historians, and educators to help us better understand the legacy of Vanport and its influence on the city of Portland today. Your donation will help underserved audiences bear witness to Oregon's link to the Great African American Migration of the 20th Century. People who were...

“...Seeking the warmth of other suns."-Richard Wright

About the Play

Playwright’s Notes

Cottonwood in the Flood was written as a tribute to the people of Vanport – for the work they did, for the lives they led and for the legacy they have left us. During the play’s several years of evolution, I have met and learned from many people, and I am indebted to each of them. I am grateful for their time and their wisdom, and rest assured that any inaccuracies or other flaws in this play are mine and not theirs. -- Rich Rubin

   Rich Rubin (Playwright)

 His plays have been produced throughout the U.S., and internationally in Europe, Asia, Australia, New Zealand, Canada and Mexico.  Institutional colleagues in the development and/or staging of his plays have included the American Bard Theater Company, Manhattan Theatre Works, Castillo Theatre, American Actors UK, Tristan Bates Theatre, UP Theatre Company, Athena Theatre Company, Stella Adler Studio of Acting, Long Beach Playhouse, Milwaukee Repertory Theater, Aston Rep Theatre Company, Rising Sage Theatre Company, Actors Theatre of Charlotte, Post5 Theatre, Portland Center Stage and the Utah Shakespeare Festival.  Rich’s work has been nominated for the L. Arnold Weissberger Award/Williamstown Theatre Festival, and has been selected as a co-winner of the Fratti-Newman Political Play Contest, the Neil Simon Festival New Play Contest and the Long Beach Playhouse New Works Festival. 

His plays have also been chosen as a finalist for the Julie Harris Playwright Award, Playwrights First Award, Ashland New Play Festival, Trustus Playwrights Festival, nuVoices Festival/Actors Theatre of Charlotte, Oregon Book Award, Heideman Award/Actors Theatre of Louisville, New American Play Project/Utah Shakespeare Festival and the Burbage Prize.  Rich is a proud member of the Dramatists Guild and Portland’s Nameless Playwrights and P-Town Playwrights -- www.richrubinplaywright.com.

 Damaris Webb (Director)

She is a performer, director and teaching artist who recently (re) relocated to Portland, OR after 26 years making and producing work in New York City. Ms. Webb holds her MFA from Naropa’s Contemporary Performance Program, and her BFA from NYU’s Experimental Theater Wing. Her original work is often seen in non-traditional performance venues such as late night parties, warehouses and church basements, it is sometimes epic and may involve zombies, superheroes or sock puppets.  The Oregonian calls her solo play The Box Marked Black “A look at race in a way that’s open-hearted and even-handed”.  She is a 2012, 2013 & 2015 Regional Arts & Culture Council grant recipient (The Box Marked Black: Tales of a Halfrican-American Growing up Mulatto. With sock puppets! and American King Umps: A Midsummer Night’s Melodrama on the Tragedy of Slavery, Cottonwood in the Flood).In Portland, she offers Contemplative Dance Practice through Be Space, is a coach for PlayWrite, Inc., and a teaching artist for The August Wilson Monologue Competition. www.DamarisWebb.com

COTTONWOOD IN THE FLOOD CAST


                Anthony Armstrong, Joe Gibson, S. Renee Mitchell, Theresa Park

Jeb Berrier, Seth Rue, Jocelyn Seid & Josiah Phillips* -- (Left to right from top)

  *AEA

pending

"Maybe the finest acting I've ever seen at  a stage reading..." Brett Campbell -Oregon Arts Watch  

"It's got  that very particular quality so often crowed about  in art, so rarely actually seen; Capital -I importance ..." Megan Burbank - The Portland Mercury

The History of Vanport


Vanport, between Portland and Vancouver, was built in 110 days in 1942 to accommodate the influx of wartime shipyard workers, becoming the second largest city of Oregon. At its peak, it was home to 40,000 people, including 6,000 African Americans, three times as many as had lived in all of Portland two years before. It was one of the first integrated communities in North America and its largest wartime public housing project. The town included a number of noteworthy institutions, such as K-12 schools, 24-hour day care, grocery stores, a health-care facility for shipyard workers, and the Vanport Extension Center, which became Portland State University.

On Memorial Day in 1948, a flood wiped out the entire city within a matter of hours, displacing 12,000 residents. This tragedy forced the overwhelmingly homogeneous city of Portland, and the state of Oregon, down the path toward interracial progress.

Today, Vanport is memorialized with only a few interpretive signs to mark what was once the second largest city in Oregon. During the dialogues following the screening of our short documentaries, people of all generations consistently say they were never taught this chapter of history. Those who have heard of it usually are only aware of the flood.  

  2016Vanport

Mosaic Festival

The Vanport Mosaic Festival is 4-day multi-disciplinary event that memorializes a unique sociological experiment that forever altered Oregon’s racial history. On the 68th anniversary of the Vanport Flood, Memorial Day Weekend 2016, the Festival will unite Portland area residents via historical and artistic tributes, including screenings of oral histories, a play, poetry, music, tours, educational and community dialogues, and exhibits of photos and artifacts. We will honor former Vanport residents with a reunion and archive their oral histories, photos, and artifacts.

We are a collective of storytellers, media makers, artists, historians, educators, long-term Portland residents and newcomers who seek to understand the construct of our social memory about this seemingly forgotten piece of Oregon history. -- www.vanportmosaic.org.

Partnerships & Grants

Special acknowledgements & Video Credits:

Thanks to everyone who gave their time, talent, and space, to create this project: Matt Boyer from Roosevelt High School; Chris Lane, Claire Wheeler, and Michael Meo of Grant High School; & Beatrice Gilmore.

Video Credits:

Produced by Meredith Lawrence
Staged Reading footage: Kate Szrom
Beatrice Gilmore Interview: Sommer Martin, Richard Percy, Jing Wong, James Burke
Historical Photos: City of Portland Archives, National Archives
Music: "John Stockton Slow Drag" by Chris Zabriskie (http://chriszabriskie.com)

Websites:

Vanport Mosaic Festival – http://vanportmosaic.org

WillaKenzie Estate - http://www.willakenzie.com

Oregon Heritage Commission – http://www.oregon.gov/OPRD/hcd/ohc/Pages/index.aspx

Multnomah County Cultural Coalition – http://multcoculturalcoalition.org

Regional Arts & Culture Council - http://www.culturaltrust.org

NAACP Portland Branch 1120 - http://www.portlandnaacp1120.org

Cultural Trust - http://www.culturaltrust.org

Arnold Weissberger Award/Williamstown Theatre Festival, and has been selected as a co-winner of the Fratti-Newman Political Play Contest, the Neil Simon Festival New Play Contest and the Long Beach Playhouse New Works Festival. His
plays have also been chosen as a finalist for the Julie Harris Playwright
Award, Playwrights First Award, Ashland New Play Festival, Trustus Playwrights
Festival, nuVoices Festival/Actors Theatre of Charlotte, Oregon Book Award,
Heideman Award/Actors Theatre of Louisville, New American Play Project/Utah
Shakespeare Festival and the Burbage Prize.  Rich is a proud member of the
Dramatists Guild and Portland’s Nameless Playwrights and P-Town Playwrights -- www.richrubinplaywright.com.
 Damaris Webb (Director) 

She is a performer,
director and teaching artist who recently (re) relocated to Portland, OR after
26 years making and producing work in New York City. Ms. Webb holds her MFA from
Naropa’s Contemporary Performance Program, and her BFA from NYU’s Experimental
Theater Wing. Her original work is often seen in non-traditional performance
venues such as late night parties, warehouses and church basements, it is
sometimes epic and may involve zombies, superheroes or sock puppets. 
The Oregonian calls her solo play The Box Marked Black “A look at
race in a way that’s open-hearted and even-handed”.  She is a 2012, 2013 & 2015 Regional Arts & Culture
Council grant recipient (The Box Marked
Black: Tales of a Halfrican-American Growing up Mulatto. With sock puppets!
and American King Umps: A Midsummer Night’s Melodrama on the Tragedy of
Slavery, Cottonwood in the Flood).In Portland, she offers Contemplative Dance
Practice through Be Space, is a coach for PlayWrite, Inc., and a teaching
artist for The August Wilson Monologue Competition. www.DamarisWebb.comCOTTONWOOD IN THE FLOOD CAST                 Anthony Armstrong, Joe Gibson, S. Renee Mitchell, Theresa ParkJeb Berrier, Seth Rue, Jocelyn Seid & Josiah Phillips* -- (Left to right from top)  *AEA pending 
"Maybe the finest acting I've ever seen at  a stage reading..." Brett Campbell -Oregon Arts Watch  
"It's got  that very particular quality so often crowed about  in art, so rarely actually seen; Capital -I importance ..." Megan Burbank - The Portland Mercury

















The History of Vanport
Vanport, between Portland and Vancouver, was built
in 110 days in 1942 to accommodate the influx of wartime shipyard workers,
becoming the second largest city of Oregon. At its peak, it was home to
40,000 people, including 6,000 African Americans, three times as many as had
lived in all of Portland two years before. It was one of the first integrated
communities in North America and its largest wartime public housing project.
The town included a number of noteworthy institutions, such as K-12 schools,
24-hour day care, grocery stores, a health-care facility for shipyard workers,
and the Vanport Extension Center, which became Portland State University. On Memorial Day
in 1948, a flood wiped out the entire city within a matter of hours, displacing
12,000 residents. This tragedy forced the overwhelmingly homogeneous city of
Portland, and the state of Oregon, down the path toward interracial progress.Today, Vanport
is memorialized with only a few interpretive signs to mark what was once the
second largest city in Oregon. During the dialogues following the screening of
our short documentaries, people of all generations consistently say they were
never taught this chapter of history. Those who have heard of it usually are
only aware of the flood.  
  2016VanportMosaic Festival 
The Vanport
Mosaic Festival is 4-day multi-disciplinary event that memorializes a unique
sociological experiment that forever altered Oregon’s racial history. On the
68th anniversary of the Vanport Flood, Memorial Day Weekend 2016, the Festival
will unite Portland area residents via historical and artistic tributes,
including screenings of oral histories, a play, poetry, music, tours,
educational and community dialogues, and exhibits of photos and artifacts. We
will honor former Vanport residents with a reunion and archive their oral
histories, photos, and artifacts.
We are a collective of storytellers, media makers,
artists, historians, educators, long-term Portland residents and newcomers who
seek to understand the construct of our social memory about this seemingly forgotten
piece of Oregon history. -- www.vanportmosaic.org.
Partnerships & Grants 
Special acknowledgements & Video Credits:Thanks to everyone who gave their time, talent, and space, to create this project: Matt Boyer from Roosevelt High School; Chris Lane, Claire Wheeler, and Michael Meo of Grant High School; & Beatrice Gilmore.

Video Credits:
Produced by Meredith Lawrence
Staged Reading footage: Kate Szrom
Beatrice Gilmore Interview: Sommer Martin, Richard Percy, Jing Wong, James
Burke
Historical Photos: City of Portland Archives, National Archives
Music: "John Stockton Slow Drag" by Chris Zabriskie (http://chriszabriskie.com)Websites: Vanport Mosaic Festival – http://vanportmosaic.org
WillaKenzie Estate - http://www.willakenzie.com
Oregon Heritage Commission – http://www.oregon.gov/OPRD/hcd/ohc/Pages/index.aspx
Multnomah County Cultural Coalition – http://multcoculturalcoalition.org
Regional Arts & Culture Council - http://www.culturaltrust.org
NAACP Portland Branch 1120 - http://www.portlandnaacp1120.org
Cultural Trust - http://www.culturaltrust.org

story:
Hi, my name is Adam Seid Tahir and I am living in Stockholm, Sweden. I am 19 years old and I started dancing when I was seven. At the time I danced a lot of Hiphop, but while getting older I started to explore other stiles as Jazz, Ballet and later Contemporary. This, little by little, led to me deciding that this was what I wanted to do with my life. Currently I am studying at The Royal Swedish Balletschool in the contemporary section. I am now in my third and also last year, which means that I have to audition this spring for further education or hopefully a start in the professional life as a dancer. Since I have to go abroad to audition, costs will get pretty high. And since I don't come from a wealthy family I need to raise all the money on my own. 

                                                                                                    

My passion

It isn't that I like to dance, although I do. It isn't that I love to dance, although I really do. It isn't even that I crave to dance everyday, although I actually really do. It is simply that I need  to dance every single day for the rest of my life. Dancing is what makes me, me. Without dancing I can't exist.

For me dance is a way of expressing my thoughts and feelings. It is a free space where I can step out from my everyday-life and just be here and now. I love moving, it makes me happy, and it is my own meditation and medicine. Even though I am not sick in any way, I desperately need this medicine every day for the rest of my life.

  


What I want with my dancing

My dream is to some day be able to work as a professional dancer. Hopefully to get the chance to work in a dance company. My dream is simply to be able to dance for the rest of my life, which means that I have to be able to make the barest minimum of a living out of it. My hopes for the closest future is to get admitted to a danceschool or a junior company if I am lucky. This would mean that I would be so much closer to reaching my dream.


How am I going to use the money

The costs for being able to audition is flights, accommodation, food and sometimes an audition fee. Here are some of the places I want to audition to and the estimated cost:

Junior Ballet de Geneve 

(The audition is during two days in Switzerland)

Flights: 150 euro
Accommodation: 180 euro
Food: 40 euro

Juilliard

(The audition is during two days in New York)

Flights: 500 euro
Accomodation: 200 euro
Food: 40 euro
Audition fee: 60 euro

Codarts

(The audition is during four days in the Netherlands)

Flights: 140 euro
Accomodation: 170 euro
Food: 75 euro
Audition fee: 50 euro

SEAD

(The audition is just one day in Austria)

Flights: 140 euro
Accomodation: 100 euro
Food: 30 euro
Audition fee: 25 euro

Dantzaz Konpainia 

(The audition is just one day in San Sebastian)

Flights: 340 euro
Accomodation: 70 euro
Food: 30 euro

The costs of these auditions are already over my goal of 2000 euros so I would actually need a lot more than that. But being able to get 2000 euros would mean that I at least could audition to the most important ones. Other places I also really would love to audition to is; IT-dansa, Staatstheater Wiesbaden, Skånes Dansteater, Carte Blanche and Netherlands Dans Theater with many others... Since you really can't be sure of getting your first or second or even third audition I have to try out for many different places to even have a chance.

Contact

If you have any questions or tips or anything you want to tell me please use this email address: adam.seidtahir@hotmail.com

Please help me in my pursuit of becoming a dancer. I will always be thankful for any kind of support!

Thank you

story:
Who and Why:

We are Faction of Fools Theatre Company, a Commedia dell'Arte theatre company located in Washington, DC.

We are producing Shakespeare's bloodiest play, TITUS ANDRONICUS, by combining a tragi-comic genre from the 16th Century with the blood effects technology of the 21st. Think the lopped limbs, squirting stumps, arrows, swords, and rolling heads of Saw or Hostel, combined with Shakespeare's text, and the acrobatics, masks, and spectacular physical comedy of Commedia dell'Arte.

You probably already know that making theater is expensive. Our ticket price is only $25.00.  And to spread blood all over the stage and actors every night (and to clean it up) is a big additional expense: at least $1500 just for the blood.

What We Need:

FILL THE BLOOD BANK!

The play isn't a joke, but it's too absurd to stomach as a straight drama.  Our goal is to present the absurdity of violence in comedic proportions.  To do this, we need:

  • Blood that squirts, oozes, and smears.
  • Blood that is eaten, washed out of costumes, and splattered on windows.
  • Blood that can be rigged to accommodate acrobatics! Did I mention that some of the limb-lopping happens while people are airborne? 

We are staging ALL of Shakespeare's violence. For example, when Titus' sons kill the prince of the Goths in Act 1 Scene 1, setting off the cycle of revenge: "Let's hew his limbs til they be clean consumed" is usually performed off-stage.  The first time we tried it on-stage in rehearsal, no one in the room could stop laughing. 

The Washington City Paper called our Romeo and Juliet  "ingenius" and "splendidly physical."  The Washington Post said of our adaptation of Hamlet, "an intriguing current of seriousness courses through Hamlecchino: Clown Prince of Denmark."  Your contributions can help us apply the same unique brand of physical comedy to Titus Andronicus. 

What You Get:

  • Tickets to the show!
  • Eat pie with a company member before the performance!
  • We'll even fabricate a death for you on stage during one of the performances! (That's a special privilege for our $1,000 contributors.)
  • And other cool perks - check out the list!

Director Matthew R. Wilson has imagined the world of TITUS ANDRONICUS  in a pristinely clean capital, a Rome whose people leave war outside the city limits. On a gleaming white Scenic Design by Ethan Sinnott and Costumes by Denise Umland, the bloody violence unfolds in Blood Effects by local goremeister Casey Kaleba and Fights Choreographed by Kaleba and Wilson. The versatile ensemble includes Nello DeBlasio in the title role, with Cori Dioquino, Daniel Flint, Christina Marie Frank, Tyler Herman, Manu Kumasi, Toby Mulford, Matthew Pauli and Chema Pineda-Fernández, along with Gallaudet University seniors Miranda Medugno and Charlie Ainsworth.

Performances are May 29 - June 22, in the Eastman Studio Theatre at Gallaudet University (Thu, Fri, Sat at 8pm / Sun at 2pm). 

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that not everyone can contribute funds.  You can still help us out in a very important way:

  • If you enjoyed the video, share it with your friends: http://youtu.be/HOeFQOAKxQw

  • If you are excited about Titus Andronicus, tell your friends on Facebook and Twitter using the share tools below.

Your contribution means a lot to us. Most importantly, we want you to see the fruits of your contribution, to share in our artistic discoveries, to laugh as hard as your guts can take. We hope to see you at the show...

...for some bloody good fun.

story:
43 performances // 24 ensembles // 15 days

“FURY Factory redefines live theater.” San Francisco Arts Monthly.

Inspired by New York festivals such as the ones hosted by PS122, HERE, and Under the Radar, the FURY Factory is the only event of its kind in the Bay Area. 

For two jam-packed weeks in July, 24 innovative theater companies from all over the country will converge in San Francisco’s Mission District to create an outpouring of performance, artistic exchange, cross pollination, panel discussions, and training events open to everyone -- but we simply cannot do it without your help.

What We Need // Where The Funds Will Go

In order to bring these amazing artists and all of their energy to the Bay Area, a meeting ground must be provided. The FURY Factory is the only festival of its kind in the Bay Area, and this is an event about artists and community coming together in one place for a national dialogue.

Providing the space for all these artists to perform in is no small feat, and with big spaces come big costs. The funds we are seeking to raise will pay for the rental of the 3 festival venues, and provide an amazing canvas for the participating artists to come play on.

Help us bring these wonderful, innovative and creative companies to the audiences of the Bay Area!

We need to raise at least $10,000 by July 6 to be make this festival possible.

If you can't make a donation at this time, there are many other ways to contribute to this campaign which are just as helpful! 

* Email the link to this campaign, and information about the festival, to friends, family, colleagues, etc.
* Post the campaign link to your Facebook page, Twitter feed or other social media.
* Come see the work! There are so many shows to see, people to meet, and discussions to have; your presence is important to us!

The Shows // Your Impact

Your donation will help fund the performance venues for the festival, without which this event would be impossible. You are bringing fantastic works to the Bay Area with your donation. You can find the full schedule and descriptions of all the shows here!

The Submarine Show (Oakland) - The Submarine Show

Two men crash their submarine on bottom of the sea, then swim, fly and go insane in a madcap journey from the ocean to the sky and back.

Dandelion Dancetheater (San Francisco) - Tongues and Gather (world premiere)

Life and death come to us all. Sam Shepard and Jospeh Chaiken are interpreted by Bay Area favorite Dandelion Dancetheater.

Under the Table (Brooklyn and San Francisco) - The Hunchbacks of Notre Dame

The Hunchinson Family Players, a theater troupe of hunchbacked siblings, hope to turn their luck around with an adaptation of Hugo's classic novel.

Post Natyam Collective (Transnational) - Super Ruwaxi: Origins

See theater, multimedia, and contemporary Indian dance, mashed together to create a live comic-book story about queerness, coming of age, and the immigrant experience.

Teatro Luna (Chicago) - Generation Sex

In Generation Sex the ladies of El Teatro Luna, Chicago’s all-Latina theater, bare all without blushing as they explore how technology has transformed sex, love, and relationships.

Plus new works by:

Antic in a Drain (SF) // Bad Unkl Sista (SF) // Danielle Deadwyler (Atlanta, GA) // Deborah Slater Dance Theater (SF) // Dzieci (New York) // The Defenestrators (SF) // Epic Frame (New York) // Estela Garcia (Los Angeles) // foolsFURY (SF) // Killing My Lobster (SF) // Hungry Bird Theatre (Oakland) // The Illuminated Theater (SF) // The Imaginists (Santa Rosa) // Theatre Plastique (Brooklyn) // Ragged Wing (Oakland) // the real kim harmon (New York) // WaxFactory (New York)


***UPDATE***

Our perks have been made even perkier! All donations at the $50 level or above now include an invitation to our Sweet Sixteen Kickoff & Donor Appreciation Party on Sunday, July 13 from 3pm-5pm. This update will apply retroactively, so if you've already donated, don't worry - you're already on the guest list. We look forward to thanking YOU in person!

***UPDATE PART DEUX***
ALL contributions to the campaign are tax deductible! You will receive a tax receipt for your contribution at the end of the campaign. If you need it sooner or you'd like to donate anonymously, please contact us and we can work something out! Woohoo!

story:
**Campaign Countdown- Added Perk!

Donate at the $200 level for a custom half-day Shakespeare workshop for 5-30 people with director Scott Emerson Moyle! (Three available- GTA only)**

Headstrong Collective, in association with Urban Bard, is presenting the site-specific Romeo and (her) Juliet, featuring a female Romeo and Juliet living in contemporary Toronto. Most recently, Headstrong Collective produced the critically acclaimed one-person show Licking Knives in the 2014 Toronto Fringe Festival. Urban Bard, "Toronto's coolest classical company", has been producing exciting and accessible Shakespeare since 2009. Our smash hit Drunk Macbeth played to sold-out audiences in November 2013 and January 2014 at the iconic Tranzac Club.

With your help, Headstrong Collective and Urban Bard will create exciting new opportunities for female and female-identified, culturally diverse, and LGBTQ performers and audiences in the world of classical performance.

What We Need & What You Get

We are asking for $3000 to help us pay for rehearsal and performance space, the largest cost in our production budget.

  • $1000 for three weeks of rehearsal space and tech time
  • $2000 for nine performances at the Bloor Street United Church in Toronto

Donate $25 and you’ve given us 2 hours of rehearsal. Donate $250 and you’ve given us a performance!

Perks include acknowledgement on the Romeo and (her) Juliet website, private stage combat training with our incredible Fight Director Siobhan Richardson, a copy of the debut cd from Toronto's folk darlings Birds of Bellwoods, or your own beautiful mask to wear when you see the show and attend the Capulets ball!

This is an all-or-nothing campaign; if we don't reach our goal, our production will not receive your contribution, so please spread the word!

The Impact

Female/female-identified performers and queer stories are often overlooked in classical performance. This is a unique opportunity to see a familiar story in a new and timely light. Many queer youth face harassment, bullying, and suicide. Our production will specifically address the role of the community in the protection and care of our youth.

We take accessibility to heart. Urban Bard aims to be accessible economically with reasonable ticket prices for performances in indoor spaces and accepting pay-what-you-can donations for performances in outdoor spaces. We choose performance spaces in areas close to transit and easily accessed by pedestrians and cyclists. In addition, our performance venue is fully accessible to those with physical disabilities.

Risks & Challenges

Producing independent theatre is no easy task. This production is an artists’ collective, which means that the artists will share in the profits from the production. We are seeking corporate donations and selling advertisements in our program to fund the remainder of our production budget. We are also very grateful to our supporters and volunteers so far!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't able to contribute, please consider sharing this campaign via email, Twitter (#RandJTO) or Facebook.

And come to the show! Our preview performance on Wednesday September 3rd  is Pay-What-You-Can (PWYC) with a suggested donation of $10.
story_txt:
**Campaign Countdown- Added Perk!Donate at the $200 level for a custom half-day Shakespeare workshop for 5-30 people with director Scott Emerson Moyle! (Three available- GTA only)**Headstrong Collective, in association with Urban Bard, is presenting the site-specific Romeo and (her) Juliet, featuring a female Romeo and Juliet living in contemporary Toronto. Most recently, Headstrong Collective produced the critically acclaimed one-person show Licking Knives in the 2014 Toronto Fringe Festival. Urban Bard, "Toronto's coolest classical company", has been producing exciting and accessible Shakespeare since 2009. Our smash hit Drunk Macbeth played to sold-out audiences in November 2013 and January 2014 at the iconic Tranzac Club.

With your help, Headstrong Collective and Urban Bard will create exciting new opportunities for female and female-identified, culturally diverse, and LGBTQ performers and audiences in the world of classical performance.What We Need & What You Get

We are asking for $3000 to help us pay for rehearsal and performance space, the largest cost in our production budget.


$1000 for three weeks of rehearsal space and tech time

$2000 for nine performances at the Bloor Street United Church in Toronto


Donate $25 and you’ve given us 2 hours of rehearsal. Donate $250 and you’ve given us a performance!

Perks include acknowledgement on the Romeo and (her) Juliet website, private stage combat training with our incredible Fight Director Siobhan Richardson, a copy of the debut cd from Toronto's folk darlings Birds of Bellwoods, or your own beautiful mask to wear when you see the show and attend the Capulets ball!
This is an all-or-nothing campaign; if we don't reach our goal, our production will not receive your contribution, so please spread the word!

The Impact

Female/female-identified performers and queer stories are often overlooked in classical performance. This is a unique opportunity to see a familiar story in a new and timely light. Many queer youth face harassment, bullying, and suicide. Our production will specifically address the role of the community in the protection and care of our youth.

We take accessibility to heart. Urban Bard aims to be accessible economically with reasonable ticket prices for performances in indoor spaces and accepting pay-what-you-can donations for performances in outdoor spaces. We choose performance spaces in areas close to transit and easily accessed by pedestrians and cyclists. In addition, our performance venue is fully accessible to those with physical disabilities.

Risks & Challenges

Producing independent theatre is no easy task. This production is an artists’ collective, which means that the artists will share in the profits from the production. We are seeking corporate donations and selling advertisements in our program to fund the remainder of our production budget. We are also very grateful to our supporters and volunteers so far!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't able to contribute, please consider sharing this campaign via email, Twitter (#RandJTO) or Facebook.
And come to the show! Our preview performance on Wednesday September 3rd  is Pay-What-You-Can (PWYC) with a suggested donation of $10.

story:
Pour faire un don, c'est par ici!


LAB87 a besoin de vous!

Chers amis, LAB87 a besoin de votre aide.

Du 11 au 29 novembre prochain, la compagnie présentera TRIBUS, une pièce de l'auteure anglaise Nina Raine qui fait le tour du monde depuis sa création au Royal Court de Londres, en 2010. La pièce sera présentée au Théâtre La Licorne, en co-diffusion avec La Manufacture.


Pourquoi une campagne de financement?

Malgré une forte recommandation du jury, nous n'avons reçu aucune subvention de la part du Conseil des Arts du Canada. Cette aide financière s'avérait cruciale pour la production de cette pièce. Un changement dans le mode de fonctionnement du Conseil des Arts et Lettres du Québec nous place également dans une situation problématique, puisque notre demande de subvention ne sera analysée qu'en décembre prochain, soit après la production. Certains projets peuvent survivre sans subventions - nous l'avons prouvé avec L'obsession de la beauté et Les flâneurs célestes - mais Tribus ne fait malheureusement pas partie de cette catégorie. L'absence de subventions dans une salle comme la Grande Licorne menace non seulement la survie de LAB87, mais également celle des artistes qui la portent, qui pourraient devoir engouffrer une somme importante pour palier au manque de fonds.


Comment seront utilisés les dons?

La pièce Tribus pose un regard nouveau sur la réalité des jeunes Sourds d'aujourd'hui. Nous souhaitons qu'ils puissent voir ce spectacle, qui parle d'eux et qui s'adresse également à eux. Voici comment seront utilisés les dons.

  • Location de deux projecteurs de surtitres.
  • Embauche d'interprètes en LSQ pour une représentation spéciale.
  • Frais de formation en LSQ pour deux membres de la distribution.
  • Décors et costumes.
  • Location de locaux de répétition.
  • Publicité.

N.B. Les dons ne serviront pas à payer les membres de l'équipe. Comme nous ne sommes pas subventionnés, nous fonctionnerons en partage de recettes, c'est-à-dire que nous nous partagerons un pourcentage des revenus issus de la vente de billets.


À propos de Tribus

Billy est sourd de naissance. Ses parents ne lui ont jamais permis d'apprendre le langage des signes, de peur qu'il s'isole au sein de la communauté sourde et malentendante. Sa rencontre avec Sylvia, une malentendante en voie de devenir sourde, bouleversera son existence et éveillera en lui un désir d'expression par le langage des signes. Cet épanouissement soudain déstabilisera la cellule familiale et exacerbera des travers peu reluisants de sa personnalité.

Tribus est une pièce sur la communication et les subtilités du langage. L’auteure Nina Raine nous démontre avec cette oeuvre que le vocabulaire

traditionnel est un outil de communication imparfait, un mot n'ayant jamais exactement la même signification d'une personne à une autre. Ainsi, les mots peuvent servir de perches comme de remparts. Ce texte aborde également la question de l'éducation d'un enfant né avec un handicap.


L'équipe de Tribus

  • Texte: Nina Raine
  • Mise en scène: Frédéric Blanchette
  • Assistance à la mise en scène et traduction: Jean-Simon Traversy
  • Distribution: Catherine Chabot, Benoît Drouin-Germain, David Laurin, Jacques L'Heureux, Monique Spaziani et Klervi Thienpont.
  • Décors et costumes: Elen Ewing
  • Éclairages: André Rioux
  • Direction technique: David Poisson


Qui est LAB87?

LAB87 est né du désir d’établir un pont durable avec la dramaturgie anglo-saxonne émergente. Notre mandat premier est de produire et de diffuser un théâtre contemporain innovateur et accessible. Pour ce faire, nous cherchons à collaborer avec des auteurs dangereusement actuels. Nos membres aspirent à rejoindre et à développer un public formé de gens qui n’ont pas l’habitude d’aller au théâtre. Nous souhaitons ainsi mener la vie dure à tous les médias sociaux et autres plateformes de divertissement issues de notre génération. Chaque année, notre comité de lecture est appelé à se prononcer sur près d’une centaine d‘oeuvres dramatiques contemporaines, et à soumettre des projets de création qui soient conformes à nos exigences artistiques.

En 2009, David Laurin, Mathieu Quesnel, Jean-Simon Traversy et François-Simon Poirier fondent LAB87. Au cours de sa première année d’existence, la compagnie établit des contacts fructueux avec six jeunes auteurs québécois et donne naissance au projet Nos Bras Meurtris, présenté dans le cadre du Festival du Jamais Lu, à Montréal. En 2012, après deux ans de préparation, elle produit L'obsession de la beauté, le plus récent succès de l’américain Neil LaBute. Cette pièce, mise en scène scène par Frédéric Blanchette, est présentée 28 fois à guichets fermés à La Petite Licorne. La saison suivante, LAB87 revient à la charge avec Les Flâneurs célestes, de la jeune américaine Annie Baker, récipiendaire du Prix Pulitzer 2014 en écriture dramatique. Mise en scène par Jean-Simon Traversy, la pièce est chaudement accueillie par la critique.

L'impact du projet

L'impact de ce projet pour la communauté Sourde montréalaise sera fort et immédiat. Non seulement on parlera d'eux dans la population et les médias, mais on leur permettra de voir du théâtre et de s'identifier à des personnages, chance qu'ils n'ont que trop rarement. Cette sortie au théâtre leur permettra de découvrir un monde auquel ils n'ont jamais accès et d'entrer en contact avec des entendants qui auront été sensibilisés à leur situation.


Lancer un message au CAC

Les productions présentées dans la grande salle du Théâtre La Licorne sont presque toujours subventionnées. Cette fois-ci, pour une raison que l'on ignore, le Conseil des Arts du Canada a décidé de ne pas cautionner le choix de la direction artistique de La Licorne. Comme jeune compagnie, nous n'avons pas les reins assez solides pour mener à terme une production aussi complexe sans recevoir d'appuis. Sans l'aide de généreux donateurs, LAB87 sera contraint de fermer ses portes. Si nous passons à travers la tempête grâce à votre aide, cela enverra un message clair au Conseil des Arts du Canada, qui devra revoir sa position sur notre travail.


D'autres manières de nous aider

La contribution financière n'est qu'une façon de nous venir en aide. Vous pouvez vous impliquer de plusieurs manières:

  • Parlez de Tribus à vos proches et à vos amis.
  • Aidez-nous dans la distribution de dépliants et la pose d'affiches.
  • Devenez bénévole pour notre soirée bénéfice, en octobre prochain.
  • Si vous êtes avancé en LSQ, venez nous aider en répétition.
  • Si vous êtes orthophoniste et que vous travaillez régulièrement avec des Sourds, venez nous aider en répétition.

Vous avez du temps à donner?

Faites-nous signe: dlaurin@lab87.org

story:
Who We Are...

My name is Rainey Rowan and I am helping produce a new short play written by Alex Krasser with direction by Glenn Giron, an up and coming director here in NYC. The production is an original one-​act play called Waiting for the G in which Trey and Quint are on their way to an important job interview and waiting for a train that may or may not show up. As they are emotionally and physically worn down by circumstance and eccentric subway denizens, they struggle to find some sense of control, pushing their sanity and friendship to the brink.. This ​one-act is being produced at The Hudson Guild Theater as part of their NY WinterFest in January starring, Lori Bodinizzo, Eric Cotti, Sean Evans, Michael Maricondi, and Chase Slovak and WE NEED YOUR HELP to make it happen!  

What We Need...

We have set a goal of $2500 for our production costs and artists fees, which include:

  • Artists Fees
  • Scenic Elements (like a REAL SUBWAY BENCH)
  • Props (like a REAL PHONE BOOTH)
  • Rehearsal Space
  • A HAND DRAWN Program

If we don't reach our entire goal, we will divide the funds up evenly, with special regard to the needs of our artists, first and foremost.

Impact, Risks & Challenges...

Our biggest aim is to pay our creative team. Yes, having a fabulous set and ahmazing props is important, but it's invaluable to the integrity of our actors, scenic designer, sound designer, and the rest of our team to pay them for their artistry, effort and time. It is our utmost priority and our biggest challenge. We would like to set a high standard as an emerging production team, in an industry that oftentimes does not pay artists what they are owed. It is a challenge, but one we are ready to face head on.

Other Ways You Can Help...

If you can't monetarily contribute, that's okay! We get it, we are all starving artists to different degrees (at least metaphorically, eh?) BUT, that doesn't mean you can't help... you could:

  • Share our campaign on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, Snapchat, ALL dating sites, and Gypsy Housing (May have been kidding about the last two, but maybe not!)
  • Talk about our campaign with your friends, family, co-workers, cab drivers, subway man-spreaders, and ex-best friends.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools! It's super user friendly.
  • And, of course, come see the show!

Show Info...

Three performances at The Hudson Guild Theater

January 15th at 6:15PM, January 19th at 9:00PM, and January 21st at 3:30PM

Click here to purchase tickets

New theater cannot be produced without the generosity of our artistic family and community, whether it be financially or not. We are all in this together and are more grateful than an Indiegogo campaign has characters for. (Seriously, there's not a lot)

Thank you, thank you, THANK YOU.

story:
“We are a diverse theatre for the world as we see it, producing new and contemporary plays that explore the social, political and cultural issues within our communities.”

Gabriela Sanchez– Founder and Executive Director

Synopsis 

Morir Sonyando is a play about family and the grace we must choose to bestow on one another every day to keep alive.

“The first hit tears your skin and makes you bleed. It feels like the world has turned to spinning stars. But after that, you don’t feel much more.” 

Genesis, an academic working her way through an Ivy League education, is proud of the fact that she’s survived her family’s dysfunction, if only just barely. But when her estranged mother, Paloma, is released from prison after a decade of incarceration, Genesis is forced to confront her involvement in the imprisonment and the life from which she has done her best to escape. 

Photo - Genesis (Erlina Ortiz), Paloma (Gabriela Sanchez) and Felix (Anthony Davila)    

Photo - Genesis (Erlina Ortiz), Paloma (Gabriela Sanchez)

What We Need 

Domestic violence continues to be a pressing issue in our society; our call to action as artists and activists is to empower Philadelphia communities and beyond. Recently, Power Street received the Creative PHL Performance in Public Spaces grant to perform Morir Sonyando at Fair Hill Square Park (4th & Lehigh) on Saturday, May 16th at 7:30pm. This event will be free to the public! 

Power Street believes in giving back, at this performance we will be collecting donations for our partnered organization Women In Transition (WIT), however, these donations will not be tax deductible. 

We are seeking financial support to offset costs for technical equipment for this specific production and to help continue the future touring of this universal play to high schools, universities, libraries, community centers, parks and recreations; wherever we can spread our message! Your generous contribution will support awareness on Domestic Violence and help Philadelphia neighborhoods experience Morir Sonyando’s powerful message. All donations are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

Expenses:

Projection: rear projector, table mount, rear projector screen

Cables: HDMI, mac adapter connector, and computer audio cables. 

Dividers: fabric 

This is why we need your help!


Get to know us 

Power Street Theatre Company (PSTC) is an ensemble-based theater company composed of culturally conscious theater artists collaborating to create new work that explores social issues. The company aims to be a catalyst for cultural outreach and understanding within Philadelphia and beyond. 

Power Street Theatre Company and Women in Transition (WIT) are partnering in bringing to diverse public spaces around the US the play Morir Sonyando: Die Dreaming, written by Erlina Ortiz. The play premiered this past fall part of the 2014 FringeArts Festival in Philadelphia and made local headlines as Philadelphia City Paper’s 15 must-see shows. “In our play Morir Sonyando, we will follow, in a non-linear structure, the past, present and future of three family members (mother, daughter and son) that had their lives changed because of an act of despair that would destroy everything” – Thais Flaitt Giannoccaro, director. More than mere entertainment, this production aims to heighten consciousness around the issue of domestic violence, by exposing and engaging local audience members on this urgent topic.

Each performance of Morir Sonyando is followed by insightful talkbacks with the cast and audience. For many audience members who can identify with the experiences of the characters in the play, these talk backs create a space for breaking silence. It is as if a sense of community is formed around the realization that survivors of domestic violence are not alone; their voices matter! Power Street is thrilled to collaborate with WIT, a Philadelphian organization that empowers survivors through counseling, referrals and advocacy. WIT's expert team of professional advocates will mediate our talkbacks and distribute literature about the topic of domestic and intimate partner violence. 

Power Street Theatre Company strongly believes in providing affordable access to the arts and raising domestic violence awareness around diverse issues that are relevant in many communities.  “We hope that for every person who sees our play there is one less person who must suffer at the hands of someone who is supposed to love them. We hope that for every person who sees our play there is one more person who has found their voice.”- Erlina Ortiz, playwright. 

Photo – from the documentary Sin by Silence    

The Impact 

By donating to Power Street you become apart of a movement that empowers and educates communities at large!

Quiara Alegria Hudes, recipient of the 2012 Pulitzer Prize for Drama wrote a public letter to the company and said: "What more could we possibly hope for in the future of American theatre? We need groups like this to keep going--to create more art and joy and hold our face to the flame. This is theater that is urgent, necessary, and beautiful. Growing up in West Philly, with much family in North Philly, I had no idea theater existed in Philadelphia. Theaters didn’t put up posters in our neighborhood. Theater wasn’t “for us.” We weren’t invited to the table. Power Street is building a new table. One Philly--and this nation--desperately needs."

Power Street aims to foster and share more theatrical works from our multi-diverse minority group of artists, outreaching minority communities throughout the US and the world, for many years to come! 

Testimonials 

“Morir Sonyando, Power Street’s most recent production puts a focus squarely on a topic that is both universal and incredibly personal to our community. Morir Sonyando looks at the very complicated subject of domestic violence seen through the lens of a Latino family. Along its heartbreaking journey Morir Sonyando investigates incarceration, substance abuse, immigration, hope and the irrevocable damage that the silence surrounding domestic violence often breeds. We watch a family, full of love and expectation, crumble and rebuild itself after a lifetime of violence leads to one choice that changes everything. Unlike so many other works on this topic there are no sinners or saints here. Each character is a beautifully drawn image of a mother, a daughter, a father, a son, complicated and shaped by the limitations and dreams that too often accompany being Latino in the United States. The play’s blending of culture, taboos, healing, and questions about what it means to be loving and free open up such an important dialogue about domestic violence in an attempt to look at it as a symptom of larger problems - like painful immigrations practices and incarceration that overwhelmingly punishes people of color - that plague so many American cities today.”

Tamanya Garza Director, Producer and Digital Marketing Specialist President of the Board of Directors, Azuka Theatre 

“The opportunity to attend Morir Sonyando was incredible for our students from Olney Charter High School. The students had never seen a play performed live, and it exposed them to a new area of art. Several of the students who came are English Language Learners who are emergent bilinguals. Seeing a play performed in Spanish and English was eye-opening for them--they expressed excitement about seeing a professional play performed in multiple languages. The subject matter was also compelling. Immediately after the play, students started talking about their own experiences witnessing domestic violence. Seeing professional actors take this subject matter seriously opened the door for them to see their own experiences as part of larger structural issues, and allowed them to share with each other. They left the theater feeling bigger and seeing themselves as the tellers of stories. Seeing my students react so enthusiastically to the play also inspired me as their teacher. It gave me ideas about how to lead our unit on Theater of the Oppressed and what topics would be of interest to students. I look forward to how students who saw the performance will be able to use what they learned to bring their own experiences and ideas into the limelight to share important topics with others.” 

Elizabeth Logue – Professor Olney Charter High School 

Photo- Morir Sonyando, Domestic Violence Awareness Month (student matinee)

Our History 

Power Street premiered its first production, MinorityLand, at Taller Puertorriqueño for the 2013 Philly Fringe Festival, followed by a production at the University of Pennsylvania for the Festival Latino. Power Street ensemble tackles what it means to be a minority, what it means to be a community, and just how deeply our words and actions can affect those around us. When the local university begins buying up houses in an integrated black and latino community, residents are pushed out, and the very fabric of the community is ripped apart. MinorityLand attracted to North Philly more than 500 people through its 2 weeks run.

Photo - MinorityLand Reading, University of Pennsylvania 

In the spring of 2014, Power Street joined forces nationally with NoPassport, in collaboration with Dominic D'Andrea (Producing Artistic Director, The One-Minute Play Festival, #1MPF), and locally with the Philadelphia New Play Initiative, the Directors Gathering, Plays & Players, and Tamanya Garza to produce 30/30/1, a day of celebration of new plays by US Latina/o playwrights. Throughout out a still cold Saturday in Philadelphia a group of more than 50 theatre artists gathered at Play & Players Theatre to read and discuss US Latina/o plays and the day culminated on a panel and a stage reading of Learn to be a Latina by Enrique Urueta. With the success of this day event in June the companies hosted three more stage readings (To Catch the Lightning by Carmen Rivera, El Nogalar by Tanya Saracho, and Dark Matters by Oliver Mayer), bringing the Latino/a theater to Central Philly community.

Photo- 30/30/1: Philadelphia Celebrates Latina/o Playwrights  


Morir Sonyando is the company’s second full production, proven that this young company is here to stay. Matching its audience outreach expectations the play was listed among the 15 must-see Fringe shows by the Philadelphia City Paper, in addition performed at Temple University for Lambda Theta Alpha Sorority Inc's Founders Week. Power Street was also nominated to the 2014 Hispanic Choice Awards for The Vision Award, presented to the artist, or group of artists, who use visual, musical and/or performing arts, to inspire positive change in the lives of others. 

Photo- Morir Sonyando, Temple University, Women Against Abuse advocates

Other Ways You Can Help

If you’re interested in helping but don’t not have the financial means:

  • Join us for the outdoor premiere of Morir Sonyando at Fair Hill Square Park (4th & Leigh) on Saturday, May 16th at 7:30pm. This event will be free to the public. Help us spread the word!
  • Let your friends know about Power Street Theatre Company and have them make some noise about it on their favorite social media platform. Hash tag: 

    #powerstreetontour #itsonus #morirsonyandooutdoors #domesticviolenceawareness #Whyistayed #Whyileft #breakthesilence #indiegogoPST#breakthecycle #WIT 

  • Make use of the Indiegogo share tools!

    Power Street Theater Company is deeply grateful to all who support our vision.

    Thank you for your support!
story_txt:
“We are a diverse theatre for the world as we see it, producing new and contemporary plays that explore the social, political and cultural issues within our communities.”
Gabriela Sanchez– Founder and Executive DirectorSynopsis Morir Sonyando is a play about family and the grace we must choose to bestow on one another every day to keep alive.“The first hit tears your skin and makes you bleed. It feels like the world has turned to spinning stars. But after that, you don’t feel much more.” Genesis, an academic working her way through an Ivy League education, is proud of the fact that she’s survived her family’s dysfunction, if only just barely. But when her estranged mother, Paloma, is released from prison after a decade of incarceration, Genesis is forced to confront her involvement in the imprisonment and the life from which she has done her best to escape. Photo - Genesis (Erlina Ortiz), Paloma (Gabriela Sanchez) and Felix (Anthony Davila)    
Photo - Genesis (Erlina Ortiz), Paloma (Gabriela Sanchez)

What We Need 
Domestic violence continues to be a pressing issue in our society; our call to action as artists and activists is to empower Philadelphia communities and beyond. Recently, Power Street received the Creative PHL Performance in Public Spaces grant to perform Morir Sonyando at Fair Hill Square Park (4th & Lehigh) on Saturday, May 16th at 7:30pm. This event will be free to the public! 
Power Street believes in giving back, at this performance we will be collecting donations for our partnered organization Women In Transition (WIT), however, these donations will not be tax deductible. 
We are seeking financial support to offset costs for technical equipment for this specific production and to help continue the future touring of this universal play to high schools, universities, libraries, community centers, parks and recreations; wherever we can spread our message! Your generous contribution will support awareness on Domestic Violence and help Philadelphia neighborhoods experience Morir Sonyando’s powerful message. All donations are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.
Expenses:
Projection: rear projector, table mount, rear projector screen
Cables: HDMI, mac adapter connector, and computer audio cables. 
Dividers: fabric 
This is why we need your help!





Get to know us 

Power Street Theatre Company (PSTC) is an ensemble-based theater company composed of culturally conscious theater artists collaborating to create new work that explores social issues. The company aims to be a catalyst for cultural outreach and understanding within Philadelphia and beyond. 
Power Street Theatre Company and Women in Transition (WIT) are partnering in bringing to diverse public spaces around the US the play Morir Sonyando: Die Dreaming, written by Erlina Ortiz. The play premiered this past fall part of the 2014 FringeArts Festival in Philadelphia and made local headlines as Philadelphia City Paper’s 15 must-see shows. “In our play Morir Sonyando, we will follow, in a non-linear structure, the past, present and future of three family members (mother, daughter and son) that had their lives changed because of an act of despair that would destroy everything” – Thais Flaitt Giannoccaro, director. More than mere entertainment, this production aims to heighten consciousness around the issue of domestic violence, by exposing and engaging local audience members on this urgent topic.
Each performance of Morir Sonyando is followed by insightful talkbacks with the cast and audience. For many audience members who can identify with the experiences of the characters in the play, these talk backs create a space for breaking silence. It is as if a sense of community is formed around the realization that survivors of domestic violence are not alone; their voices matter! Power Street is thrilled to collaborate with WIT, a Philadelphian organization that empowers survivors through counseling, referrals and advocacy. WIT's expert team of professional advocates will mediate our talkbacks and distribute literature about the topic of domestic and intimate partner violence. 
Power Street Theatre Company strongly believes in providing affordable access to the arts and raising domestic violence awareness around diverse issues that are relevant in many communities.  “We hope that for every person who sees our play there is one less person who must suffer at the hands of someone who is supposed to love them. We hope that for every person who sees our play there is one more person who has found their voice.”- Erlina Ortiz, playwright. 

Photo – from the documentary Sin by Silence    




The Impact 

By donating to Power Street you become apart of a movement that empowers and educates communities at large!
Quiara Alegria Hudes, recipient of the 2012 Pulitzer Prize for Drama wrote a public letter to the company and said: "What more could we possibly hope for in the future of American theatre? We need groups like this to keep going--to create more art and joy and hold our face to the flame. This is theater that is urgent, necessary, and beautiful. Growing up in West Philly, with much family in North Philly, I had no idea theater existed in Philadelphia. Theaters didn’t put up posters in our neighborhood. Theater wasn’t “for us.” We weren’t invited to the table. Power Street is building a new table. One Philly--and this nation--desperately needs."
Power Street aims to foster and share more theatrical works from our multi-diverse minority group of artists, outreaching minority communities throughout the US and the world, for many years to come! 
Testimonials 
“Morir Sonyando, Power Street’s most recent production puts a focus squarely on a topic that is both universal and incredibly personal to our community. Morir Sonyando looks at the very complicated subject of domestic violence seen through the lens of a Latino family. Along its heartbreaking journey Morir Sonyando investigates incarceration, substance abuse, immigration, hope and the irrevocable damage that the silence surrounding domestic violence often breeds. We watch a family, full of love and expectation, crumble and rebuild itself after a lifetime of violence leads to one choice that changes everything. Unlike so many other works on this topic there are no sinners or saints here. Each character is a beautifully drawn image of a mother, a daughter, a father, a son, complicated and shaped by the limitations and dreams that too often accompany being Latino in the United States. The play’s blending of culture, taboos, healing, and questions about what it means to be loving and free open up such an important dialogue about domestic violence in an attempt to look at it as a symptom of larger problems - like painful immigrations practices and incarceration that overwhelmingly punishes people of color - that plague so many American cities today.”
Tamanya Garza Director, Producer and Digital Marketing Specialist President of the Board of Directors, Azuka Theatre 
“The opportunity to attend Morir Sonyando was incredible for our students from Olney Charter High School. The students had never seen a play performed live, and it exposed them to a new area of art. Several of the students who came are English Language Learners who are emergent bilinguals. Seeing a play performed in Spanish and English was eye-opening for them--they expressed excitement about seeing a professional play performed in multiple languages. The subject matter was also compelling. Immediately after the play, students started talking about their own experiences witnessing domestic violence. Seeing professional actors take this subject matter seriously opened the door for them to see their own experiences as part of larger structural issues, and allowed them to share with each other. They left the theater feeling bigger and seeing themselves as the tellers of stories. Seeing my students react so enthusiastically to the play also inspired me as their teacher. It gave me ideas about how to lead our unit on Theater of the Oppressed and what topics would be of interest to students. I look forward to how students who saw the performance will be able to use what they learned to bring their own experiences and ideas into the limelight to share important topics with others.” 
Elizabeth Logue – Professor Olney Charter High School 


Photo- Morir Sonyando, Domestic Violence Awareness Month (student matinee)

Our History 
Power Street premiered its first production, MinorityLand, at Taller Puertorriqueño for the 2013 Philly Fringe Festival, followed by a production at the University of Pennsylvania for the Festival Latino. Power Street ensemble tackles what it means to be a minority, what it means to be a community, and just how deeply our words and actions can affect those around us. When the local university begins buying up houses in an integrated black and latino community, residents are pushed out, and the very fabric of the community is ripped apart.
