Photo - MinorityLand Reading, University of Pennsylvania 

In the spring of 2014, Power Street joined forces nationally with NoPassport, in collaboration with Dominic D'Andrea (Producing Artistic Director, The One-Minute Play Festival, #1MPF), and locally with the Philadelphia New Play Initiative, the Directors Gathering, Plays & Players, and Tamanya Garza to produce 30/30/1, a day of celebration of new plays by US Latina/o playwrights. Throughout out a still cold Saturday in Philadelphia a group of more than 50 theatre artists gathered at Play & Players Theatre to read and discuss US Latina/o plays and the day culminated on a panel and a stage reading of Learn to be a Latina by Enrique Urueta. With the success of this day event in June the companies hosted three more stage readings (To Catch the Lightning by Carmen Rivera, El Nogalar by Tanya Saracho, and Dark Matters by Oliver Mayer), bringing the Latino/a theater to Central Philly community.

Photo- 30/30/1: Philadelphia Celebrates Latina/o Playwrights  
Morir Sonyando is the company’s second full production, proven that this young company is here to stay. Matching its audience outreach expectations the play was listed among the 15 must-see Fringe shows by the Philadelphia City Paper, in addition performed at Temple University for Lambda Theta Alpha Sorority Inc's Founders Week. Power Street was also nominated to the 2014 Hispanic Choice Awards for The Vision Award, presented to the artist, or group of artists, who use visual, musical and/or performing arts, to inspire positive change in the lives of others. 
Photo- Morir Sonyando, Temple University, Women Against Abuse advocates




Other Ways You Can Help
If you’re interested in helping but don’t not have the financial means:

Join us for the outdoor premiere of Morir Sonyando at Fair Hill Square Park (4th & Leigh) on Saturday, May 16th at 7:30pm. This event will be free to the public. Help us spread the word!
Let your friends know about Power Street Theatre Company and have them make some noise about it on their favorite social media platform. Hash tag: 
#powerstreetontour #itsonus #morirsonyandooutdoors #domesticviolenceawareness #Whyistayed #Whyileft #breakthesilence #indiegogoPST#breakthecycle #WIT 


Make use of the Indiegogo share tools!


Power Street Theater Company is deeply grateful to
all who support our vision.
Thank you for your support!

story:
Summary

BAKER'S DOZEN: 12 Angry Puppets is going to the Vancouver Fringe Festival! 

The show, created and performed by Adam Francis Proulx, has appeared all over: Toronto Festival of Clowns, Toronto Fringe (NOW Magazine, Best Puppetry), Montreal Fringe (Best Solo Show), Sault Pride, Staircase Theatre in Hamilton, and even opened for Rick Mercer and can be seen soon on TV on Bell Fibe On Demand.

And despite this success and hustling... theatre is expensive!!!

The show is heading West in September 2015 and needs your help!

What We Need & What You Get 

We need to help cover our costs to take the show out West and are offering some unique perks to entice you. We have set our goal at $2000 to make it realistic. In an ideal world, $2600 would really grease the wheels!

Our costs include:

  • Air Travel - $700
  • Publicity in Vancouver - $500
  • Festival Entry Fees - $800
  • Stage Manager - $300

Perks will include:

  • Puppet buttons!
  • Personalized videos!
  • Show tickets!
  • Even custom puppets made by Adam!!!

SO!!!

Any little bit helps! We are excited to bring this story to the West Coast and tell people there about standing up for yourself, being aware of your first impressions, and fart jokes. Lots of fart jokes.

Twitter: @BakersDozenTO
Facebook: BAKER'S DOZEN: 12 Angry Puppets
Website: www.AdamFrancisProulx.com

story:
Short Summary

The SHINKA Project started in 2013 to explore the theme of evolution. It evolved into a 20 minute trio piece in 2015. Then in 2016, it became an ensemble 60 minute piece. Finally, we can share this project with the world! 

This is my passion project, and I have been working with several different wonderful performers to develop it over the past 4 years.  

Evolution of SHINKA: 

2013: SHINKA-evolution- duet with Jordan Rosin, Jason Lasky 

2015: SHINKA -evolution- trio with Jordan Rosin, Chris Carlone, Byron Hagan 

2016: SHINKA ensemble with Jordan Rosin, Chris Carlone, Byron Hagan, Leah Beltran, Clara Kundin

This is an original story that I have been choreographing in order to communicate with the world. We are evolving every single moment. We may not see it physically, but mentally, we are evolving all the time. That was the starting point for me. Then I thought of the history of humans, the history of earth- the history of living beings. When I see what is going on in the world today, I believe it is a reflection of our minds- then what if-- what if we can change our minds? The world we see might be different. We might be able to create a society for our children, grandchildren and future generations, where we would want to live - We can transform. These ideas have been evolving in me for the past 4 years. I have been learning, performing, teaching, and creating for years now, and I have found amazing collaborators who can share our common passion. And I feel now I am so lucky that I have people who can create something together- share a vision together. This project is my love letter, and is our prayer to you- our dear friends, family, co-workers, our loved ones- and all living beings on this planet. After 4 years of exploration, I applied to the Capital Fringe Festival, and we received the opportunity to premiere this work in Washington DC!! And I found my team! I am so thankful to the people who are on board with me to go on this journey together. Bob Lyness, Jorge Luna, Miles Butler, Clara Kundin, Jennifer Marinelli, Efren Sanchez, Rui Dun, Robin Dill, and Deepsikha Chatterjee! 

--------

TEAM! 

Featuring: Jorge Luna, Miles Butler, Clara Kundin, Jennifer Marinelli, Efren Sanchez, Yokko

Directed & Choreographed by Yoshiko Usami

Costume Designer:  Deepsikha Chatterjee

Lighting Designer/ Production Manager:  Robin Dill

Assistant Director : Rui Dun

Producer/Company Manager: Bob Lyness

 And in order to realize this Capital Fringe Tour, we need a production budget--!  So we need your help!!

What We Need

We need $2500-! 

- Fringe Registration Fee

- Insurance

- PR & Marketing Fees

-Transportation 

-Costume & Lighting

-Labor (actual stipends for our wonderful performers and designers!)

-----

The Impact

I do believe this type of show and story needs to be told more. It may be a small single action in the beginning, but one stone creates a ripple and it will get bigger if we keep doing something. We all can do something. And your contribution is a huge part of our action!  Your love, your energy, your prayer is in that contribution, and we carry that into our show! So we do super appreciate your love and support! 

Risks & Challenges

We will do 5 shows plus tech in 3 days. And this is a Butoh & dance & physical theatre show where we put ourselves 120% into every single show to transform. We all will be challenged physically, mentally, emotionally, and spiritually. This is our prayer. 

We will perform at Elstad Auditorium – Gallaudet University,  and we are making the piece is accessible and inclusive of  the non-hearing community by using American Sign Language. None of us have not done that, and this is our challenging!

We are excited these challenges! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this campaign with others to tell them this project exists. By passing information about the show and project -one by one- it will get bigger if we all do so!  Please spread the word!!   We appreciate your help.

 

THANK YOU FOR READING THIS!! 

 

MUCH LOVE, 

Yokko

story:
Who we are and what we do:

Our company, Open Book Theatre Ltd, has been bringing immersive and exciting theatre to libraries since 2013, including successful performances of 'Dracula', 'Alice's Adventures in Wonderland' and 'The Wind in the Willows'.  Our idea was to help recreate a buzz about libraries within local communities, as well as bringing theatre to areas with very few arts activities.

Since then we have become more and more passionate about bringing theatre to as many people as we can.  Therefore, we have made our performances free and completely accessible to those with financial barriers.

We are a non-profit organisation that depends completely on public and private funding.  By donating, you will be helping us to bring 'The Jungle Book' to 22 libraries to over 1000 audience-members, including children and adults who have never been to the theatre before.  The production will be professional and high-quality, immersing it's audience and using the library surroundings in the creation of the jungle.  Thank you for supporting us!

What you donations will do:

We believe in paying all cast and creatives a fair wage. This has been covered largely by funding from libraries and their local councils, but we still need to cover costs of other elements of the show. 

Here's a break down of what you donations will do:

  • £9.99 will buy paint for the set.
  • £17 will buy costume full costume for one actor.
  • £85 will cover the cost of our climbing frame (our big set-piece)
  • £50 will buy diesel for the van
  • £1000 would cover the van hire and parking!
  • £1 will buy some useful materials from pound shops to put towards prop-making.

The Impact

Our adaptation of Rudyard Kipling's 'The Jungle Book' will encourage families into their local libraries.  It will inspire audiences to read the book.  It will mean an entertaining and fun arts activity for many communities with little-to-no access to theatre.

By contributing, you will be helping Open Book to continue our successful work and giving families the chance to see a high-standard of theatre in their local libraries.

Reviews and audience feedback from past productions:

“Open Book Theatre has mounted an excellent site-specific production… intimate and engaging… It is these events that bring people together, which demonstrate why we need to save our libraries.”  Hannah Elsy, A Younger Theatre

“It was great use of a library… Highlighting the connection between great works of literature and the vital place libraries have in our society.”  David Norman, Clandestine Critic

“I absolutely loved the play. As I’m 14 I was quite reluctant to see it at first, as I thought it would be babyish, but it was wonderful and enjoyable for all.”  Young adult, Idea Store, Watney Market

Other Ways You Can Help

We greatly appreciate your support.  If you can't donate, you can still help us massively by sharing this page with as many people as possible on Facebook, twitter and other social media sites.

story:
Who we are

Under the direction of Princess Grace Award-winning choreographer, Gabrielle Lamb, Pigeonwing Dance integrates the rigor of classical training into a unique contemporary movement language rich in detail and humor. According to the Dictionary of American Regional English, ""to cut a pigeon wing" means "to execute an intricate dance step with grace... to dance in a fancy way".  In the fanciest of ways, our New York-based company blends technical virtuosity and visual poetry to investigate the complexities of 21st century lives.

www.pigeonwingdance.com

Our Project

This fall, Pigeonwing is a company in residence at Baruch Performing Arts Center in the heart of Manhattan’s Flatiron District. The residency gives us the unusual luxury of a three-week rehearsal period on the stage of Baruch College’s historic Mason Hall, a rarely used 1929 Art Deco theatre and will culminate in two events: an open rehearsal for the CUNY community and a performance for the general public (November 18, 7:00 PM).

During this residency, choreographer Gabrielle Lamb will work with the seven wonderful and creative dancers of Pigeonwing on Bewilderness, a new ensemble piece that explores group dynamics under pressure and draws inspiration from historian and activist Rebecca Solnit’s writings on the disaster communities that spring up after earthquakes and floods.

 The new work includes, as a virtuosic prelude, a new solo created for an extraordinary guest artist, Pei-Ju Chien Pott, Principal Dancer with the Martha Graham Company, and set to music by Henry Purcell.  The program is completed by Tessellations (2016), set to music by the Amestoy Trio and Cat Power, and performed by The Joffrey Ensemble. 

www.baruch.cuny.edu/bpac

So far:

We started working on ideas for Bewilderness during Summer 2015, in a residency at Queens College.  In August 2016 we were invited for a residency at Socrates Sculpture Park, where we created and performed a section of the piece on an outdoor stage under a canopy of trees overlooking the East River.   We're excited to get onstage this November and find out how the gritty Art-Deco ambience of Mason Hall will color the rest of the work.  

Help us to make our goal!

We are grateful to have received support this year from both the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council and the CUNY Dance Initiative.   Thanks to these two organizations we are able to rehearse and perform in a large, centrally located Manhattan theatre; but we still need to raise $3000 in order to fully fund our project.   Your donations will help to pay the salaries of the artists and technicians whose experience and professionalism are vital to the success of the work.  

Gabrielle Lamb/Pigeonwing Dance is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non­profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Gabrielle Lamb/Pigeonwing Dance must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” only. Any contribution above the value of the goods and services received by the donor is tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

 

Photos by Charles Roussel
story_txt: Who we areUnder the direction of Princess Grace Award-winning choreographer, Gabrielle Lamb, Pigeonwing Dance integrates the rigor of classical training into a unique contemporary movement language rich in detail and humor. According to the Dictionary of American Regional English, ""to cut a pigeon wing" means "to execute an intricate dance step with grace... to dance in a fancy way".  In the fanciest of ways, our New York-based company blends technical virtuosity and visual poetry to investigate the complexities of 21st century lives.www.pigeonwingdance.comOur ProjectThis fall, Pigeonwing is a company in residence at Baruch Performing Arts Center in the heart of Manhattan’s Flatiron District. story:
Short Summary

My name is Karlan Judd. I moved to NYC 10 years ago to pursue my dream of becoming a writer of Broadway shows! I've had lots of ups and downs, but the highlight of my time here was when I was given the Richard Rodgers Award for Musical Theatre by Stephen Sondheim. 

I was inspired to write The Real Actors of NYC by Nicholas Barnes, Jacob McKenna and Jennifer Anderson, three actors in NYC. As I listened at our dinner dates to their stories about being an actor in NYC, I decided to write a show that would give them what they wanted, the chance to star in a Broadway show! 

We have received generous donations in order to put this show up in an Off Broadway Theatre for a six week run. We are most of the way there, but we need your help to raise the remaining $15,000 so this production can happen.

The budget for the show goes primarily to actor, director and designer salaries, sets, props, insurance and advertising. We are working with Actors Equity and the Stage Directors and Choreographers Society Unions and meeting all of their minimum requirements. 

The Impact

I have been working to become a musical theatre writer for 20 years. I always have to choose the topic for my shows carefully, as it is a huge commitment to write a full length musical. I usually end up writing a show about an underdog - someone who's story needs to be told but isn't. That's the case with The Real Actors of NYC. Here are three mega-talented actors, but they just aren't finding the jobs that will help them build their careers.

Risks & Challenges

Mounting an Off Broadway show is always a gamble. Investors are always wary of whether or not they will get their money back. Truth is, the majority of Broadway and Off Broadway shows don't make their money back. However, when they do, they do VERY WELL! Just look at Wicked! With your donations, we will be able to lessen the risk to investors, and create a financial model that will give them some assurity that their investment in our show is a good one! 

The Real Actors of NYC is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non­profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of The Real Actors of NYC must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” only. Any contribution above the value of the goods and services received by the donor is tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law. 

If for any reason this production is delayed or cancelled, all donations will be used exclusively for the further development and production of THE REAL ACTORS OF NYC.

story:
Brief Note From The Director:
This production of The Who’s Tommy explores how this universal story can resonate not only with a female protagonist, but also for any time and place. Our story is not set in London or in any specific time period, but rather explores the general dynamics of rigid order, society, conformity, and the anarchy inherent to the communities we all know. In this, we are leaning into the feeling of the concept album: broad sweeps of plot, emotional storytelling, and using musicality to illustrate changes in time, identity, and place.

Where Your Money Will Go!:

Your money will go to helping many student designers and team members create Tommy's world. We are completely reliant on outside funding sources so it is with your generosity that the imaginations and skills of this team will come to life! We also pride ourselves on giving young team members the chance to learn, grown and work with tools that they will have no other place to gain experience with. More specifically, here are some of the areas your generous donations will go!

  • Set: Our set designer is one of the most talented and creative designers Northwestern has seen in years. His designs are ambitious and creative and will challenge everyone as they come to life. His set will be our first introduction into Tommy's world
  • Costumes: One of the most crucial parts of any character is their costume. This helps build their identity and give the audience more of an insight into who they are and what their role in the world is. 
  • Props: From items as small as a pen to as large as a pinball machine, the props are the finest of details that round out our world. They are what make a room into Tommy's room. They are what make a stage into Tommy's stage. 
  • Lights: Lights are one of the most crucial parts to any show. They set the mood, highlight the subtle, and dazzle an audience wherever they go. A great set needs great lights to highlight all of its magic. 
  • Projections: Tommy seeks to push the boundaries on what Northwestern productions can do and will be experimenting with projections for the show. These will certainly add a new and exciting element to Tommy and will further the capabilities of what Northwestern student theatre can accomplish.
  • Marketing: We need people to see the show! What would a Who concert be with no audience!? Our marketing team works tirelessly for months to excite the community to come and be a part of our show. Your generous donations will help us get creative and have wonderfully exciting promotional materials to spread Tommy's music. 

    • The story of Tommy Walker is as follows:

    In the wake of a violent war, a war-ravaged Captain Walker returns home to find his wife unfaithful, raising his only daughter Tommy with her lover. When Walker kills his wife’s lover, the young Tommy fearfully recedes into her traumatized mind (appearing deaf, dumb, and blind to the world from this point forward) as her parents adamantly silence her as a witness to her father’s crime. Hoping to fix Tommy, Mr. and Mrs. Walker uselessly drag Tommy through a parade of doctors and specialists while her society mourns her refusal to participate in the comfort of community. Frustrated, the Walkers abandon Tommy to the abusive hands of babysitters in order to retain the support of their community. Uncle Ernie and cousin Kevin take advantage of Tommy’s silence, but the tortured Tommy finally finds comfort in her skill at pinball, impressing her peers with her unmatched, miraculous skill.

    Eventually when the Walker’s are finally honest with a new doctor about the trauma in Tommy’s past, the doctor explains that Tommy’s silence is a chosen rebellion and in response, her resentful mother symbolically smashes the mirror in which Tommy had sought comfort through the turmoil of her childhood. Shocked into agency, Tommy discovers her voice and abandons her poisonous family to build a life from her pinball fame. One night, performing in her  hometown, Tommy accidentally injures an eager fan named Sally and Tommy’s capacity for violence distresses her into inviting the entirety of her audience to her childhood home to see the roots of her suffering and rebellion. The ravenous crowd swarms her home, demanding to know secret of Tommy’s uniqueness and strength. But Tommy urges them to appreciate the clarity with which they already touch, see, and feel the world; explaining that she didn’t know her own power, a power they all already have. The crowd explodes, unsatisfied without an easy answer and so Tommy is left with the lonely kind of freedom that accompanies the pursuit of personal truth.

story:
Short Summary

From the minds of Val Dunn and Jenna Kuerzi from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, USA, comes a satirical look at Johnny Depp’s film career from pre-teen heart throb to Wino Forever, and everything in between, to ask…. What happened?

Toss your golden doubloons, Scissorhands memorabilia, and embarrassing fan letters onto the shrine turned dumpster fire Depp has created for himself. Part ritual & part drunken singalong, Johnny Depp: a Retrospective features rum, promiscuity, and $30,000 worth of candles by which we can pay to watch the Rich consume us all. Jenna Kuerzi as Johnny Depp as Jack Sparrow as Johnny Depp as Late Stage Capitalism as Jack Sparrow. Val Dunn, for one brief shining moment, as Winona Ryder.

*Any resemblance to persons, living or dead, is intended purely as a satire.*

What We Need & What You Get

Every dollar you donate will go directly to making this Edinburgh Dumpster Fire Dream come true. Here's where your money will go if you donate to us: 

  • Fringe Registration Fee ($)
  • A Place for Us to Sleep in Edinburgh ($$)
  • Flights to Edinburgh ($$$)

Look, we get it. You've probably never been paid $55,000,000* for anything. That's why we're only asking you to help us with the bare minimum. It's crucial we meet this fundraising goal as it doesn't even begin to factor the total cost of becoming "International Artists Val Dunn & Jenna Kuerzi". (Funds raised through Indiegogo won't, for example, pay us or feed us.) We don't expect to make any money on this theatrical adventure, just a little bit of full-hearted foolhardy comedic art commentary on capitalism. 

*Johnny Depp earned $55,000,000 for filming On Stranger Tides... which is 36,666 times the amount of money we're hoping to crowdsource. 

The Impact

For further information on how this show has positively impacted Philadelphia/Everyone, please refer to Henrik Eger's review of the show. 

"Surrounded by enthusiastic Deppean super fans who had seen most of his films and who had fallen in and out of love with him since adolescence, I felt as out-of-place as a Puritan wearing a winter coat at a nudist beach. And yet, I enjoyed the evening. One scene in particular intrigued me. Depp was cutting paper into small pieces that tumbled down like snowflakes over Dunn’s head, which was covered by two frizzy, differently-colored wigs on top of each other. “Winona Ryder,” someone shouted. “Edward Scissorhands,” screamed someone else. I had no idea what it was all about. Call me crazy, but I loved the show." - Henrik Eger 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share our fundraising page with people who have more money than we do. 
  • Connect us to folks who will be in Edinburgh in August.
  • Make an in-kind donation: chocolate! beer! rum! red wine! brown paper bags! printing! space! 

~Thank you for your help!~

story:
THE FISHERMAN AND HIS SOUL

Music | Shadows | Magic

"Every evening the young Fisherman went out upon the sea, and threw his nets into the water.” So begins the 1891 fairy tale by Oscar Wilde that will come to life on the BCT stage in the spring of 2015. What the fisherman finds in his net will get your imagination whirling: “But no fish at all was in it, nor any monster or thing of horror, but only a little Mermaid lying fast asleep." This discovery sends the fisherman on a journey that questions what he will give up for love and the consequences that ensue.
BCT is thrilled to be presenting this latest World Premiere by two of the most talented artists it has been our pleasure to work with over the years. Michael Baltzell and Michael Hartwell, who will bring this work to life, have been a part of BCT as scenic designers, technical directors, directors, actors and musicians.This play is a labor of love from two of BCT's most ingenious artists. It promises to be filled with light, shadows, magic and imagination. We believe audiences will love it. We know we do.



WHO'S WHO

We believe very strongly that the quality of a new play is directly connected to the talent and enthusiasm of the collaborative team that creates it. For this project we have gathered the very best. It's more than a team, it's a family and we are thrilled to be embarking on this project with a phenomenally talented and inspiring family of artists. 

THE CAST: Anne McDonald (Fisherman/Soul), Neil Brookshire (Fisherman/Soul), Jordan Bowman (Witch/Mermaid), Justin Ness (Priest/Shadows), Hailee Lenhart-Wees (Merchant/Shadows), with Sean Dahlman and Anthony Parry (Musicians.)

THE DESIGNERS: Michael Baltzell & Michael Hartwell (Scenic), Darrin Pufall (Costumes), Peter John Still (Sound), Deborah Penrod  (Lights), Sean Dahlman (Composer) and Bernadine Cockey (Props). 

THE PRODUCTION TEAM: Michael Baltzell & Michael Hartwell (Co-Writers & Directors), Kristy J. Martin (Stage Manager), Sarah Kelso (Assistant Stage Manager), Paul Miller (Master Electrician), and Tim Long (Sound Technician). 


What We Need & What You Get

This is a big project. We're looking to raise $20,000 in three weeks. That's less than 25% of what the play will cost to produce but the rest will be paid for with ticket sales (less than half) and other contributions that have already been made. Where will the contributed money go? Here are just a few of the many costs of producing this World Premiere:

Building the scenic elements for THE FISHERMAN AND HIS SOUL.

Creating costumes for several characters,  including a mermaid, a witch, a merchant, a priest  and many exotic shadowy characters.

Producing just the right properties to enhance our magical journey.

Developing lighting  effects particular to the needs of this production.

Salaries, travel expenses, sound effects and electricity. There are many different line items in the budget for a new play, but there is a kind of alchemy that happens when you add it all together with a live audience. The result is something very special, a little magical even, but we won't really know what it is until it all comes to life on stage in April. We do know this: We can't do it without your help. 

What’s in it for you? (PERKS!)

Apart from knowing that you'll be helping to bring a brand new play into the world, there are some very cool perks that come with your support. Look through the list to the right and find the possibilities that excite you. Every dollar BCT raises from this campaign will go directly toward the production costs for THE FISHERMAN AND HIS SOUL.

BCT is a 501(c)3 non-profit organization. Your contribution (minus the actual value of any perks you receive) will be fully tax deductible.

The Impact

BCT has a growing reputation as a surprisingly fertile starting place for new plays. Boise? Really? Yes, Boise, really. We believe that THE FISHERMAN AND HIS SOUL has the potential to be the best work we've ever done. Your support will boost the resources we have to pursue our vision, and to boost Boise's reputation as a leading home for great theater.

Risks & Challenges

BCT has produced thirteen World Premieres over the past seven seasons and we learn something new every time. The audiences are getting bigger and so are the shows.

Sitting in the red seats at BCT and enjoying a great play is a memorable experience, but sitting in those seats and knowing that you helped bring that story, that play, that world to life... that's a very gratifying feeling.

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that some people just can’t contribute money, even five bucks, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

Help BCT to get the word out by making some noise about our campaign. With only three weeks to reach our goal, we could use your help. Tell your friends and family. Tell your neighbors. Think of the most talkative and charming person you know... and tell them. Plus, Indiegogo has some great social media sharing tools to make it easy to spread the word via Facebook, Twitter and Google+.

Volunteer to usher at a performance. Every show at BCT is made possible by the help of our hard working volunteers. It's a fun way to spend an evening (or an afternoon) and if there are seats available, you get to see the show for free!

The result is something very special, a little magical even, but we won't
really know what it is until it all comes to life on stage in April. We do know
this: We can't do it without your help. 
What’s in it for you? (PERKS!)
Apart from knowing that you'll be helping to bring a brand
new play into the world, there are some very cool perks that come with your
support. Look through the list to the right and find the possibilities that
excite you. Every dollar BCT raises from this campaign will go directly toward
the production costs for THE FISHERMAN AND HIS SOUL.
BCT is a 501(c)3 non-profit organization. Your contribution
(minus the actual value of any perks you receive) will be fully tax deductible.
  The Impact 
BCT has a growing reputation as a surprisingly fertile
starting place for new plays. Boise? Really? Yes, Boise, really. We believe
that THE FISHERMAN AND HIS SOUL has the potential to be the best work we've ever done.
Your support will boost the resources we have to pursue our vision, and to
boost Boise's reputation as a leading home for great theater.   Risks & Challenges 
BCT has produced thirteen World Premieres over the past seven seasons and we learn something new every time. The audiences are getting bigger
and so are the shows. 
Sitting in the red seats at BCT and enjoying a great play is a memorable experience, but sitting in those seats and knowing that you helped
bring that story, that play, that world to life... that's a very gratifying feeling.   Other Ways You Can Help 

We know that some people just can’t contribute money, even
five bucks, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:
Help BCT to get the word out by making some noise about our
campaign. With only three weeks to reach our goal, we could use your
help. Tell your friends and family. Tell your neighbors. Think of the most
talkative and charming person you know... and tell them. Plus, Indiegogo
has some great social media sharing tools to make it easy to spread the
word via Facebook, Twitter and Google+.
Volunteer to usher at a performance. Every show at BCT is
made possible by the help of our hard working volunteers. It's a fun way to
spend an evening (or an afternoon) and if there are seats available, you get to
see the show for free!

story:
Ms Pascale needs marley flooring for her studio

Pascale Leroy Ballet Center is up-and-running, and her students are full of enthusiasm. Now, Ms Pascale needs marley flooring to accomodate her young ballerinas en pointe!

  • American Harlequin Corporation has provided a discounted quote
  • $7,500 will cover the Gray Cascade material Pascale prefers, plus installation
  • The marley will cover and enhance the beautifully-sprung hardwood floor
  • Young professional-track and adult students alike will benefit from the flooring

story:
The Campaign
My name is Luther D. Isler, and I am the Executive Director of THE BOMB SHELTER, a free Harlem based nonprofit arts organization, and the writer/director/producer of "What Would You Do?" A Poetry Play about 7 young adults struggling with love, sex,  and identity. I am also a 29 year old, husband and father of 2 daughters, living and raised him Harlem, New York City, with a passion for empowering young people. We, THE BOMB SHELTER, are campaigning to raise funds to produce "What Would You Do?" at The Snapple Theatre, which will then help jump-start the Full Year of THE BOMB SHELTER Programming including Open Mics, Poetry Slams, Workshops, Plays, A Community Concert, and more, promoting literacy and creativity in the Harlem community and beyond.

The Cost
At minimum, to produce 1 open mic each month, 1 slam each month, 2 writing workshops each month, and 1 play reading each season costs over $15,000 a year mostly on space rental alone. For the past 3 years I've run THE BOMB SHELTER programs for free as a voluntary labor of love, even putting up more than half of the initial costs of producing "What Would You Do?" out of my own pockets. We could be doing so much more if THE BOMB SHELTER could replace one of my part time jobs, which would cost a minimum of $15,000 a year. Thats $30,000 just for 1 event a week and 1 part time staff for 1 year and that's only the start and taking "What Would You Do" Off-Broadway will help launch us in that direction.

"What Would You Do" Off-Broadway will cost $10,000
The cost of renting the theatre is $300 an hour. The show is 2 hours (not including set up and talk-back).
The cost of paying cast and actors is about $800 per show. 
Thats $1,700 per show. 4 shows is $6,800.
Plus the cost of a publicist and a other costs.
The $5,500 allows us to start this process, reserve the theatre and hire a publicist or marketing consultant.

Help us reach our goal and depending on your level of contribution you will get 2 tickets to the Off-Broadway production and a credit in the Off-Broadway Playbill as an Associate Producer, Co-Producer, Co-Executive Producer, or Producer.
In addition:
Associate Producers get a ticket to our benefit performance this October.
CoProducers get a digital download or DVD of the play.
Co-Executive Producers get an exclusive THE BOMB SHELTER present "What Would You Do?" T-shirt.

If we do not reach our entire goal, everything we do acquire will still go towards renting the theatre either farther in 2016 or for less days and the cast and crew will have to get paid out of the profits of the show. 


The Community
I wrote the play 12 years ago as a high school junior and intern of New Heritage Theatre group. I preparation for a youth conference on sexual health and safety, I was asked to write a performance piece to open the event. A single monologue turned into a 7 character play with various archetypes each struggling with self-identity, sexuality, and making life changing decision. This year, we successfully presented 11 performances in a comunity center and 1 show at a local theatre. The responses have been phenomenal.

"What Would You Do?" is a play about 6 young adults struggling with love, sex, identity, family, and HIV and other consequences of their life changing decisions through poetry and spoken word. It is an intelligent, Shakespeare meets Harlem Renaissance meets Jazz meets Hip Hop riveting, suspenseful, hilarious, tear jerking, thought provoking Urban Earth-tone shot of reality. Everyone who has seen it, from 14 to 41, feels it is a strong conversational piece that touches of universal truths that connects us as humans beyond age, social, or economic status.

And the play this only a launchpad for more THE BOMB SHELTER programming.

We're really excited abut what's coming up for The Bomb Shelter and "What Would You Do?". We have a 5 year plan for for The Bomb Shelter now that The Bomb Shelter has successfully begun its expansion from just an pen Mic into an Arts Organization with the success as a first time Theatre Production Company. This plan includes empowering young people, and adults alike, through literacy and creativity via our open mics, writing and performing workshops, an annual free concert featuring artists that share our vision of an empowered New York and global community, and training, employing, and providing internships for young people.

story:
WHAT IS BLOOM?

The night before performer and bodyworker Lindsay Abromaitis-Smith was diagnosed with ALS, she dreamed of a goddess made entirely of plants and flowers who told her she had to learn how to physically manifest differently. BLOOM. SHE IS DESCENDING is an evolving document of her changing body, which she finds increasingly aligned with the slow, rooted unfurling of life in the plant world. 

WHAT IS ALS?
Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis or Lou Gehrig's Disease is a neuromuscular degenerative disease that causes motor neurons in the brain and spinal cord to die and their corresponding bodily functions such as movement, speech, swallowing, and breathing to cease. It is terminal, often quickly progressing, and there is currently no cure and very little treatment.

HOW DID BLOOM BEGIN?
BLOOM began as a one-woman show, performed at Dixon Place, NYC in September 2013 to a sold out house. In the year since its debut, BLOOM has evolved into a multi-media ensemble performance incorporating dance, puppetry, and an immersive sonic environment. It was performed again as a work-in-progress at Dixon Place, NYC in July 2014, in a production made possible with support from Cheryl Henson. 

WHERE IS BLOOM GOING?
BLOOM is expanding to become a multi-media installation and performance piece incorporating video, puppetry, and kinetic objects along with a live soundscape in an environment designed to support Lindsay's ongoing exploration of her constantly changing capacity for movement. It will be previewed in New Orleans this fall as a part of the group show "With Light, With Love" presented by The Tigermen Den for the Prospect 3 Biennial P.3+ Satellite Program, and the finished piece will be installed and performed in Lindsay's hometown of NYC in December 2014. 

WHY IS BLOOM IMPORTANT?

BLOOM is a platform for Lindsay, a storyteller and healer by trade, to share her physical, emotional and imaginative experiences of ALS with the world around her. By creating an immersive environment and using the tools of physical theater, she is able to amplify what her journey with ALS feels like, and share the terrifying struggles and odd beauty of her experience with a wide audience. 

By previewing the show in New Orleans in October, Lindsay will connect her experience with the city's embrace of the luscious decadence of life and death before bringing it home to be realized in its entirety in New York City in December. The goal of this show is to bring the jungle of verdant growth and beautiful decay in Lindsay's body and mind to the stage as a work of art, fostering connection, understanding, and community through an experience that is so often painful and isolating. In doing so, BLOOM strives to make visible an experience of disability that too often remains unseen and unheard. It is a dance of transformation that speaks to the many diverse communities of those affected by disability. 


HOW IS BLOOM BEING MADE?

Because Lindsay is no longer able to build or manipulate objects with her own hands, she has enlisted the help of an all-star team of designers, puppeteers, performers, musicians, builders and producers to help her realize her vision. The BLOOM team brings decades of cumulative professional experience in the fields of puppetry, performance, music, film, management and production to the project along with their dedication to helping Lindsay bring her vision to life. Professional highlights from the team's collective resume include performances seen on Broadway and Comedy Central, participation in the Park Avenue Armory Show and the Frieze Art Fair, and design work for clients ranging from Sesame Street to Bjork. 


WHAT DOES BLOOM NEED?

We are seeking funding for the installation and performance of BLOOM in New Orleans this October and New York City this December. The money raised will be put into action financing the many costs associated with producing a piece of theater, and will aid in the particular challenges of doing so while living with ALS. Costs of sculptural materials, camera and projection equipment, audio equipment, stipends for our cast and crew, handicap accessible travel and transportation expenses to get Lindsay, her crew, her puppets and her caregivers from New York to New Orleans, are all outlined in the budget below. 

  • Set Design + Materials - $2,100
  • Puppetry Design + Materials - $2,200  
  • Sound Design + Equipment - $4,500
  • Video Design + Equipment - $2,300
  • Lighting Design + Equipment - $2,000
  • NYC - NOLA Travel Expenses - $2,300
  • Handicap Accessible Transport & Accommodation in NOLA - $2,800
  • NYC Handicap Accessible Transportation Expenses - $3,000
  • Cast & Crew Stipends - $23,700
  • Space Rental - $5,000

HOW WILL BLOOM GIVE BACK?

Incentives for giving include many different levels of access to Lindsay's work, ranging from tickets to the performance, to DVD's of Lindsay's past work, to video extras featuring interviews with Lindsay about the project, to a salon-style roundtable discussion with Lindsay and the BLOOM team. 

Any funds raised in excess of our goal will be donated to the Muscular Dystrophy Association. MDA is the world’s leading nonprofit health organization sponsoring research seeking the causes of and effective treatments for neuromuscular diseases. MDA research grants currently are supporting more than 250 projects worldwide. MDA has been instrumental in Lindsay's care and support since her diagnosis. MDA has provided Lindsay, along with countless others suffering from neuromuscular diseases, with crucial resources such as no-cost wheelchairs and doctor's visits, medical advocacy, diagnostic tools, and clinical care. 


HOW WILL BLOOM RAISE AWARENESS?

Lindsay Abromaitis-Smith grew up in the theater and has been performing in some capacity her entire life. It is inextricably a part of who she is. She is in a unique position to shed light on what a lived experience of ALS can look and feel like. Her commitment to performing throughout the progression of the disease is an act of empowerment and defiance as much as it is one of acceptance and surrender. With this project, she is asking for help in realizing the full articulation of her vision with the intention that her experience may educate, inspire and empower the world around her.

The BLOOM team is committed to working together to support Lindsay in bringing her vision to life on the grand scale that befits this once-in-a-lifetime opportunity. We, in turn, are asking for your support in helping us make this happen. This is an invitation to invest in a project that shines a light on what a lived experience of ALS can look and feel like: beautiful, scary, wild, loving, painful, awesome, sensual, slow, deep, heavy, and changing every day. BLOOM is a dance of transformation that is made possible by the love and support of the people in our communities. We are asking you to join us in making this possible.


HOW CAN I HELP?

Every dollar given helps connect the dots between Lindsay, her story, her vision, and its reach. There are rewards at every level that are designed to foster this connectivity. For $5 you can subscribe to email updates that document the show as it unfolds. For $25 you can receive a custom made medicine bag filled with ephemera from the show. For $50 you can receive a DVD of the first two performance of BLOOM with handmade artwork by Lindsay. Exclusive Packages offering a whole suite of rewards connecting you to the show start at $150 and include audio and video recordings from the show, original artwork by Lindsay, a limited edition letterpress book of Lindsay's poetry, original photographic prints, and much more! 

Support in the form of helping us spread the word about BLOOM is just as important as each and every financial contribution to the production. Every single person that this show reaches is one more point of connection bringing Lindsay, BLOOM, and its audience closer together in the fullest possible realization of this work. 

Help us connect BLOOM with the world by sharing this campaign on social media and email using the links on this page. Follow us on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and Tumblr, and share your support with your networks as BLOOM digs deep and reaches far to share this work with the world.

story:
Short Summary

I have been auditioning to go to Alvin Ailey's summer intensive since I was 10 years old.  I was always accepted but financially I have never been able to go.  I was so excited to audition this year at 15 years old and be accepted to the Professional Division Summer Intensive (I am now 16) and to be given a 50%+tuition scholarship.  Between scholarship and local sponsorship, my tuition is now completely paid.  I was also awarded an $800 scholarship for housing but I still have to raise the housing and food balance (which is substantial) and travel costs.  

My mom is recently divorced and  the sole provider for my family.  She has worked very hard and volunteered at my dance studio to help keep me dancing while also supporting my disabled older sister.  At my age and level it is important for me to be able to attend an intensive in New York so that I can be recognized for year-round training at their school.  My short-term goal is to get there this summer.  My long-term goal is to go to the summer program, be asked to attend The Ailey School program year-round, be asked to join Ailey II and through my performances and work ethic there, finally be asked to be a professional dancer with Alvin Ailey's company.  Any generosity that helps me overcome our family's recent financial hurdles and achieve my goals would be greatly appreciated.

What You Get/The Perks:

$0- $25:  You will have my undying appreciation.  You will have the satisfaction of knowing you were personally responsible for making my dream of dancing this summer in New York in Alvin Ailey's Professional Division Summer Intensive possible.  You will receive a personal thank you card from me.  

$50 -  $150:  You will have my undying appreciation and the satisfaction of knowing you were personally responsible for making my dream of dancing this summer in New York in Alvin Ailey's Professional Division Summer Intensive possible.  You will receive a personal thank you card and photo from me.

$200 and above - You have my undying appreciation and special thanks for personally being such a large factor in my dream of dancing this summer in New York in Alvin Ailey's Professional Division Summer Intensive becoming a reality.  You will receive a personal thank you card and letter as well as a personal letter from me after the Summer Intensive letting you know what I learned, the connections I made and what your gift meant to me.  

Indiegogo asks where the money will go if I don't achieve my goal.  I know I have a very short amount of time to raise the balance I owe Ailey but I believe I am going to achieve this goal with the help of friends and benefactors.  If for some reason this doesn't happen, I will use the money to fly to Ailey for open classes so that I can still be taught by the instructors and give them a chance to see me dance and I will attend the last week of my school's summer intensive because Carlos dos Santos, Jr. (an amazing choreographer and teacher who has worked with Ailey in the past) will be there as a guest teacher.   He is the first person who actually made me think seriously about switching from classical to contemporary ballet for my career.  

The Impact

 I find it easy to express my feelings through a contemporary dance because it's not just about how high your leg goes but how you draw the audience into the story you are telling with your dance by touching their heart and their emotions.   I see myself as one of the Ailey dancers.  I am a hard worker.  I listen and apply corrections.  I believe I will have a successful experience at this intensive and you will not waste your money by helping me.  

When you go to the Summer Intensive at Ailey, they look at you to see if you would be a good fit for the year-round Ailey School. Then, from the school it's usually into Ailey II.  Even if you are in Ailey II, you still have to go to the audition like everyone else to get into Ailey's traveling company. There are no guarantees on any of this but this is what I want to do.   I need your financial support to make this dream come true.  

Other Ways You Can Help

I know sometimes you want to help but you can’t contribute financially.  That doesn’t mean you can’t help though!

Please share this on your Facebook and ask your friends to help spread the link to their friends.  Please help me get the word out about what I am trying to achieve.  I don't have much time to make this happen!

long-term goal is to go to the summer program, be asked to attend The Ailey School program year-round, be asked to join Ailey II and through my performances and work ethic there, finally be asked to be a professional dancer with Alvin Ailey's company.  Any generosity that helps me overcome our family's recent financial hurdles and achieve my goals would be greatly appreciated.What You Get/The Perks:$0- $25:  You will have my undying appreciation.  You will have the satisfaction of knowing you were personally responsible for making my dream of dancing this summer in New York in Alvin Ailey's Professional Division Summer Intensive possible.  You will receive a personal thank you card from me.  $50 -  $150:  You will have my undying appreciation and the satisfaction of knowing you were personally responsible for making my dream of dancing this summer in New York in Alvin Ailey's Professional Division Summer Intensive possible.  You will receive a personal thank you card and photo from me.$200 and above - You have my undying appreciation and special thanks for personally being such a large factor in my dream of dancing this summer in New York in Alvin Ailey's Professional Division Summer Intensive becoming a reality.  You will receive a personal thank you card and letter as well as a personal letter from me after the Summer Intensive letting you know what I learned, the connections I made and what your gift meant to me.  Indiegogo asks where the money will go if I don't achieve my goal.  I know I have a very short amount of time to raise the balance I owe Ailey but I believe I am going to achieve this goal with the help of friends and benefactors.  If for some reason this doesn't happen, I will use the money to fly to Ailey for open classes so that I can still be taught by the instructors and give them a chance to see me dance and I will attend the last week of my school's summer intensive because Carlos dos Santos, Jr. (an amazing choreographer and teacher who has worked with Ailey in the past) will be there as a guest teacher.   He is the first person who actually made me think seriously about switching from classical to contemporary ballet for my career.  The Impact I find it easy to express my feelings through a contemporary dance because it's not just about how high your leg goes but how you draw the audience into the story you are telling with your dance by touching their heart and their emotions.   I see myself as one of the Ailey dancers.  I am a hard worker.  I listen and apply corrections.  I believe I will have a successful experience at this intensive and you will not waste your money by helping me.  When you go to the Summer Intensive at Ailey, they look at you to see if you would be a good fit for the year-round Ailey School. Then, from the school it's usually into Ailey II.  Even if you are in Ailey II, you still have to go to the audition like everyone else to get into Ailey's traveling company. There are no guarantees on any of this but this is what I want to do.   I need your financial support to make this dream come true.  Other Ways You Can HelpI know sometimes you want to help but you can’t contribute financially.  That doesn’t mean you can’t help though!Please share this on your Facebook and ask your friends to help spread the link to their friends.  Please help me get the word out about what I am trying to achieve.  I don't have much time to make this happen!

story:
Who We Are

We are a team of young artists working to tell stories and push creative boundaries through a combination of theatre, dance, music and media. D I S T O R T I A N is the debut show from High Fantastical Productions and poses the questions hidden by the answers. We all grow up being taught to fit a certain mold and behave a certain way in order to become "functioning" members of society; but just how far do these limits stretch? With the outcome of the universe inevitable, do these limits even matter? Or are they just a construct ingrained in us by older generations. 

The Impact

With your help, we can bring this dream to reality. Our cast is diverse in abilities, our performance space is intimate and our non-linear style in storytelling is unique, offering a one of a kind experience for audience and cast alike. We aren't here to create a spectacle, but rather a shared experience. Your donation will help us formally introduce ourselves to the New York City theatre scene which will open doors to greater resources, more complex work, and increasingly positive exposure. 

The Price of Creation

We have determined that $1,165 is necessary to complete our project. That's not an impossible goal!
The largest chunk is going into renting our performance space. Excluding the final payment we hope to acquire through ticket sales, we need $850 for our space. The white box laboratory space at the Alchemical Theatre Laboratory is a perfect artistic creation space for our piece! It is conveniently located on West Fourteenth Street, between Sixth and Seventh Avenue on the Second floor. 
We have miraculously configured that we will be able to do all necessary marketing for $60. In addition to launching an extensive media campaign, we will be handing out post cards and putting up flyers all around the city. 
Buying only what is absolutely crucial; we have budgeted $172 for materials. This includes a canvas to cover the stage, work lights for lighting, plywood to build various types of flats and a surprise element incorporated into the world of the show. 
Lastly, as we strive to push creative boundaries we are hoping to rent a projector in order to incorporate live feed media into the show - this will provide a varied texture to our already varied landscape. This will cost us $83. 
We are hosting several different kinds of fund raisers, and from the good people we reach via indiegogo (that's you!) we are asking for a gracious $850 to get our company and production on its feet. 

Risks & Challenges

D I S T O R T I O N  is a departure for us in many ways. One of the largest risks, of course, is that we will fail to sell any tickets. But we're not resting on our laurels; we're well acquainted with the hard work of selling an artistic product. We are young but have an incredible amount of drive and ambition as well as experience in the arts! We'll do our utmost to make our donors proud to have given to this production.

We also face the challenge of being a small, burgeoning company with few resources. What we don't have is access to the kind of infrastructure or cash flow a larger companies have at their disposal.

But what we do have is you. You are our network, and a more motivated, adventurous group we've rarely seen. Your donations will help us create a beautiful piece of work, place ads in the right places so people will come to the show, and, in the long term, perpetuate High Fantastical Productions work.

Artistically speaking, putting on a show is a huge risk—and it should be! We're trying out new and exciting, creative roles: directing a group of peers, hosting weekly movement classes centered around Laban and Suzuki techniques, premiering original work by young writers, all while showcasing some of the best talent the city has to offer.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't help us out by donating, be sure to share this campaign on your social media network(s)! If you're in the NYC area, be sure to stay up to date with our Facebook page which will detail upcoming events.
We are also holding several other fundraisers including our "Apocalypse Party" which will be open to the public. 
Thank you so much for your attention and time. Without your support a group of passionate young individuals would not be able to build a theatre company from the ground up and for that we are eternally grateful. We can't wait to dive into this adventure headfirst! Stay tuned! 

Follow us on Facebook at www.facebook.com/HighFantasticalProductions

story:
The London Ballet Company

The London Ballet Company is a small group of professional dancers with a big ambition.

Our ethos is to bring the highest quality of dance performance to non-traditional venues, and bespoke engagements, in order to embrace those who might not have previously been inspired to visit this powerful art form.

We are committed to nurturing both our own dancers as well as international dancers and choreographers, who will deliver world class dance performances, rooted in a strong classical technique. It is our aim to entertain and engage our audience with distinctive, dynamic productions, to push the boundaries of artistic prowess, where the audience can admire the athleticism in the grace of our dancers.

The London Ballet Company is launching a crowdfunding campaign to help cover the costs of our new production The Snow Queen to be premiered winter season 2016 choreographed by Fran Mangiacasale. Any additional profit from ticket sales will be shared amongst the artists.

We are in our sixth year of existence and have been completely self funded to date. We want to grow, expand and reach new heights with this new production. We are very grateful for any support you can offer.

 

What We Need & What You Get

All the money from this campaign will go directly to our production of The Snow Queen. We are aiming to raise £1950 that will cover the bare minimum in putting on this production: studio hire during the rehearsal period, theatre hire, theatre technician and costumes.

Any donation is very much appreciated, and we are offering a number of different perks, check them out!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you would like to help us but cannot donate, then please do help us in other ways...
  • Follow us on facebook 'The London Ballet Company', Twitter @LondonBalletCo, Instagram 'thelondonballetcompany'
  • Share our Indiegogo campaign on your social media - use the logos at the top /\
  • Buy a ticket and come to see our show! Tickets are available here: https://www.ticketsource.co.uk/the-london-ballet-company

Thank you!!!

story:
The History Of Moving Arts

Founded by Lee Wochner and Julie Briggs in 1992, Moving Arts has been producing and premiering original and inspired plays for two decades. For the 20th Anniversary Season - 20/20 Vision, Sara Wagner, the company's current Artistic Producer, choose to remount Wochner's The Size of Pike, originally produced in the same theater in 1994. While performing in various other venues over the years, Moving Arts has always held onto the intimate space on Hyperion. However, the attached seating has restricted the ability to alter the staging or set-up of this precious little black box. By contributing to this campaign you can help restore and transform the quality of Moving Arts' home base for years to come.

What We Need & What You Get

Here is exactly what your contribution will do for us and what you will get in return:

Our Goal of $3,000.00 will buy comfy new seats and collapsable risers, that can be placed in any configuration needed for any production. Funds raised will also go towards the painting of the risers and a gorgeous new sign outside out theater.

We have all kinds of goodies to express our gratitude. You can get Can Coolers, T-shirts, get your ticket in advance for the show, have your name engraved one of the few chairs that will be a part of this theater for years to come, or maybe even get to have your beautiful face used onstage during The Size Of Pike!

A contribution of any amount is appreciated, adored and as always, tax-deductible.

The Impact

This campaign will not only enhance the immersive experience of Moving Arts' production of The Size Of Pike, but will open up possibilities and improve the quality of our space on Hyperion for the next 20 years. 

Moving Arts is one of the longest running non-profit theaters in LA. It's a warm, welcoming place for actors, writers, directors and producers alike to create adventurous new theater. Your contribution will allow us to continue to evolve and accommodate even more work.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you want to help but cannot contribute that's fine! Please share our campaign with your friends, family and anyone you think may be able to help. Come see the show! Everything helps!

Show Details!

The Size of Pike opens May 3, 2013 and runs through June 1, 2013.  Show dates will be Thursday, Friday and Saturday nights at 8:00 PM.

Moving Arts Hyperion Theater

1822 Hyperion Ave.

Los Angeles, CA 90027

Tickets are available at www.MovingArts.org/size-of-pike/

$20 gets you a ticket and a FREE DRINK!

Thank you for your support!

**If you have a specific request or wish to reserve the ticket incentive for a specific date please, email thesizeofpike@gmail.com**

story:
Alternative Synergy The Company has performed at countless venues around New York and has received recognition from audiences around the world; now, the company is creating its own show “The Debut.”

Who is Alternative Synergy The Company

ASTC is a performing arts company that blends multiple genres of arts and capitalizes on its dancers' diverse backgrounds, cultures and interests to create a truly unique style that is unexpected, dynamic and explicitly “alternative”.  Through an environment of mutual learning, exploration and curiosity of craft, the company creates universal narratives combining balletic shapes, grooves, and illusive movements, composed to an exclusive soundtrack.  The company prides themselves as risk-takers while maintaining accessibility to all audiences.   

The Debut 

In Spring of 2018, ASTC will premiere its first full length production In New York City. The repertoire revisits the definition of "creative being", and encourages audiences to connect through compassion, motivation and the mutual drive to realize and actualize hidden dreams and goals in our everyday life. 

Your Donation

ASTC is a company that thrives on hard work; each week, the artists push themselves outside their comfort zones, both through intense physical training and motivating each other to express complex personal and universal experiences through their art, all whilst being a social and educational force in the arts field.The Debut is set to premiere at the Actors Fund Theater in Brooklyn on Saturday March 17  however the date cannot be yet confirmed due to the lack of funds, which means your donation is even more than ESSENTIAL. Contributing to the campaign will not only enable the culmination of this work to take center stage in our first full length production, but will also help us unleash the confident and influential "creative being" in all who attend the show. All donations will go directly towards the costs of venue rental, rehearsal space, lighting, cinematography and artist insurance. Please help us share our passion and alternative synergy with the global community and donate today!  

Cost Breakdown 

$2000 - Venue Rental

$1000 - Space Rehearsal

$2000 - Stage Production  

$2000 - Videography/Photography

$500 - Costume

$500 - Props

story:
Hello...

   Thank you so much for visiting my IndieGoGo fundraising page! My name is Vivian MirAnn, and I'm a burlesque performer from Albuquerque, New Mexico. I've been involved in burlesque as a solo performer since 2009, and have had the honor to perform at festivals and events across the United States and Canada. In late 2010, I formed the Gilded Cage Burlesk & Varieté, a performers guild of burlesque artists, aerialists, fire performers, belly dancers, Vaudevillians and circus/sideshow artists of all stripes. We have since become a troupe, hosting shows five times per year as well as producing "ABurlyQ! Burlesque & Sideshow Spectaculár!", a weekend-long event held every summer. While many groups across the country focus strictly on burlesque, our troupe recreates historically accurate shows featuring burlesque alongside the Vaudeville and circus-style acts as seen at the turn of the last century.

   The fundraising campaign that I have created will help fund my travels across North America over the winter of 2013. This tour is important both for myself and for the Gilded Cage troupe, as well as New Mexico's burgeoning burlesque scene, as it helps to raise awareness of the existence of our alternative performance art community here in the Southwest. Many people in the country are unaware that there is a thriving burlesque and Vaudeville community here, but we aim to change that! Burlesque and sideshow are uniquely American forms of theatrical art, and the goal of Gilded Cage Burlesk & Varieté and our supporters is to see these art forms thrive again, reaching new audiences that are unaware of the medium's resurgence and importance in American history. In addition, travel forges new contacts for members of the community at large. We bring many performers from across the continent to our home venue, and this tour is sure to expand our talent pool from which to create exciting new shows for our audiences.

On the road again...

   In the past, I have paid for all travel expenses on my own either from my paychecks or from show payouts. Requesting financial help is new to me, but in order to meet the goals of our troupe and continue to expand our community, help is needed to offset gas and hotel expenses. The money raised from this campaign will go strictly to travel expenses. Anything left over from the tour, including payouts and tips, will go toward the Gilded Cage performer fund with the express purpose of paying performers to travel to New Mexico and expand our community.

   In exchange for contributions to this campaign, I'll be offering several perks based on contribution amounts. Most of these items will only be available on IndieGoGo, and won't be found anywhere else! Just select your contribution amount, tell me what you'd like to receive from the list, and I'll send it to you!

Why should you help?

   This isn't just about performances, it's about people. The folks involved in burlesque and Vaudeville work hard to create a visceral experience for audience members. The medium does not exclude based on appearance, physical features, weight, gender or creed. It's a loving community that accepts performers for the unique individuals that they are. Our troupe works to expound on these tenets, providing a safe, welcoming environment for people to explore their creativity free from negativity. Your contributions will help spread the word of our existence. Since I began traveling out on my own, our network has grown by leaps and bounds, making our events the largest and most-inclusive in New Mexico. But there's still many more miles to go...

Can't donate?

   It's a tough economy out there, and we know it! Please feel free to help in smaller ways...sharing this fundraiser with friends and fans of the theater will surely help! IndieGoGo has tools to help share, and word-of-mouth can do miracles!

  Thank you so much for your time, consideration, and assistance. It means the world to me and the gang of the Gilded Cage!

story:
OUR PROJECT AND US

Lord Blackberry's Apocalypse is the story of a delightfully demented owner of a puppet factory in Los Angeles who imprisons his workers inside the factory to save them from the impending apocalypse. Caitlin Bower's psychosexual puppet play explores the ways in which we deceive ourselves in order to survive the tragedies of reality. 

Bower, a graduate of UCLA's School of Theater, Film, and Television where she studied acting and directing, is now making her playwriting debut with the Illyrian Players.

Who are the Illyrian Players? Why would she pick us? The Illyrian Players are a rising LA theater ensemble committed to:

unveiling the relevance of classics,  

creating a haven for artists  and opportunities for women in the theatre,  

promoting a message of sex-positivity and tolerance, 

 and reclaiming the power of theatre  as a subversive art form  with which to change the world!

PLUS: past productions have been given sterling reviews with "GO!" ratings from the LAWEEKLY!! (we produce great work)

WHY WE'RE FUNDRAISING

Bower has been putting money away for a long, long while but theater is always more expensive to produce than originaly conceived and thus we are asking you for help! Our goal of $1500 will cover the rent of the theater, the construction of the puppets (marionets, hand puppets, and full body puppets!!), costumes, props and whatever is left over will go to our fringe campaign!

The Illyrian Players believe whole heartedly in bringing GREAT THEATER TO EVERYONE at recession proof prices. The more we can raise the richer the experience. 

ALL MONEY DONATED GOES DIRECTLY TO THE PRODUCTION!!!

We are truly inspired by Lord Blackberry's Apocalypse and are dedicated to bringing it to full fruition regardless of the fact that no one is getting paid. Your money goes where it counts: to the play. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you love the arts but are in a bind and can not contribute NEVER FEAR! There is more than one way to trim an impecable Blackberry beard: get the word out about our production! Let your lovers, friends, family, coworkers, frenimies (and hey! even your enemies) know about our production and its needs!

We thank you so much for your time and consideration! You rock :)
story_txt:
OUR PROJECT AND US
Lord Blackberry's Apocalypse is the story of a delightfully demented owner of a puppet factory in Los Angeles who imprisons his workers inside the factory to save them from the impending apocalypse. Caitlin Bower's psychosexual puppet play explores the ways in which we deceive ourselves in order to survive the tragedies of reality. 
Bower, a graduate of UCLA's School of Theater, Film, and Television where she studied acting and directing, is now making her playwriting debut with the Illyrian Players.
Who are the Illyrian Players? Why would she pick us? The Illyrian Players are a rising LA theater ensemble committed to:
unveiling the relevance of classics,  
creating a haven for artists  and opportunities for women in the theatre,  
promoting a message of sex-positivity and tolerance, 
 and reclaiming the power of theatre  as a subversive art form  with which to change the world!
PLUS: past productions have been given sterling reviews with "GO!" ratings from the LAWEEKLY!! (we produce great work)
WHY WE'RE FUNDRAISING
Bower has been putting money away for a long, long while but theater is always more expensive to produce than originaly conceived and thus we are asking you for help! Our goal of $1500 will cover the rent of the theater, the construction of the puppets (marionets, hand puppets, and full body puppets!!), costumes, props and whatever is left over will go to our fringe campaign!

story:
A Gentle Spirit 

at the MNfringe festival

an adaptation of Dostoevsky's classic

The play

A pawnbroker stands over the bed of his deceased wife, who has just leapt to her death. In a frenzied reflection he recounts the events of their marriage. The story is unveiled to both the audience and to the pawnbroker himself, as he attempts to understand why his wife committed suicide.

By the end we are given a distillation of pride, power, and the inner workings of empathy and inequality.

Why donate

All money donated goes directly to the production and support of the artists.

  • Compensating the artists for their work and creativity 
  • Publicity
  • Set design
  • Producing fees 

The Artists

Actors:

Matt Wall has a degree in Theater from St. Olaf College and has trained extensively with Atlantic Theater Company (co-founded by David Mamet and William H. Macy) in NYC and LA. He has several acting credits in the area and in NYC. He is a co-founding member of Minneapolis' Theater Pfeffernuus and NYC's Backyard Theater Company. Matt has directed productions for the MN Fringe Festival, and the Sanford Meisner Theatre and HERE Arts Center in NYC. For the past five years, he has served as Resident Director for the Fall semester at Mesabi Range College. Teaching credits include Guest classes at Mesabi Range College, Hibbing Community College, and he led the Theater program for YouthSummer 2008 at UW-Superior. He received an award from Lake Superior Writers for his short play, "This Too Shall Pass". Matt can also play the violin.

Mickaylee Shaugnessy is happy to be part of her fourth MN Fringe Festival.  She has been active in the Twin Cities theater scene since 2004. She is also a company member and board member of Green T Productions.

Creatives:

Andrew Watkins is a Minnesota born theater artist now based in New York City. He trained at The Perpich Center for Arts Education, The Royal Conservatoire of Scotland and Fordham University at Lincoln Center. This is his fifth consecutive production with MNfringe.

Sylvia Bay is a self-proclaimed genius who has spent the last three years at Rarig Center as a U of M undergrad, accumulating splinters, writing shift plots, and getting paint on every single pair of her jeans. She enjoys scenery and props construction and design, stage management, and making sure everything goes according to plan. Additionally, she likes to bake a large batch of cookies during her annual two hours of free-time.

Marlee Leebrick-Stryker holds a Bachelor of Arts degree in Creative Writing from Beloit College. She is currently writing for several publications around the Twin Cities and is planning to attend graduate school in the near future.

Even if you can't give

We thank you for your interest in and support of the arts!

Getting word out always needs some help. Share us on Facebook or Twitter. Tell your friends and family.

Most imortantly come see the show!

We are premiering at the Illusion Theater. You have 5 chances to catch us:

Fri, Aug 2 - 8:30   Sun, Aug 4 - 7:00   Tue, Aug 6 - 5:30   Thu, Aug 8 - 5:30   Sat, Aug 10 - 8:30
