story:
Hello!

I’m Rebecca Lazier, a Canadian-born choreographer based in Brooklyn, New York.  

After 20 years of creating and producing dances here and abroad, I am excited to announce that my newest dance, There Might Be Others, will be presented at New York Live Arts March 16-19, 2016!

It is a great honor to be included in NYLA’s 2016 season. There Might Be Others is my most ambitious project to date and features over 25 amazing collaborators from four countries: 15 dancers and 10 percussionists.

I hope you will collaborate with us as a backer of this project.  We need to raise $13,000 to support the stellar cast artists and help pay for production costs.  Any donation will make a difference and all are fully tax-deductible.  

The Story:

This project began in 2014 with a self created challenge to develop a choreographic adaptation of composer Terry Riley’s In C.  I found this prompt compelling because I have long been interested in open works, emergent forms, and collaborating with performers as co-authors.  Slowly the project grew in scope and took on a life of its own.  Last year I travelled with members of the New York cast to develop the piece through residencies with local dancers in Canada, Turkey, and Poland.  We were able to secure funding to invite performers from each country to be part of the NYLA premiere. I am excited to explore ways the size and diversity of the cast will allow the performance to reflect our global society and contribute to broader conversations about culture and the world at large. 


My amazing team:

Music Collaborators: This summer I began collaborating with composer Dan Trueman to develop the music score.  He is creating the piece with the inimitable ensembles  Sō Percussion and Mobius Percussion, in addition each performance will feature guest percussionists to form a wild and robust sound.  This summer we were all in residence at Sō Percussion’s Summer Institute at Princeton University.  It was fantastic to fill the studio with all of the performers and dozens of instruments and develop a score together. Watching the musicians and dancers become equal participants in the creation of the work was electric.   

Dance Collaborators:  The New York cast is an extraordinary mix of artists: Natalie Green, Simon Courchel, Christopher Ralph, Raja Kelly, Saul Ulerio, Asli Bulbul, Cori Kresge, and Anna Schon!  Turkish collaborators include Tan Temel, the artistic director of TORK Dance and professor of dance at Yildiz Technic University. The Canadian collaborators, Sara Coffin and Rhonda Baker,  are members of Mocean Dance, a Nova Scotia based repertory company dedicated to improvisational forms. The Polish participants, Pawel Sakowicz, Agnieszka Kryst, Ramona Nagabczynska, and Jan Lorys, have presented work independently in Poland, Europe, and New York.

Designers: I am thrilled to be collaborating again with Mary Jo Mecca for the costume design and Davison Scandrett for lighting and visual design.  They are the superb team that designed Coming Together/Attica.


The Ask: 

We have secured several grants but we still need funds to bring this work to life. It is a big vision. To give you an idea of how your contributions will be put to work, consider that: $20 pays for rehearsal space for one hour, $100 pays for the truck to move instruments to and from rehearsal, $160 pays for 8 dancers to rehearse for one hour, $900 pays for one five-hour rehearsal with 8 dancers in a studio with musicians for 5 hours. When we achieve our goal of $13,000 we will have raised enough to pay for 50 hours of rehearsal for everyone.  

With so many different expenses, we simply cannot do this without you. 

Creating this piece has taken us to the far reaches of Turkey and northern Poland and to the forests of Nova Scotia and the sweltering summer studios at Princeton. My favorite moments have been savoring the laughter and joy that arises from building a community of collaborative, interdisciplinary artists.  I am overwhelmed with gratitude for the people who are coming together to make this project a reality. When we previewed the piece in Poland in June a critic said “The performers, who masterfully employ both technique and rhythm in a whimsical and energetic way, created a one-of-the-kind masterwork.”


I hope we can share it with you.Tickets are available here.

With love and gratitude,

Rebecca

If you already know you cannot attend the performance, please consider donating the cost of a ticket $15-30!

*Rebecca Lazier is a sponsored artist with The Performance Zone Inc (dba The Field), a not-for-profit, tax-exempt, 501(c)(3) organization serving the performing arts community. Contributions to The Field earmarked for Rebecca Lazier are tax-deductible to the extent allowed by law. For more information about The Field contact: The Field, 75 Maiden Lane, Suite 906 New York, NY 10038, phone: 212-691-6969 or for our national charities registration. A copy of our latest financial report may be obtained from The Field or from the Office of Attorney General, Charities Bureau, 120 Broadway, New York, NY 10271.

story:
Help us share @ Detroit Dance City Festival and beyond!

Hello and welcome to my first crowdfunding campaign! This campaign arises as I have been given an incredible opportunity to bring my choreography to Detroit, a city that is experiencing profound growth and renewal, in part due to its burgeoning art scene. Two of my recent works have been selected to be presented at the Detroit Dance City Festival (DDCF), a 3-day International Festival taking place in August.  

In order to go to DDCF, and continue creating, it is imperative to acquire funding.  Your tax-deductible donations will ensure that my film, my dance partner, and I get to Detroit; and return with a starter fund for future work. 

Participating in DDCF is bigger than showing these works - it's about sharing in a community-building festival that offers a variety of experiences to the public, and aims to connect artists to each other while connecting Detroit to the world. It is about engaging in this lively moment in Detroit's history, taking part in the conversation, sharing through dance, and returning with more to give.  Read on to learn about DDCF, choreographic works, and next steps. We look forward to performing in Detroit and hope to see you there. 

THANK YOU for helping us GO and GROW.


ABOUT DDCF "Detroit Dance City Festival is a three-day community building event that celebrates dance in its various forms and disciplines... The mission is to educate audiences about the impact of dance, provide opportunities for artists to share their work, and create an artistic network between Michigan, the United States, and the world. DDCF will showcase the work of over 30 local and national and international performing artists and companies."

DANCE FILM FEST 

Oonossa "is a dance in dunes, among the beach heather, in wind and mist. Time moves forward and back, a dry branch partners the grounded movement." This short film is my first exploration in film and collaboration with Fred Hatt; together it was conceived, edited, and self-produced. Oonossa will be screened on Thursday, August 25th @ 6:00 pm @ YMCA Boll Theater.  

CHOREOGRAPHER'S SHOWCASE  

Catchweight/Glass Heart, a duet touching on themes of control and vulnerability in relationships, was originally created with actor/boxer Daniel Krstyen during my 2014 Artist-in-Residency at Chez Bushwick; and premiered at the Center for Performance Research in 2015.  Join us Friday, August 26th @ 7:30 pm @ YMCA Boll Theater to see the newest adaptation, performed with Mariusz Daniel Kujawski.


The Nitty-Gritty and Nifty Gifts!

Your gifts will help us cover these COSTS: 

  • Artist Fees
  • Flights
  • Studio Rental
  • Accommodations
  • Production Fee for DDCF
  • Application Fees for Residencies & Performance Opportunities
  • Costumes, Props, Video Editing, Sound Editing, Photography, Film Scouting and Shooting, & Administrative Expenses  

Funding also secures current and future partnerships. Check out these incredible collaborators:

  • Fred Hatt, Visual Artist, Photographer, Filmmaker, & Editor
  • Daniel Krstyen, Actor/Boxer & original performer in Catchweight/Glass Heart 
  • Mariusz Daniel Kujawski, Dancer
  • Matt Rocker, Musician & Sound Designer
  • Miro Ćelić, Photographer
  • Simone Tobias, Costume Designer 
PLAYFUL PERKS:  Are you a Creative Cat or Party Animal?  Because I adore you (& animals), I created playful packages to say "thank you."  Your contributions are priceless, so please enjoy your perks, you big-hearted animals.

GIVE, sans CA$H!

Contributions come in many forms. Contact kellybuwalda@gmail.com to help.

  • PROPS:  Seeking ladders (new + old, can be broken) for future work. Give if you live in NYC! Seeking 8 ft. aluminum ladder to borrow for 8/27 performance if you live in DETROIT. 
  • SHARE the love by sharing this campaign.

B E Y O N D 

Sneak a peak at my choreographic visions...

  • DANCE FILM SERIES:  Fred and I plan on shooting another film in nature by Autumn 2016, our next step in building a series of films that investigate one's connection to the earth.
  • CATCHWEIGHT CONTINUED:  I intend to grow this work and perform it in NYC at a non-traditional venue by 2017.


Your support is vital, and I am grateful.  Thank you.


ABOUT KELLY BUWALDA

A native of Indiana, Buwalda has been performing, teaching, and creating in NYC for the past 15 years.  She earned her Bachelor of Arts degree in Dance and Psychology from Hope College in Holland, MI, and graduated from New York City's Institute for Integrative Nutrition as a Certified Health Coach.   

Kelly is Teaching Artist with National Dance Institute and with the New York City Ballet, and currently performs with Bianca Johnson and Dancers, as well as in her own work.  Dancing has taken her to the UK, Belgium, Italy, Mexico, and Puerto Rico, and she has enjoyed performing in a variety of theaters as well as site-specific locations. 


Kelly Buwalda, Project-Based Choreographer is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Kelly Buwalda, Project-Based Choreographer must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
About Developing Daisy 

THIS CAMPAIGN IS CLOSED.  OUR NEW CAMPAIGN IS TITLED DEVELOPING DAISY IS HERE!  

WE THANK THOSE OF YOU WHO CONTRIBUTED TO THIS CAMPAIGN.  THOSE FUNDS ARE GOING TOWARDS THE STAGED READINGS RESCHEDULED FOR JUNE 20 AND 21ST.  

PLEASE GO TO OUR NEW PAGE.  

NEW LINK: http://igg.me/at/developingdaisyishere

Helen Newman and Stephanie Glickman have spent many years in the creation of Developing Daisy, a musical in 3 acts with 15 original songs. DAISY is a lesbian love story set in the present, with lengthy flashbacks into the 1970’s, reflecting all that decade’s passion, idealism, politics and drama.

Meet Daisy Frank... an aging photographer, who, reluctant to participate in a retrospective that will bring back memories from her youth, is being urged on by a young hip assistant, Jamie Lerner.  From radically different perspectives, they relive the spirit and politics of that earlier decade while making transformative discoveries about themselves and each other.  Through their unlikely collaboration, and their journey through the "great mother-daughter divide", Daisy comes to terms with the long suppressed pain of her first lesbian love, dispelling the ghosts of her past and embracing her future.

Helen and Stephanie have been working tirelessly to present the first staged reading of the entire play. It will be presented by the Theater for the New City in Manhattan on January 24th and 25th, 2015. With a cast of 10 equity actors and 15 musical numbers, the two performances not only promise to be entertaining and uplifting, but allow you an opportunity to be part of this developmental process.

 WE NEED YOUR HELP!

The Theater for the New City is providing us with rehearsal space as well as their largest theater for the two performances.

In order to take advantage of this generous opportunity and to bring this important historical musical to the next step, we need to raise $10,000. The majority of funding will go towards ensuring that we can put on the most professional quality reading possible with a highly experienced director,  music director, and 10 talented actors/singers.  The  funds will also allow us to hire design consultants and technical support.  We hope to bring in producers and backers can take Developing Daisy on to a full production.

Please Note: If you would like your donation to be tax deductible, please visit our website for instructions on how to mail a check.

     Why is it important to bring Daisy's story to the stage? 

    Developing Daisy is more than just a musical. Your contribution helps fund something bigger, and here are just a few examples of the benefits of donating to fund this production:

    • To keep the memory of this important decade for feminism and
      LGBTQ rights alive
    • To document some of the radical changes that have occurred in those communuties in the last 40 years
    • To add to the stories already on film and the stage which portray marginalized individuals and relationships
    • To be entertained!  To enjoy the experience of music, drama, and humor expressing women's love and connections

       Other Ways You Can Help

      Small donations of any amount are welcome, but if you can't contribute financially, don't worry - you can still help us. Statistically speaking, spreading the word is crucial to the success of our campaign. Please consider helping us get the word out about about our campaign by liking us on Facebook, and sharing our fundraiser with your friends and family.

      Remember, you can share our campaign on Email and Facebook using the Indiegogo share tools at the top of this page! Feedback about our campaign is also welcome, so feel free to send some our way, or to contact us by email at info@developingdaisy.com.

      LEARN MORE ABOUT US AND HEAR MORE SONGS BY CLICKING ON OUR WEBSITE BELOW.

      www.DevelopingDaisy.com
story_txt:
About Developing Daisy 
THIS CAMPAIGN IS CLOSED.  OUR NEW CAMPAIGN IS TITLED DEVELOPING DAISY IS HERE!  
WE THANK THOSE OF YOU WHO CONTRIBUTED TO THIS CAMPAIGN.  THOSE FUNDS ARE GOING TOWARDS THE STAGED READINGS RESCHEDULED FOR JUNE 20 AND 21ST.  
PLEASE GO TO OUR NEW PAGE.  
NEW LINK: http://igg.me/at/developingdaisyishere
 Helen Newman and Stephanie Glickman have spent many years in the creation of Developing Daisy, a musical in 3 acts with 15 original songs. DAISY is a lesbian love story set in the present, with lengthy flashbacks into the 1970’s, reflecting all that decade’s passion, idealism, politics and drama.
Meet Daisy Frank... an aging photographer, who, reluctant to participate in a retrospective that will bring back memories from her youth, is being urged on by a young hip assistant, Jamie Lerner.  From radically different perspectives, they relive the spirit and politics of that earlier decade while making transformative discoveries about themselves and each other.  Through their unlikely collaboration, and their journey through the "great mother-daughter divide", Daisy comes to terms with the long suppressed pain of her first lesbian love, dispelling the ghosts of her past and embracing her future.
Helen and Stephanie have been working tirelessly to present the first staged reading of the entire play. It will be presented by the Theater for the New City in Manhattan on January 24th and 25th, 2015. With a cast of 10 equity actors and 15 musical numbers, the two performances not only promise to be entertaining and uplifting, but allow you an opportunity to be part of this developmental process.

 WE NEED YOUR HELP!
The Theater for the New City is providing us with rehearsal space as well as their largest theater for the two performances.

To be entertained!  To enjoy the experience of music, drama, and humor expressing women's love and connections

story:
Join RE|Dance Group as we take contemporary dance theatre across the country.  Our Goal is to transport nine ensemble members and a 25 foot wall to surprise, delight and inspire audiences with our new work, “It’s About Love Again This Year.”  Your contribution to our campaign will make RE|Dance Group’s touring schedule for 2015 a reality.  In “It’s About Love Again This Year” text and visual design collide with movement.  RE|Dance Group creates fully realized worlds where every action, sound, and visual carries important information in understanding the whole.  We find that these multiple entry points invite the viewer to lean forward and feel. 

Michael Estanich and I established RE|Dance Group in 2009 as a means to explore long distance collaborations and present dance theatre works that examine the many facets of human relationships.  I am the Executive Director of RE|Dance Group as well as a Chicago based dance artist and teacher.  Artistic Director, Michael Estanich, lives in Wisconsin, working at the University of Wisconsin-Stevens Point as an Associate Professor of Dance.  Our creative process embodies rich emotional content and dramatic imagery through the layering of music, text and sculpture.  We seek to establish physical memories that enrich our dancing and the relationships created in our works.  We are like-minded artists that have the same movement aesthetic and we happen to also be the best of friends.

Contributing to On the Road with RE|Dance Group would allow our partnership to continue growing as it has over the past 6 years.  The initial duets we began making grew into a company of nine dancers and this company of nine dancers is now establishing a touring schedule that will take us to several cities in 2015.  We appreciate your support in helping us share our work with people across the country.  Every donation amount makes an impact on our work and we feel so grateful to have your support.  We hope to see you in a theater in your town or city soon!

Love, 

Lucy (and Michael)

story:
Our Story

Black River Dance is a beautiful space in Central Harlem with two spacious dance studios.  Currently, it is primarily being used as a rental space for parties.  The neighborhood and the space itself are begging to become a consistent arts and community space, offering dance classes to children and adults.  Black River Dance Academy (www.blackriverdanceacademy.com) now offers ballet, modern, jazz, African, yoga, and fitness classes to teens and adults, dance classes to children ages 4-11 on Saturdays, and a Friday Afternoon Arts Academy for the charter school students who dismiss early on Fridays.  They receive lunch, homework tutoring, and a dance class from 1-5:30pm.  Eventually the venue will also present up and coming artists of all genres in a cabaret style with catered food and wine included in the price of the ticket: "Picnic at Black River."  We are interested in outreach among the community, local artists, and educational groups.
About Me

My name is Melissa Edwards, Program Director, and I have danced all of my life.  I moved to Harlem, found the space, and feel my background prepared me for an undertaking such as founding Black River Dance Academy.  I earned a BFA in Dance from Ohio University, an MA from NYU, and an MFA from Smith College.  I taught the last 10 years in high schools and colleges and taught for children and adults in myriad studios before that.  I adore teaching and finding ways to share creative outlets in my community.  Black River Dance Academy has endless possibilities, and I am ready to put my energy into developing it as a dance academy and a presenting venue. 

What We Need 

Finances are definitely the biggest issue in registering students in this neighborhood.  Many families do not have the extra money for dance classes.  We put the price point extremely low to attempt to include the entire community, but many still cannot afford it.  Most classes in NYC are between $15 and $20; ours are $8-$10.  At these prices, we cannot cover our costs.  Plus, we would like to offer scholarships to students who are enthusiastic but truly cannot find $50 for the semester.  To cover our semester with the registration we have now, we need:

$2,000 for rent

$1,200 for administration costs (120 hours at $10/hour.  This is over 8 weeks and actually not nearly enough, but we are all donating much of our time).

$400 for ballet barres

$1,000 for marketing brochures and online advertisements

$5,140 is the difference in what we made in tuition versus what we need to develop the program, including paying teachers a fair wage even for classes with low enrollment right now.

We appreciate every dollar.  Please find our perks with every contribution on the next page!

    The Impact

    The arts and dance are an amazing way to grow emotionally, socially, and intellectually.  Many people in Harlem do not have access to affordable dance programs that are based on quality education with a community building priority.  Black River Dance Academy offers classes to children, tweens, teens, and adults, as well as family friendly classes like Thursday's African class.  Guest artist classes on Saturdays and performances create exposure to new genres of art.  We soon will create a company from the dancers at Black River and plan to have them perform at the famous Apollo Theater (a block away) and at other venues around the city.

      Risks & Challenges

      The largest obstacle is clearly funding.  BRDA needs to reach outside of the immediate proximity to find more customers who can pay full tuition.  We seek corporate sponsors and relationships with schools and other programs to support our community being able to continue dancing.  While we develop those relationships, we need you to help us keep the doors open this semester!

      The face of Harlem is changing with high-rises and gut renovations occurring on every block.  Black River Dance Academy is located on "Restaurant Row" of Harlem and primed to be in the perfect position as the neighborhood continues to grow.

        Other Ways You Can Help

        If you do not have the funds right now, please consider sharing this page with those who may want to help or with NYC residents looking for quality dance classes for a reasonable fee!

story:
I am Jonette Mungo. I am a mother, teacher, actress, and playwright.  This play, Mirror, Mirror on the Wall, is an amazing tale of survival, love, and forgiveness. This is a unique story as it is my story.  I call it autobiographical fiction.  I am a country girl.  I am the granddaughter of farmers who grew up cultivating an acre garden from which my uncles, aunts and grandparents all gathered.  It was a humble life but it was by no means poor.  I am not your cliché and neither is this story.  The main character in this story is Aurhora.  She had it all growing up and still her life was no fairytale.  She lost her virginity to rape, her self-esteem before that had been destroyed from family and she entered young adulthood as a broken person.  That brokenness caused her to spiral into out of control abusive relationships that almost end her life.  She sees her life as a cruel joke that God plays on her and she can’t seem to get it right.  But in the end-there is the constant. Herself. No matter what- it is Aurhora who must decide, change, or continue on living this way.

The uniqueness of this show is also in how the story is told.  Mirror, Mirror on the Wall is told through monologue, dialogue, spoken word, dance, video re-enactments, original song and multiple character portrayal both on stage and on screen.  There is no other one-woman show that has delicately and craftily combined so many storytelling mediums to effectively reach its audience.  This show does that!

It has taken me four years to write and re-write this show.  The women and men I shared its content with encouraged me to finish it.  They could all see a piece of themselves or someone they knew in what Aurhora’s story is.  They all wanted to see and know how it would end as if Aurhora’s story could help them figure out how to get out of the darkness and onto a better path.  That is why this show must take the stage.  Your help is needed to reach, teach, and help women and men come through the rough places and find their place of peace.  Afterall, what is good theatre if it doesn’t make you feel something? Good theatre impacts its audience.  Mirror, Mirror on the Wall is good theatre!

The Crispus Attucks Theatre is the birthplace of this show.  This theatre was first home to local black performers who had nowhere else to share their talents and gifts.  It is still giving life to new artists and children of all walks of life.  This theatre is one of the oldest historically black theatres in the country.  Since its renovation and restoration in 2005 it is yet to establish ongoing seasons of shows.  That is what gave rise to the writer’s workshop.  To develop new writers so the Attucks Theatre Stage can once again be alive with new artists and new works.  Mirror, Mirror on the Wall is the show to establish the inaugural season of shows at this magical place.

Your contribution will help to make this happen. We want to make this a quality show and bring it to theatres across the country.  With your help we can.

$3500 is needed to pay for the use of the theatre

$2000 is need for promotion and advertisement materials and services

$1500 is needed for set design and construction

$2500 is needed for the cinematography, original music score, and multimedia elements

$500 is needed for costumes and makeup

No matter how small your donation, it helps.  Spreading the word to others who can give helps. Telling organizations you are a part of about this production helps.  We thank you for your all your help and assistance in making this happen.

Like our page on Face Book Mirror, Mirror on the Wall.  You can also find it at www.facebook.com/aurhora.mirror

You can also follow us on Twitter at https://twitter.com/Aurhora757

story:
Coming to Bad Ends

a new electro-pop musical

Based on the novel mysteries by Knut Hamsun

Book & Lyrics by John Aldous
Music by Lucas Segall
Directed & Choreographed by Brandon Powers
Music Directed by Patrick Sulken
Casting by Geri Silver
General Management by Evan Bernardin
Produced by Feast Productions
Featuring: Carl Wilson, Celeste Rose, Kasey Huizinga, Nick Day, Robby Dalton, Charlie Kolarich, Embry Thielmeier, Laura Winters, & Gaby Hornig

Video by Andy Zou * Vocals by Andi Aladeff 

Special Thanks to Dana O’Brien!
 

About the Piece

In the summer of ’91 (1891 that is) Johan Nagel comes upon a small Norwegian coastal town. The town enchants him, and he elects to spend the summer there. He falls madly in love with Dagny, a woman whose fiancé is currently stationed far away. Despite the protestations and warnings of others, Nagel falls in deep with Dagny’s seductive social circle. Little does he know that Dagny is not unaccustomed to breaking hearts and his new friends might not have his best interests in mind.

This new musical is currently having its first developmental workshop at Standard Toykraft in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. The workshop runs September 6th-12th, culminating in an invited rehearsal on the evening of the 12th to share the week’s work with collaborators, supporters, and curious community members.


Why We Need Your Support

Writing a new musical is solitary work and we are excited to have the opportunity to explore the piece in collaboration with real bodies and voices in the room. We’ve reached the point in our process where it is no longer useful to murmur in living rooms and endlessly email---it’s time to get the piece into a space where it can breathe.

While this workshop doesn’t require fancy costumes or other production elements, it does require a few main costs:

*Rehearsal Space*

Finding a space to rehearse an amplified electro-pop musical for a reasonable rate in New York is challenging. We are lucky to be working in Standard Toykraft’s beautiful Williamsburg space for the entirety of our workshop with ample space to sing, dance, and explore.

*Sound Equipment*

Since we are at the point in our process where a keyboard just won’t cut it we do have to use microphones, amps, and a sound system in order to really explore this musical’s unique electro-pop score.

*Artist Compensation*

We are very fortunate to have an outstanding croup of innovative young artists working on this piece. You can check out a little about them below:


John Aldous (Book & Lyrics)

John Aldous is a Texas-born playwright, librettist and lyricist. He graduated from Northwestern University where he studied theatre and English literature. His plays include Presidential Roulette (which takes place in the mind of Abraham Lincoln), Alice at the Occupation (which takes place at Occupy Philadelphia circa Thanksgiving 2011), and Christmas Study #55 (which takes place on Christmas).


Lucas Segall (Composer)

Lucas is a Brooklyn-based composer and producer who creates instrumental and electronic concert music, recordings, and film scores. He collaborates regularly with numerous musicians, filmmakers and theatre artists.


Brandon Powers (Director & Choreographer)

Brandon Powers is a director and choreographer from New York City.   He directed and choreographed PINK MILK at Oracle Productions, which was nominated for four 2014 Non-Equity Jeff Awards including Best Choreography and Best Ensemble and voted Best Free Show in Chicago by Newcity.  Powers attended New York Stage and Film's Powerhouse Apprentice Program, where he studied directing and worked with renowned theatre artists including Theresa Rebeck, Doug Hughes and Michael Mayer.  He has trained in various styles of dance with Paul Taylor Dance Company, Mark Morris Dance Group, Harkness Dance Center, and Steps on Broadway. His directing credits include: MUSIC OF THE NIGHT (a dance-driven adaptation of PHANTOM OF THE OPERA), NIJINSKY'S LAST DANCE, WOYZECK, as well as the world premiere, FringeNYC, Chicago Fringe, and Oracle productions of PINK MILK.  Choreography credits include THE MUSICAL ADVENTURES OF FLAT STANLEY (dir. Lookingglass Theatre Company's David Catlin), THE PAJAMA GAME, GREASE, and PIPPIN. He is a proud graduate of Northwestern University.


Patrick Sulken (Music Director)

Patrick Sulken is a music director based in New York City.  Most recently, he served as the standby conductor of the 1st National Tour of Peter and the Starcatcher and as the Music Director of Dani Girl at Exit, Pursued by a Bear.  Other NYC: Little Miss Sunshine (2econd Stage), Titanic (Avery Fisher), Story Pirates.  Regional: Gigi (Kennedy Center), Lempicka (Yale Rep).  Film: Ithaca (John Mellencamp, composer).  As a composer and arranger, Patrick's work has been heard at Signature (NY), NYMF, and the Smithsonian Folklife Festival.  His first original musical, Met by Moonlight, premiered in July 2013 at The Music Theatre Company in Chicago, IL. Proud Northwestern University graduate.

 

Evan Bernardin (General Manager)

Evan Bernardin is a New York City based General Manager and Producer. A recent graduate of Marymount Manhattan College's Theatre Arts program, Evan has spent the last year apprenticing for Leonard Soloway Productions, aiding in the development of projects headed both on and off Broadway. As a freelance General Manager Evan has worked for The Workshop Theatre Company, The Broadway Youth Ensemble, Born for Broadway, and his independent company, JEM Theatricals. Additionally, Evan has collaborated on projects including performances at Lincoln Center, The United Nations, The Harvard Club, Georgetown's Gaston Hall, The Culture Project, The Ohio Theatre, and The Metropolitan Museum.

 

Geri Silver (Casting)

Geri is delighted to work with Feast Productions on Coming to Bad Ends. She moved to the New York City area last year after earning a Master's degree in Media and Communications from City University London, and now works full time as a Program Associate at The Paley Center for Media. She spends her spare time immersed in theatre and Instagramming her cats.

 

Feast Productions (Producer)

Feast Productions creates nourishing theatrical experiences with a focus on intimacy, technology, and spectacular fantasy. We believe art is both a necessity and a luxury and that audiences of all ages benefit from access to culture. We are committed to new work, new artists, and new audiences.www.feast-productions.com

Writing a new musical
is solitary work and we are excited to have the opportunity to explore the
piece in collaboration with real bodies and voices in the room. We’ve reached
the point in our process where it is no longer useful to murmur in living rooms
and endlessly email---it’s time to get the piece into a space where it can
breathe.
While this workshop
doesn’t require fancy costumes or other production elements, it does
require a few main costs:
*Rehearsal Space*
Finding a space to
rehearse an amplified electro-pop musical for a reasonable rate in New York is
challenging. We are lucky to be working in Standard Toykraft’s beautiful
Williamsburg space for the entirety of our workshop with ample space to sing,
dance, and explore.
*Sound Equipment*
Since we are at the
point in our process where a keyboard just won’t cut it we do have to use
microphones, amps, and a sound system in order to really explore this musical’s
unique electro-pop score.
*Artist Compensation*
We are very fortunate
to have an outstanding croup of innovative young artists working on this piece.
You can check out a little about them below:

John Aldous (Book & Lyrics)
John Aldous is a Texas-born playwright, librettist
and lyricist. He graduated from Northwestern University where he studied
theatre and English literature. His plays include Presidential Roulette
(which takes place in the mind of Abraham Lincoln), Alice at the
Occupation (which takes place at Occupy Philadelphia circa Thanksgiving
2011), and Christmas Study #55 (which takes place on Christmas).

Lucas Segall (Composer)
Lucas is a Brooklyn-based composer and producer who
creates instrumental and electronic concert music, recordings, and film scores.
He collaborates regularly with numerous musicians, filmmakers and theatre
artists.

Brandon Powers (Director & Choreographer)
Brandon Powers is a director and choreographer from
New York City.   He directed and choreographed PINK MILK at Oracle
Productions, which was nominated for four 2014 Non-Equity Jeff Awards including
Best Choreography and Best Ensemble and voted Best Free Show in Chicago by
Newcity.  Powers attended New York Stage and Film's Powerhouse Apprentice
Program, where he studied directing and worked with renowned theatre artists
including Theresa Rebeck, Doug Hughes and Michael Mayer.  He has trained
in various styles of dance with Paul Taylor Dance Company, Mark Morris Dance
Group, Harkness Dance Center, and Steps on Broadway. His directing credits
include: MUSIC OF THE NIGHT (a dance-driven adaptation of PHANTOM OF THE
OPERA), NIJINSKY'S LAST DANCE, WOYZECK, as well as the world premiere,
FringeNYC, Chicago Fringe, and Oracle productions of PINK MILK.  Choreography
credits include THE MUSICAL ADVENTURES OF FLAT STANLEY (dir. Lookingglass
Theatre Company's David Catlin), THE PAJAMA GAME, GREASE, and PIPPIN. He is a
proud graduate of Northwestern University.

Patrick Sulken (Music Director)
Patrick Sulken is a music director based in New York
City.  Most recently, he served as the standby conductor of the 1st
National Tour of Peter and the Starcatcher and as the Music Director
of Dani Girl at Exit, Pursued by a Bear.  Other NYC: Little
Miss Sunshine (2econd Stage), Titanic (Avery Fisher), Story
Pirates.  Regional: Gigi (Kennedy Center), Lempicka (Yale
Rep).  Film: Ithaca (John Mellencamp, composer).  As a
composer and arranger, Patrick's work has been heard at Signature (NY), NYMF,
and the Smithsonian Folklife Festival.  His first original
musical, Met by Moonlight, premiered in July 2013 at The Music Theatre
Company in Chicago, IL. Proud Northwestern University graduate.
 
Evan Bernardin (General Manager)
Evan Bernardin is a New York City based General
Manager and Producer. A recent graduate of Marymount Manhattan College's
Theatre Arts program, Evan has spent the last year apprenticing for Leonard
Soloway Productions, aiding in the development of projects headed both on and
off Broadway. As a freelance General Manager Evan has worked for The Workshop
Theatre Company, The Broadway Youth Ensemble, Born for Broadway, and his
independent company, JEM Theatricals. Additionally, Evan has collaborated on
projects including performances at Lincoln Center, The United Nations, The
Harvard Club, Georgetown's Gaston Hall, The Culture Project, The Ohio Theatre,
and The Metropolitan Museum.
 
Geri Silver (Casting)
Geri is delighted to work with Feast Productions
on Coming to Bad Ends. She moved to the New York City area last year after
earning a Master's degree in Media and Communications from City University
London, and now works full time as a Program Associate at The Paley Center for
Media. She spends her spare time immersed in theatre and Instagramming her
cats.
 
Feast Productions (Producer)
Feast Productions creates nourishing theatrical
experiences with a focus on intimacy, technology, and spectacular fantasy. We
believe art is both a necessity and a luxury and that audiences of all ages
benefit from access to culture. We are committed to new work, new artists, and
new audiences.www.feast-productions.com

story:
HI! 


This indiegogo goal is to support an independently produced production of           THE MISANTHROPE at The Bryant Lake Bowl

 We are seasoned theater artists in collaboration with local Minneapolis musicians. The net revenue of this project goes entirely to the artists so any amount will help.

We are looking to raise only $700 to advance this production and its cause! 

 And, of course, we want you to come see it!

But first, here's why we're doing this campaign:


YOUR HELP... 

    • WILL further support the costume design, which is based in New York's current fashion trends. This classic 17th Century play is being adapted to take place in New York's High Fashion Society. In a play about a man who has come to hate society this adaptation ups the ante by making him someone who once loved creating what society would wear.

    • WILL help increase the production's exposure and Actor's fees. The Bryant Lake Bowl has a strong presence in Minneapolis, but we would like to spread the word out as much as possible to fill the seats. The more we can help bring people into the theater for every performance, the more the actors will be rewarded for their work. The acting company is going to share the net profits of this production. 

    • WILL increase the fee of the musicians for their work, the band is made up of local, young rock musicians that are excited to join up with a live theater event. They have a small fee already, but your contribution will go towards increasing that fee and helping collaborations of this kind.

    Your contribution WILL continue the mission of combining the live arts disciplines through a cooperative collective and bringing those                                         collaborations to life!



    WHAT IS THIS SHOW!?


    Director Adrian Balbontin’s contemporary adaptation of Moliere’s cynical couplet comedy of mis-manners transports the action from the salons of 17th Century France to the studios of today’s New York fashion scene; where you cut your teeth by cutting people down as you claw your way to the top. Sam Pearson is Alceste, the misanthropic designer desperate to escape the hypocrisy of society and the couture life at large, and features Charla Marie Bailey, Brian Coffin, Devon Cox, Nathan Gebhard, Anni Jordan-Amberg, Pegeen Lamb, Todd O’Dowd, and Joe Scheller. The band, covering the music of Beirut, will also accompany throughout the 90-minute performance.

    The production team includes Jenna Rose Graupmann (Costumes) and Emily Sullivan (Stage Manager). The band is Maya Baglein, Lauren Endorf, Sasha Ivanosky-Schow, Greg Novak, and Joe Scheller.


    The Misanthrope will open on Fri., Jan. 2 and run through Sat., Jan. 17; with performances on Fri., Jan. 2, Sat. Jan 3, and Thurs. Jan. 8 & 15 at 7pm, and Fri., Jan. 9 & 16 and Sat. Jan. 10 & 17 at 10pm. Admission is $10-15 sliding scale. For tickets, please call the Bryant-Lake Bowl’s box office at 612.825.8949 or log on to bryantlakebowl.com. 


    The producer/director, Adrian Balbontin, is a theatre director new to Minneapolis. He's lived in New York, Los Angeles, and Chicago, but it was in the Twin Cities where he was most inspired by the energy of the theater community. He's about supporting performance artists, especially theatre artists, and believe they should always be rewarded for their work. The more often our society can do this, the more live art stays ingrained in our daily lives, the stronger and more connected we are as a community.


     AND REMEMBER...

    Tell your friends! 
    Share this campaign! 
    Come see the show!

story:
The Project

"Esther, Sweet Esther" is a new comedic/dramatic operetta based on the biblical Book of Esther which tells the story of how a beautiful Jewish maiden became the Queen of Ancient Persia and saved the Jewish people from annihilation at the hands of the evil Prime Minister, Haman. Music and Lyrics by Jeremiah Ginsberg and Book by Wendy Ross Ginsberg and Jeremiah Ginsberg.
 
For over 2 years, Jeremiah & Wendy Ginsberg have been pouring all their creative juices into writing this new operetta (their 4th musical), and now they have been invited to produce the show at Maranatha Church in Paramus, NJ. The first public performances of “Esther, Sweet Esther” in Concert are scheduled for August 16, 17 & 18, 2013. 
 
This will be an outstanding theatrical event! Admission is Free! All are welcome! The producers desire that as many people as possible be given the opportunity to experience this great end-time work as it makes its way to Broadway.
 
The Ginsbergs were invited to present 2 arias from “Esther, Sweet Esther” at The Presidential Inaugural Prayer Breakfast in Washington, DC on January 21, 2013. The cast received a standing ovation with thunderous applause!
 
Rabbi Jonathan Cahn, the keynote speaker at the Prayer Breakfast, wrote: “Congratulations on your success at the Inaugural Prayer Breakfast. The rendition of the two songs from ‘Esther, Sweet Esther’ was wonderful!”
 
The authors pray that this musical will bring hope and joy in the midst of the prevailing climate of prejudice towards the Jewish people, the nation of Israel, and the Christians who have come under persecution throughout the world today.
 

The Cast And Creative Team

The fantastic cast includes the following notable performers: Stephen Len White (International Tour, “Phantom of the Opera”), Christopher Regan (National Tour, “Evita”), George Comtois (First Broadway Revival, “West Side Story”), Denny Hollowell (Core Tenor, Virginia Symphony), DeAnn Trimarchi (Brooklyn Academy of Music, Opera),  and Gary Selman, the famous radio personality from “The Two Nice Jewish Boys!” Solo Violin, Les Morrison, Kirk Baker, Bass. Choreography by Carolyn Paddock and Music Direction by Peter Fuchs.

What We Need & What You Get

The budget is broken down into 2 phases. For Phase 1, we need money to buy airline tickets to fly the team into NJ from all over the country. Airfare will cost approximately $3,825.00. The second most important budget item in Phase 1 is the cost of 7 hotel rooms for 6 nights: $4,956.00. The third item is the pre-pay cost of renting a 12-passenger van at Newark Airport: $889.00. These items must be paid for as soon as possible before the rates go up by double or triple!

History

The Ginsbergs are pioneers in the creation of award-winning Biblical musicals. They wrote and produced “Rabboni,” a Messianic Gospel musical on the life of Yeshua, at the off-Broadway Perry Street Theatre in 1985 to rave reviews:

  • "Ebullient Joy!" - Richard F. Shepard of The New York Times 
  • "An Up-Tempo Captivating Success!" - The Jewish Telegraphic Agency

The 700 Club brought their camera crew into the theatre and produced a feature story on “Rabboni” which aired in December of 1985.

The Ginsbergs wrote and produced their second award-winning musical, “Mendel & Moses,” dramatizing the life of Moses and the Exodus from Egypt, in 1997 at The Century City Playhouse in Los Angeles and at The Canon Theatre in Beverly Hills. The critics raved:
  • “Charming and Full of Wit & Wisdom!” - Ed Kaufman, The Hollywood Reporter
  • "Mendel brings humor and high spirits to the story! Rousing laughs along the way!" - Don Shirley, The Los Angeles Times
  • "Excellent music! With its feet on the ground, its heart in the heavens, and that irrepressible twinkle in its eye, 'Mendel & Moses' is on the side of the angels and good for what ails a sickened society! Critic's Choice!" - Polly Warfield, Drama-Logue
They wrote and produced a third musical, “The Time of Mendel’s Trouble,” about the end-times and the Two Witnesses in the Book of Revelation, in 2008 off-Broadway at The Beckett Theatre.
  • "Music and lyrics are clever. And when it's funny, it's very funny!" - Laurie Lawson, The Electronic Link Journey

The Impact

The timely message in "Esther, Sweet Esther" is a beautiful reminder that when faced with impossibly dire circumstances, there is hope! There is help from Heaven!

Other Ways You Can Help

Please pass this crowdfunding project on to your friends, rabbis, church leaders, politicians, especially those who support Israel! And if you are in the Paramus, NJ area, please come to a performance on August 16, 17 or 18, 2013! We would love to see you there! Use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
HI!  Im Chaya.  Playwright.  Director.  Producer...gulp.  Hunter Emery (actor extraordinaire) and I have decided to dive into the theatre pool, head first, and produce my new (fourth) full length play, Everyone I Love is Dead...a comedy!  About seven extremely different strangers, having survived an apocalyptic plague, trying to stand one another in a basement in Brooklyn, New York.  (There's a twist).

As you might assume...things cost money.  All things.  And in this case...theatre things.  The theatre itself, costumes, lights, light person, set, set person, fire guard insurance...what!? ETC!  yep.  It's expensive.  And this money you donate will help us, not only produce my original work...but also get that proverbial foot one foot further in that proverbial door.  (say that five times fast and I will pay YOU)  (just kidding.  I can't pay you to say that five times fast.  I'm not even paying my actors.  They would be so offended.)

Whatever you donate...any amount, will help us reach our goals...and our dreams. 

That's right...I went there.  

Thank you!  Thank you!  Thank you!

Chaya Doswell and Hunter Emery

 

This money is a start.  Every inch...every dime...every umph of your investment will go straight into the pockets of our project (not our skinny jeans),  no matter what.  NO MATTER WHAT!  This play will be up on July29th and run through August 4th.  And that is a promise.
